HEADLINE: Q & A 

BYLINE:  By JANET PIORKO

 BODY:
 A Group on a Cruise

Q. I am planning to take a family group of around 30 on a week's cruise next January from San Diego to Cabo San Lucas, Puerto Vallarta and other ports in Mexico. Are there travel agencies specializing in such group bookings, or would I work through a regular retail travel agency? --N.S., La Jolla, Calif.

A. Any retail travel agency should be able to handle your group, according to Karen Bohning, a spokeswoman for the Cruise Lines International Association. You can search on the association's Web site at www.cruising.org for agencies with cruise expertise by geographical area. The agencies' listings indicate their specialties, including groups.
 Bob Pavon, a cruise specialist with Carefree Vacations in La Jolla who handles 8 to 10 groups a year, ranging in size from 20 to 120, said the extent of an agency's negotiating power usually depended on how much business it did with a given cruise line. "If the agency does more groups, they're going to have more clout," he said. 
 Cruise lines typically allow one free berth for a certain number of paying clients; with midpriced cruise lines, the number is generally one free for each 15 passengers paying full fare, according to Margaret Stein, another cruise specialist, who works with Travel Dynamics Group in La Jolla. For a deluxe ship, "it can be as low as one for five," she said.
 Groups have priority in dining room seating, Mr. Pavo said, generally getting their pick of early or late times. Ms. Stein said you can expect the line to give you a seating chart so you can organize your party into, say, three tables of 10.
 Other amenities you can request, according to both agents, include wine in everyone's cabin or a setup for a group photo with everyone getting a copy. Larger groups, say 50 or more, might get a cocktail party with open bar for an hour, Mr. Pavo said.
 He suggests booking as far in advance as possible; you can usually reserve a year ahead. "One, you get better pricing, because as the ship fills up the prices go up," he said. "And two, you have more time to get people into your group and get more amenities."
 One cruise that seems to match what you are looking for is aboard the Ryndam, a Holland America vessel sailing round trip from San Diego next Jan. 24 and calling at Cabo San Lucas, Mazatlan and Puerto Vallarta. Mr. Pavo cited a fare of $721.51 a person, double occupancy, for the seven-night itinerary, including port charges and fees, based on his agency's status as a premium preferred agency with the line.
 More information: Carefree Vacations, (800) 683-4074; Travel Dynamics Group, (858) 551-4000; Holland America: (877) 724-5425 or www.hollandamerica.com. 

Dogs Entering New Zealand

Q. We would like to go skiing in New Zealand this summer, but our Shih Tzu goes everywhere with us. Can dogs enter New Zealand without quarantine? -- Helen Fazio, Bridgewater, N.J.

A. No, dogs and cats traveling to New Zealand face a mandatory quarantine, according to Sally Aitken, technical adviser for Import Management at the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry in Wellington. And since the quarantine is for 30 days, it is doubtful that you would want to take your pet along.
 Moreover, the application procedure is quite complicated. The place to start is on the Web at www.maf.govt.nz/biosecurity/imports/animals/standards/index.htm, where you can check on the standards for various pets and countries, and find application forms. 
 You can also contact the Import Management Section, Animal Biosecurity Group, Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, Post Office Box 2526, Wellington, New Zealand; telephone (64-4) 498-9625, fax (64-4) 474-4132. 
 Four types of dogs (including crosses of these breeds) are not permitted into New Zealand at all: the American pit bull terrier, dogo Argentino, Japanese tosa and Brazilian fila.

Shipping Luggage

Q. I have been attending my World War II unit reunions for 20 years, but larger pieces of luggage are getting to be more than I can handle. Is there some economical way to ship ahead of time to the reunion hotel -- this year in San Jose, Calif. -- and back? I'm thinking of a foot locker weighing around 60 pounds packed. -- R.J. Janer, Brooklyn

A. UPS and FedEx are among the shippers that will handle such a request. (FedEx also ships luggage internationally, while UPS handles only items like golf clubs and skis internationally, according to Dan McMackin, UPS public relations manager.)
 UPS prefers suitcases to be boxed, Mr. McMackin said. (You can buy boxes at UPS locations or order them in bulk online; for example, a UPS authorized shipping outlet in Brooklyn called Postnet, (718) 852-0082, sells suitcase boxes 24 by 10 by 31 inches for $4.89.) If the luggage is not boxed, insurance covers only contents, not the luggage, which UPS considers the container. But with that one caveat, UPS agents said the company would ship the footlocker unboxed if you prefer. 
 It's a good idea to alert your hotel about the shipment and be sure there is a safe place to store it. Avoid packing anything that might be considered hazardous materials, like cologne, cigarette lighters or other flammable goods. You should put a shipping label inside the luggage in case the one outside is damaged or lost.
 To calculate the cost, you need the origin and destination ZIP code and the approximate dimensions and weight of the shipment. You can find worksheets on www.ups.com or www.fedex.com, or call UPS at (800) 742-5877 or FedEx at (800) 463-3339. 
 UPS quoted a charge of around $60 for a footlocker 30 by 16 by 16 inches and weighing 60 pounds if you have it picked up at your home. That rate is for UPS Ground service, which takes up to five business days, and includes a $5 charge for an unboxed item and $500 worth of insurance coverage.
 According to FedEx agents, you can't arrange a pickup at your home for Fedex Ground shipment; that is available only to businesses, not to residential customers. The least expensive shipment with at-home pickup would be a three-day FedEx Express; the company's agents quoted a cost of around $116 including $500 insurance. If you can take the footlocker to a FedEx location, agents said, the cost would be around $37 for a five-day FedEx Ground shipment. JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
A Muscle-Flexing Euro On a Costlier Continent

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT 

 BODY:
TO the threat of terrorist attacks, the quavering American economy and the specter of SARS, add another troubling development for the tourism trade, especially in Europe: the dollar is plumbing historic lows against the euro.
 The dollar has been weakening against Europe's common currency for months, but the rate of decline has picked up precipitously in recent weeks, since the United States government signaled that it would tolerate a weaker dollar to help revive the American economy. 
The euro began last week trading at an exchange rate of $1.17, within a penny of where it began trading four years ago. Currency traders predict it could rise to $1.30 by next year. It had already risen nearly 7 percent against the dollar since May 1 and close to 30 percent in the last 12 months. 
 Simply put, Europe is almost one-third more expensive for American visitors than it was last summer.
 "It is getting to the point where people from the States visiting Europe will say, 'I paid $3 for a cup of coffee,"' said Urs Eberhard, director of the North American office of Switzerland Tourism.
 Although Switzerland still uses francs rather than euros, the euro is widely circulated there, and even the currencies of non-euro countries have risen strongly against the newly humbled dollar. The tricky question is how badly the weak dollar will affect American tourism in Europe. The number of Americans who visited Europe dropped 1.2 percent in February, from the same month last year, which was down sharply itself after 9/11, according to the European Travel Commission's most recent statistics. 
 But travel executives attribute that in large part to the war in Iraq and persistent fears of terrorism. The outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, has gutted tourism in Asia and hurt it everywhere else, including Europe, because some people fear contracting the virus on a plane.
 With such a confluence of negative forces, travel-industry executives said, the impact of a weak dollar is difficult to measure.
 "How do you separate it from all the other influences?" said Christian Fiederer, the senior vice president for sales and marketing at SRS World Hotels of Frankfurt, which operates 300 hotels in Europe and recorded a 15 percent decline in occupancy in April, compared with the previous year. "It's easy to distinguish something as dramatic as SARS. But the strong euro has been a gradual trend."
 Still, it has begun rippling through Europe's tourism industry. Accor, the giant French hotel chain, said the euro had contributed to its poor financial results in the first quarter. Accor's occupancy rate of 60.3 percent in Europe in March was down 2.1 percent from the comparable period last year. Visit Britain, the British government tourist organization, said arrivals from North America dropped 19 percent in March compared to the same month last year, and were 30 percent lower than in March 2000.
 The British pound has risen less sharply against the dollar than the euro, which means the cost of a weekend in London has not gone up as much as one in Paris. Visit Britain attributed the decline in visitors to the war, not the stronger pound, and it said it still hoped for a recovery this summer.
 Because many Americans put off their travel plans when war broke out in Iraq, Mr. Eberhard said, the travel industry was anticipating last-minute bookings from people now ready to venture overseas. The Swiss have joined with the tourist associations of Austria, Germany and Italy -- 3 of the 12 euro nations -- to capitalize on this by jointly promoting summer tours of the Alps. 
 They will begin advertising the deals in June for vacations in July and August. For example, a nine-night Best of the Alps trip, offered by Far & Wide of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., (877) 868-7257, www.farandwide.com, goes to Lucerne, Villars, Innsbruck, Munich and Salzburg, for $1,999 a person, double occupancy, with 16 meals and air fare from New York or Boston. 
 The war, and the political rift it opened across the Atlantic, has not ebbed entirely as a concern for travelers. "We get asked by Americans: 'Are we going to be welcome in Europe? Is it safe to travel in Europe?"' Mr. Eberhard said.
 Tourism executives in the United States can draw comfort from one trend: the same currency swings that make Europe expensive for Americans are making the United States cheaper for Europeans.
 Europe's largest tour operator, TUI of Germany, said it normally derived just 2 percent of its sales from Europeans going to the United States. Spain, where tens of millions of Europeans flock every summer, generates 40 percent of its revenue.
 But TUI's sales of tours to the United States from Germany are up 30 percent through April, compared with the same period last year, while its overall bookings are down 15 percent. 
 A company spokesman, Robin Zimmermann, said of the United States, "Food, drinks and other side costs are much more affordable now because of the strong euro."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/770 and 778 Park Avenue, at 73rd Street; 
Fraternal-Twin Examples of East Side Superluxury

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE construction scaffolding around 778 Park Avenue these days distinguishes it from its fraternal twin across 73rd Street, 770 Park. Both superluxury buildings were designed by Rosario Candela, whom many consider the quintessential 1920's apartment house architect.
 The buildings, completed just as the 1920's construction boom was coming to an end, have neo-Georgian tops that seem to symbolize Park Avenue sophistication, even if the structures themselves did not satisfy one major critic. 
 In May 1929, only two days apart, two developers filed plans for completely separate buildings with designs by Candela on the western corners of 73rd and Park. The plan filed by Edgar A. Levy was for a 19-story building, soon to be known as 770 Park, which would consist of duplexes with varied layouts. 
The building to be developed by Charles Newmark, which was initially called 780 Park but was later changed to No. 778, was for an 18-story building of full-floor apartments. The cost was estimated at $5 million apiece, a high number in what was the high tide of Park Avenue luxury development.
No. 770, finished in September 1930, had 35 duplex apartments of from 7 to 15 rooms. They were displayed in advertisements declaring that "the town houses of 1930 have plenty of sunshine." Floor-to-ceiling windows in many of the rooms used for entertaining guests led to step-out balconies and offered a country-house quality. 
The typical duplex had a 16-by-24-foot dining room, a 20-by-30-foot living room and an 8-by-25-foot gallery. An article in The Real Estate Record and Guide noted an elegant touch: in place of the standard crisscross wire-reinforced glass, Candela specified polished plate glass with vertical wires every two inches. The garbage room had steam to clean out the residents' garbage buckets.
There were three entrances: one in front, for the residents; one in the basement, for deliverymen; and one at street level on the side of the building, for servants -- to "obviate the trouble that invariably arises when servants are compelled to go downstairs to the basement and use the delivery entrance," the Record and Guide noted.
At Newmark's building, the distinctive note was the size of the rooms permitted by the one-apartment-to-a-floor layout. One 16-room apartment had an 11-by-36-foot gallery, 6 bedrooms, 9 baths, 23 closets and a 32-by-21-foot living room. 
The buildings were competing against other luxury accommodations, including 1 Beekman Place, at East 49th Street; 10 Gracie Square, at East 84th Street; 895 Park Avenue, at 79th Street; and the San Remo, at Central Park West and 74th Street. But they were also in a race against time. The chill of the stock market crash of October 1929 would become a deep freeze by the end of 1930. 
No. 770 seems to have made it. It had some initial troubles, but it was quickly reorganized and gained a solid footing. But even though there were some co-op sales at Newmark's building in mid-1929, construction stopped in the summer of 1930.
The exterior had been finished, but when Newmark lost the building in early 1931, an account in The New York Times said that "the interior has never been completed." A new group of owners apparently completed the building and changed the address to No. 778 at this time; The Times noted that the prices had been reduced to between $68,000 and $144,000. It is not clear what the original prices were at either building.
The Times quoted an unidentified broker as saying optimistically that "the slate has been wiped clean, excess values have been eliminated, and there are not more than 7 or 8 percent of vacancies." But by December 1931, 778 Park Avenue had only four families.
Although Nos. 770 and 778 are now considered to be among the finest of Candela's works, the critic George Chappell, writing as "T-Square" in his "Skyline" column in The New Yorker, was not impressed. He considered the staggered, irregular window pattern on No. 770"as confusing and disturbing an arrangement of windows as one will find in a long day's walk."
"Between the changing openings and constantly changing wall spaces," he wrote, "there appears to be no system whatever in the design." 
Chappell said that at No. 778 there was "more repose in arrangement, less in detail," and concluded that "there is a distressing amount of half-baked architecture in New York, an architecture which seems to proclaim loudly a lack of the training necessary for fine work." 
The two buildings are different in many ways. No. 770 is more modernistic, with plain walls; No. 778 uses extensive quoining -- in which stone blocks are brought out at the corners -- and much more elaborate detailing. Even their rooftop towers are different: No. 770's is trim and smooth, No. 778's more robust, like a garden temple. But despite the differences, they share a basic form -- red brick with light-colored masonry detailing, with a rising tower -- and they seem far more kindred than other buildings of their type. Their coincidental placement across from each other emphasizes their similarities.
Early residents were a cross-section of the target market for such buildings. Cecil P. Stewart, a yachtsman and insurance company executive, had the 18th-and-19th-floor duplex apartment at No. 770 -- an apartment that included a solarium and a handball court. In 1934, another resident of No. 770, the theatrical producer Rowland Stebbins, invited a tenor at the Metropolitan Opera, Edward Johnson, to sing an aria from "Lohengrin" to a mix of guests that included Harold I. Pratt, son of a founder of Standard Oil; the publisher Ralph Pulitzer; and the conductor Walter Damrosch.
Tenants at No. 778 in those years included Thomas J. Watson, then president of International Business Machines, and Byron C. Foy, president of Chrysler's DeSoto division. 
In 1933, the socialite Veronica Balfe, who had a brief acting career under the name Sandra Shaw, was married at her home at No. 778 to avoid large crowds; her new husband was Gary Cooper. 
THE original plans to make Nos. 770 and 778 entirely co-op buildings fell through. Although some apartments were owned as co-ops, many 1930's ads offered apartments for lease. A 1935 ad for a 10-room apartment with six terraces at No. 778 said it was available at "at a really attractive rental," but did not specify the rent. 
By the late 1930's and the 1940's architectural changes were ratifying the economic ones -- the Cecil Stewart duplex was split into two apartments in 1944.
Andrew Alpern, who chronicles both buildings in his book "The New York Apartment Houses of Rosario Candela and James Carpenter" (Acanthus Press, 2002) said that in the 1931 foreclosure, No. 778 was sold for $2.1 million. These days, he said, apartments in the two buildings -- which are now all co-ops -- usually cost $5 million or more. One duplex apartment in No. 770 sold in 2001 for $10.5 million.
The construction scaffolding that now rings the limestone base of No. 778 is for standard exterior maintenance, according to Toni Hanson, a managing director at the managing agent, Insignia Residential Group.
Richard Lefever, president of Facade Maintenance Design, who is supervising the project, said that there are peculiarities in the building's setback design that create difficulties. Because of the irregular column layout on the upper floors, he said, there are "a lot of eccentric stresses that cause movement" and create cracks. 
Ms. Hanson said that the co-op board was considering cleaning the facade. Whether or not the facade is cleaned, the similarities these fraternal twins share will no doubt endure.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The building at 778 Park Avenue, above left, in 1945, and 770 Park Avenue in 1943. Many consider their architect, Rosario Candela, the quintessential 1920's apartment house designer. Both have neo-Georgian tops. (Photographs courtesy of Office for Metropolitan History)

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-8-03: WHAT THEY WERE THINKING; 
One Up, One Down

BYLINE:  By Abby Ellin 

 BODY:
 Eileen McGill and Ross Meyerson, Brooklyn
Meyerson (right): "Right after 9/11, I was forced to close my event marketing and entertainment business that had been very profitable for six years. For the past year, I have been trying to re-energize the same type of business under a new name. My wife's salary has been the sole means of support. We've been out to eat twice in the last year. We have no social life. Meanwhile my wife's career thrives. She is the head concierge at the Benjamin Hotel. She has been on national news shows. Still, she would rather not work at this point. Our daughter's about to go to kindergarten, and my wife's starting to feel she's missing her entire childhood."

McGill: "It takes two incomes to be a successful family here in New York. Even if one person is doing well in their career, you're still worried about your spouse and trying to pick up the slack at home so they can do what they do. One week, my job was really demanding, and it was like, who's more important -- the person who's trying to get something going or me who has a paying job? Ross ends up networking late, so he doesn't get home until 10 p.m., when I'm exhausted. I feel like I'm going to wake up and be 50. We thought about leaving town. We both want him to be able to support us. I could get a job anywhere, but it's more important that Ross get a job."

Howard Zimmerman and Charley Burch, Memphis
Zimmerman (left): "I started the first Web development company in Memphis in 1994. Early on, Charley worked for me. I sold it in 1998 to USWeb and was a paper dot-com millionaire. I was married, with a wife, kid, nice house, imported cars. The parent company went Chapter 11, and here I am in a divorce that Jerry Springer would get squeamish over. Three years ago I made about seven times what I made last year. I work for a global logistics company. I got Charley interested in the industry; he really got fired up. Now he's poised to do certain things, and I'm hoping to work for him."

Burch: "We have been really close friends since I was 11. The only thing that ever annoyed me was Howard's arrogance in regards to his ambition. He hired me to be a sales manager for Quest Interactive Media. The way I remember it, he left all of us behind because he got a $4 million offer from USWeb to buy only him out. He lost everything in the stock market a few years ago. How the tables turn. Howard still owes me $2,800 in back salary from 1995. What can I say? You have to stick by your friends even if they moan, bore you or owe you something."

T. J. Kniveton and Chad Norwood, San Francisco
Norwood (right): "It is very tough right now for programmers in the Bay Area. I have been unemployed since last September. T. J. and I met about three or four years ago. I worked at Intel and then joined a start-up. Then our company got into legal trouble, and the stock became worthless. All my paper went down the toilet. Before, I'd just buy clothes, drinks, go on weekend trips to L.A., snowboarding. Now I have about $20,000 in credit-card debt. I'm not too worried -- the A.P.R.'s average under 6 percent. What is it like watching T. J. do well? I am quite happy for him. I'm 31. He's 27. When I was T. J.'s age, I was doing just as well."

Kniveton: "It used to be when one of my friends would get laid off, everyone would network for that person. As more and more people got laid off, the support system crumbled, and it ended up like a war zone with lots of casualties in my personal circle. I work for Nokia as a senior research engineer. I own my loft. I've gotten bonuses of about 20 percent the past two years. I feel a little guilty because there's no reason that I should have a job and they don't. Sometimes I feel survivor's guilt."

Tom Currier and Luke Kaven, New York
Currier (left): "I'm a real-estate developer. I didn't think I would have a good year, but I've just finished construction on my fourth building. Since Luke has no place to stay when he is in New York, I'm letting him use the one remaining unit: a four-bedroom, three-bathroom duplex penthouse listed at $2.425 million. Luke and I hadn't heard from each other since we were kids. About five years ago, I tracked him down; it turned out he had a deep interest in jazz, and I always played in bands. The kind of capital that's required to do what he wants to do is a lot less than it takes to make a new building. So I'm trying to help him."

Kaven: "I started Smalls Records as a way to give voice to underrecognized and older artists. If not for favors from friends and family, I wouldn't have gotten by. Both Tom and his wife, Marcy, are very successful. By contrast, I don't see to my own practical needs enough. I seem to persist in the belief that if I give without regard for what I get in return, I will receive a just reward out of that. But while there have been abundant spiritual rewards, the financial rewards have sometimes not been sufficient."

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-8-03: CRASH COURSE; 
Prospect Theory

BYLINE:  By Dirk Olin; Dirk Olin is national editor at The American Lawyer.

 BODY:
 From the infamous Dutch tulip hysteria of the 17th century to the Great Depression to the dot-com crash, wild bouts of speculation have occasionally inflated big fat financial bubbles that soaked investors when they burst. Daniel Kahneman, a professor at Princeton who was the first psychologist to win the Nobel in economics (which he was awarded last year for studies he conducted with Amos Tversky), has attributed market manias partly to investors' "illusion of control." Kahneman recently explained the basic weirdness of the dot-com bomb to The Financial Times: "A high percentage of investors knew it was a bubble and still invested because they thought they could get out in time." Why did so few heed the alarms? According to Kahneman's "prospect theory," most of us find losses roughly twice as painful as we find gains pleasurable. This radical precept subverts much of "utility theory," the longstanding economic doctrine that says we weigh gain and loss rationally. When combined with the reality that some market winners display the same recklessness as some victorious gamblers -- a phenomenon that Richard Thaler, an economist at the University of Chicago, calls "the house-money effect" -- the market is often revealed to be downright loony. Indeed, the findings of "behavioral finance" in recent years have increasingly challenged the fundamental rationality assumed by defenders of "efficient markets," those who believe Eugene Fama's famous dictum that prices "fully reflect available information." Fama, another economist from the University of Chicago, is saying that you can't get ahead of the market by building a clever model, because you can't predict the news that will affect prices. (As for the crazy players, Fama has contended that big-time rational arbitrageurs counterbalance them.) So, as stocks have shown some new life this spring, can you put your trust back in the market?

Thumbnail Economics
A fairly straight line of standard economic theory runs from the late 1700's to the 20th century. First came the "invisible hand" that Adam Smith said guided decision-making according to basic market logic. This was refined in the early 19th century by Jeremy Bentham into a philosophy of utilitarianism that assumed, among other things, that consumers knew what was best for themselves. John Maynard Keynes challenged some of that doctrine's underpinnings during the 1930's, when he compared market participants to viewers trying to guess the outcome of a beauty contest. Milton Friedman subsequently helped rescue rationalism during the post-World War II period, arguing that most market participants behave as if they had made rational calculations, even if they were not consciously making those calculations. In 1979, however, Kahneman and Tversky published a paper that included results from subjects who answered two comparative money problems. And their responses appeared to reveal systematic deviations from rationality: In problem No. 1, subjects were given an imaginary $1,000 and asked to choose between (a) a 50 percent chance to gain $1,000 and a 50 percent chance to gain nothing and (b) a sure gain of $500. In problem No. 2, subjects got $2,000 and were asked to choose between (a) a 50 percent chance to lose $1,000 and a 50 percent chance to lose nothing and (b) a sure loss of $500. The results? In the first problem 84 percent chose (b). In the second, 69 percent chose (a). What's odd here is that if the majority opt for the $1,500 of (b) in problem No. 1, the majority therefore ought to take the same $1,500 payout in answer (b) in the second problem. But instead the majority is willing to take the risk to try to "break even" when the problem is framed in terms of losses. Irrationally, people feel differently about losing than they do about gaining, even if either choice produces the same outcome.

Hedging the Theories, or Practical Advice
The Princeton economist Burton Malkiel, whose investing classic, "A Random Walk Down Wall Street," has just come out in its eighth edition, mostly touts efficient markets. Like Fama, he says he believes that prices tend to go up over time but without any discernible pattern that can be used to predict future movements. Unlike Fama, however, Malkiel concedes that bursts of market irrationality do occur, which is why he calls himself "a random walker with a crutch." "There are lots of good lessons to be taken from behavioral finance," Malkiel says. "But what it doesn't do is provide any kind of clear road map for cool sharp-penciled professionals to beat the market. For example, the existence and extent of bubbles are only discernible in retrospect."
Interestingly, irrational- and rational-market experts provide much the same advice for investors: buy into index funds that are pegged to broad swaths of the market rather than trying to play selected sectors. Then hold. You might expect that advice from the efficiency mavens, but how do the behaviorists -- who say you should be able to exploit the crazy market players -- square that conservative circle? "While behaviorists think that it is theoretically possible to beat the market," Richard Thaler says, "individual investors do not have the time or training to do that on their own, and finding superior skills among active mutual-fund managers is not easy, either. So a reasonable strategy to adopt is to settle for the average returns and low fees offered by index funds."
An existentialist corollary for your consideration. More than a few philosophers have sermonized that behaving as if an afterlife exists is beneficial to society in the here and now, even if the belief turns out to be unfounded. Now listen to Malkiel: "To the extent that the behaviorists are right, few if any could take those insights and beat the market. In other words, you ought to act as if the markets are efficient." 

Of Higher Interest
* Kahneman, D., and Tversky, A. "Prospect Theory: An Analysis of Decision Under Risk," Econometrica, Vol. 47, pp. 263-292 (1979).
* Malkiel, B.G. "A Random Walk Down Wall Street."
* Fama, E.F. "Market Efficiency, Long-Term Returns and Behavioral Finance," Journal of Financial Economics, Vol. 49, pp. 283-306 (1998).
* For less empirical market studies, on film, see also Oliver Stone's "Wall Street" and John Landis's "Trading Places."

Volatility vs. Craziness
From "The New Financial Order: Risk in the 21st Century," by Robert J. Shiller, Princeton University Press, 2003

"Despite the volatility we observe in speculative markets, no one should conclude from any of my or others' research on financial markets that these markets are totally crazy. I have stressed only that the aggregate stock market in the United States in the last century has been driven primarily by psychology and fads, that it has shown massive excess volatility. But many markets for subindexes relative to the market do not show evidence of excessive volatility, and the market for individual stocks shows substantial evidence supporting the notion that prices in these markets do carry genuine information about future fundamentals. A second problem is that financial innovation sometimes encourages secret dealings, deception and even fraud. . . . But this should not be viewed as evidence against impressive progress in the field of finance."

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-8-03: ON LANGUAGE; 
Money Talks

BYLINE:  By William Safire 

 BODY:
'I have never seen the color of Mr. Baskett's money," the Scottish political pamphleteer Thomas Gordon wrote in his 1718 "Cordial for Low Spirits." The color sought was gold, or at least good silver, called white money, as against metal of baser quality, easily tarnished, called black money (which may be the source of blackmail).
 Then came the Civil War in the United States, with its shortage of metal for coins and distrust of currency issued by local banks. Lincoln's treasury secretary, Salmon P. Chase, took a chance on issuing "Legal Tender Notes" with green designs on their backs that turned out to be an ingenious way for the government to borrow from the people without paying interest. Not everyone liked the paper: "The merchant offers greenbacks," The Cincinnati Gazette reported Gen. Lew Wallace's telling an audience early in August 1862, "and Mr. Planter says, 'No, Sir, they ain't good here: I must have gold.' " But the convenient, easy-to-carry greenbacks caught on, leading to the formation of the short-lived Greenback Party a generation later. 
 The long green, originally a Pennsylvania term for cheap whiskey, was soon applied to these green-backed notes of large denomination. "There did be long green shtickin' out iv vest pockets," Finley Peter Dunne wrote in his "Mr. Dooley" series in 1893, "an' men'd drink nawthin' but champagny."
This just in, the news peg for this financial etymology: "The venerable greenback is no longer going to appear all green," The Associated Press reports. (To be precise, it's only the back that's all green.) To confound counterfeiters in this age of digital imagery, Treasury's Bureau of Engraving and Printing is rolling out a multicolored version of the $20 bill, our most criminally copied item.
The freshened-up Andy will be peachy-keen, with subtle blue and green shadings and highlighted with dozens of little yellow dots whispering"20," all making it as hard to replicate as a sophisticated teenager's hairdo. Only two out of every 10,000 bills with Andrew Jackson's face are counterfeit, but it adds up. Higher-denomination bills will be further colorized in coming years, but there are no plans to complicate the buck or the fin; no self-respecting counterfeiter wastes his time on a $1 or a $5 bill. Thanks to that, the word greenback will maintain its currency in the American language.

MOOLAH
Investigating the "high-stakes slot room" of the Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas, the columnist Eugene Kane of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel noted, "We're talking serious moola here."
This is a slang term for money. Mario Pei, the language-in-action philologist of years ago, was sure "it was Chuck Green, a friend of Damon Runyon, who invented moolah." The columnist Runyon, whose grasp of Broadway lingo was immortalized in the musical "Guys and Dolls," wrote in 1939, "He is very desperate for a little moolah."
The origin is a mystery. The current spelling with an h, moolah, is shown by a database count to be preferred over the variant moola, which suggests that in pronunciation, the first syllable has no greater stress than the second. The word breaks into moo-lah. Speculation, especially welcome with citations, will be entertained at onlanguage@nytimes.com.

DEFLATION
On Dec. 19, 2002, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, told the Economic Club of New York, "The United States is nowhere close to sliding into a pernicious deflation." In February, in the question-and-answer portion of his semiannual testimony to Congress, he repeated the sentiment, "Indeed, our general presumption is that we seek stable prices, and stable prices mean no inflation or deflation." On April 30, again reporting to Congress, he used a less scary term, "With price inflation already at a low level, substantial further disinflation would be an unwelcome development." Ten days later, a statement from the board on the interest rate used a different formulation, "the probability of an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation, though minor."
On May 21 he returned to the key word without the modifier pernicious: "We at the Federal Reserve recognize that deflation is a possibility," he told members of Congress. "Even though we perceive the risks as minor, the potential consequences are very substantial and could be quite negative." When Senator Robert Bennett, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, recalled his previous use of the word deflation, the Fed chairman asked, "Did I use the word deflation?" Bennett replied, "You kind of danced around it, but that's the way it came across." Greenspan smiled. "It was my interpreter." 
Deflation is a rise in the value of money as prices of goods and services fall (that's good for most people, especially savers and those on fixed incomes) but a drop in wages and credit and an increase in unemployment (bad for workers, lenders and investors). While disinflation is a slowing of the rise in prices, deflation is the actual fall in prices. It last happened in the United States during the 1930's, not a happy time, and is thus regarded with some dread.
The earliest use of the word in the Times archive was by Edmund D. Fisher, a deputy controller of New York City in 1913, discussing "the volume of inflation and deflation in our alternate periods of business activity and depression." No politician today likes to use that last word lightly. If we should move from unwelcome disinflation to pernicious deflation, the hopeful term to keep an eye out for is invigorating reflation.

YARD INFLATION
How long is a yard? Literalists will say 36 inches, nearly a meter. Ale drinkers define it as a long, slender glass of their favorite beverage, holding about two pints.
In business slang, a yard started out as a $100 bill: one hundred dollars is a century or a yard, The American Mercury observed in 1926. Then came the good times for the C-note, followed by the crash, and American Speech in 1932 defined yard as a G or a grand: $1,000.
Fast-forward to this millennium. (I use the verb fast-forward as a useful antonym for the movie term flashback, but with the takeover of videotape by DVD, fast-forward will be fast junked. Maybe we'll reach back to skip ahead.) According to Paul Maidment, executive editor of Forbes -- who watches the foreign-exchange markets and their inside lingo -- "Yard is now for-ex slang for a billion," since 1 billion Japanese yen equals approximately 10 million U.S. dollars. It's clearer to say "I'm a buyer of a yard of yen" than to say "I'm a buyer of a billion yen," which could easily be misheard as "I'm a buyer of a million yen."
From a hundred bucks to a billion yen -- is the yard due for a semantic crash?

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-8-03: QUESTIONS FOR DANA GIACCHETTO; 
Money Man No More

BYLINE:  By Emily White 

 BODY:
Q: In the 90's you were the financial adviser to many famous actors and artists, and in 2000 you pleaded guilty to fraud and wound up spending nearly three years in prison. Did your fellow inmates ever ask you for financial advice?
 Constantly. My advice was to take it slow and easy. I would tell the inmates: "Listen, there is no economic Holy Grail. Money is always difficult, it will always be difficult." I would say, "Look around -- money doesn't solve all your problems." 
 Do you feel as if money was your destiny and now you have to reinvent yourself?
I don't think to work with money was my destiny. I think to help people was my destiny. 
Do you miss working with money?
I do miss working with money, but part of my restriction now is I'm banned from being a registered investment adviser for life. Although I still have my own thoughts about the market. This is what I see happening: I think we'll test 7,500 on the bottom before we reach the heights of 25,000. I don't know if you'll believe this or if anyone else will -- but I think the Dow will go to 25,000 before July 4, 2005. Remember I always used to say 10,000 before 2000? That prediction was true.
So you remain an optimist.
The market will see new heights, but I think the kind of companies that are going to succeed are companies that are not built on artifice but are built on selling real products. In fact, what I am thinking of doing with my fiancee is starting a large food company. Really high quality foods at low prices, and get artists and designers to design the packaging. It will be called Taste. What Taste will represent is the finest food packaged in high design. That is my next world-conquering idea. I am getting back to the point where I'm going to be producing a tangible product. No more intangibles. A real product you can eat instead of something abstract like money. You can laugh at it now, but when you see every single shelf in America with Taste on it, you will realize that Giacchetto is back.
Do you think being part of the celebrity world had something to do with your downfall?
I don't know if they're causally linked. Obviously, at times I had what I would call a solipsistic worldview, and that gets heightened in these kind of egocentric environments. And I think that helped for -- you know, I lost my moral compass for a while.
What has happened to your ego since?
Certainly I've been humbled by the jail experience. I am not in denial about the kind of damage that was associated with me, and I want to correct that. I am working full time, reconnecting with lots of my old clients, trying to make sure that people are aware I want to heal as many wounds as I can. Or at least palliate the wounds.
Which old clients have you been contacting? Everyone was fascinated by your close friendship with Leonardo DiCaprio.
Friendship has always been very important to me, and as far as I'm concerned, true friendships require loyalty and absolute discretion. Given that, there's no way I'll mention names. I can tell you that I'll try to contact every single one of my old clients and friends to apologize for my transgressions. 
Do you feel bad for the people who lost money with you?
I feel terrible about what happened. But I think the people that know me know my true intentions were good. Over time I think that will show. I was painted with this brush as a con man and manipulator, and nobody looked at the charges. I only pleaded guilty to one charge of financial fraud. I did not plead guilty to ripping off movie stars. I am not a scammer and I have never been. I think within the wreckage there is still the soul of me. 
I have a good character, and it will resurface. Emily White

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Planning for Further Business Revival in Hoboken

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, as an apartment-building boom was getting under way here, the city's leaders were moved to take a new look at Hoboken's shabby waterfront and saw some classy office space waiting to happen. After years of planning and work to set up a 50-acre redevelopment area, after selection of SJP Properties -- in 1996 -- to build two office buildings right next to the Hudson River, after major tenants were lured from Manhattan for the twin 14-story towers SJP completed last month, it is finally happening.
 And now, the second act is supposed to begin: another office tower and a 250-room hotel are planned for another parcel of land with river frontage, situated immediately north of the SJP buildings. The developers for those projects were officially named at a ceremony held on May 27 in Pier A Park, built by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on a five-acre pier in 1999, part of the first redevelopment work. At the ceremony, SJP was named to build the third tower, and the Applied Companies of Hoboken was designated to build the hotel. 
 But first: more waiting. 
"We've been involved in this since the first opportunity," said SJP's chairman and chief executive, Steven J. Pozycki, whose firm is based in Parsippany, "and we are raring to go with the next building. Given this economy, however, we can't go yet."
Mr. Pozycki had smiled through the ceremony on a rare sunny afternoon and through a subsequent tour of the well-appointed building that Marsh & McLennan, the Manhattan financial firm, will begin moving into next month. But his mien shifted to sober as he discussed prospects for the next phase of the project called Waterfront Corporate Center.
SJP will not break ground on the next building without a committed tenant, he said, adding, "Right now, tenants are hard to come by."
Michael Barry, the principal of the Applied Companies, also beamed during the ceremony in the park, particularly when United States Representative Robert Menendez, who resides in Hoboken, spoke about how the city "deserves a hotel at this time, as the incredible jewel that is Hoboken gets unlocked," and Mayor David Roberts told of how he yearns for a place in his hometown big enough to hold a graduation party, or a wedding reception, for his daughter -- who is currently only 15.
Afterward, however, Mr. Barry said: "It's a fantastic site, an exceptional development site, and right now we are waiting along with everyone else for the hotel industry to come back. It has pretty much been out to lunch since 9/11."
The Hyatt Regency Hotel, built by Mack-Cali last year on Jersey City's waterfront as part of its Harborside Financial Center, is having some occupancy problems because of the economy, Mack-Cali's chief executive, Mitchell E. Hersh, conceded recently -- but he said that was in line with the regional and national picture.
At least the hotel industry is likely to respond quickly to an economic upturn when it comes, Mr. Barry said. "Unlike some sectors, it might take months -- not years -- once the economy starts to heal," he said. "More than other types of real estate, hotels are closely related to how the economy is doing at this very moment. We're not talking about 10-year leases after all. We're talking about getting reservations every night."
The health of Hoboken's market is directly tied to that of Manhattan, to be sure. Hoboken is just a short ferry ride away from Midtown, and the remaking of its waterfront was intended to draw businesses to "a fantastic environment without Manhattan rents," as Mayor Roberts put it.
The average annual commercial rent over all for Hoboken is $36 per square foot, according to Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company. SJP will not comment on rental rates at Waterfront Corporate Center, although the new space would certainly command the highest rates in this city, which offers very few large office spaces, and many smaller ones along its main artery, Washington Street, two blocks inland from the river.
In April, the vacancy rate for commercial space in Hoboken was 11.4 percent, Insignia/ESG reported.
Meanwhile, in Midtown Manhattan, where the average asking rent was $51 per square foot in April, according to Insignia/ESG, rental rates continued to fall, having declined 8 percent in the past year and 17 percent over the past 24 months. The vacancy rate was 12.1 percent.
On the other hand, Insignia's analysts noted a number of significant renewals and expansions among high-profile tenants in Manhattan, like Gannett, Bank of America and several law firms that have committed to remaining in Midtown. It reported, "Cautious optimism is returning to the Midtown office market." In addition, Pfizer, the pharmaceutical company, recently announced that it intended to add more than 4,000 employees in Midtown over the next 15 years -- 1,000 next year alone -- and that it would purchase a 31-story office building near its headquarters on East 42nd Street to house them.
In Midtown, while the amount of space returned to the market continues to outpace leasing activity, the total amount of square feet leased was 58 percent better in April than the year before and was 26 percent greater for the first four months of 2003 than for the same period in 2002. "The fact is we got the last big tenant that left New York for New Jersey's waterfront," said Mr. Pozycki, referring to Marsh & McLennan's impending move to 450,000 square feet in Hoboken. "Now, we just have to see what the market forces will conjure up next."
Hoboken was instantly revitalized last July, Mayor Roberts said, when the publisher John Wiley & Sons moved 950 employees into the first building completed at Waterfront Corporate Center. "We got street life -- in the daytime!" the mayor said. "The existing shops and restaurants already are seeing so much more traffic. The people from New York are seeing what a comfortable place this is to work and live."
The mayor said Wiley was already "part of the family" in Hoboken, with many employees involved in community work and the social life of the city. William Arlington, the head human resources officer for Wiley, which was based on the other side of the river for almost two centuries, said employees were thrilled with the building, which provides spacious conference rooms, a cafeteria and a stunning skyline view of Manhattan.
"The move has really been very pleasant for most of us in many many ways," said Mr. Arlington. In the three years since the decision was made to leave New York City, he said, only 10 departing employees have listed the move to Hoboken as the reason for their action.
Hoboken's public officials are committed to keeping the city's basic character intact, even as they are pleased to have the scruffy old ship-and-railyard neighborhood on the waterfront gone forever.
When negotiating with the Port Authority, which is a formal partner in Hoboken's redevelopment, city officers pressed hard to win reduction of the proposed "massing" of the buildings, making them taller rather than wider at the base, so as to retain more space for the park and open areas, and to keep the compact feel of the downtown area.
"Preserving the street grid, the fabric, without creating enclaves, is near and dear to Hoboken's heart," said Applied's Mr. Barry. "Hoboken is a wonderful walking town, with lots of shops, bakeries and restaurants. You can get from any two points without a car."
Mr. Menendez said that Hoboken was gaining a reputation for making a comeback without erasing its past. "I travel around the country quite a bit," the congressman said, "and when I mention Hoboken, people from the West Coast, the South and across, they know it as the birthplace of Frank Sinatra and baseball, but also as a place where a lot of people have brought a city back to life."

Pozycki, chief executive of SJP Properties, which has put up two office towers in the Waterfront Corporate Center in Hoboken, standing on the site where a third tower is to be built. The Applied Companies has been designated to build an adjacent 250-room hotel. (Timothy Ivy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In a Changed SoHo, Legal Pentimento 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
WHEN the city moved decades ago to upgrade SoHo and NoHo from decaying manufacturing areas and to legitimize the covert conversion of lofts there into working and living quarters for artists, one requirement was that prospective residents must be artists and certified as such by a specially appointed board.
 Now that the area has been transformed into one of the city's most sophisticated and costly neighborhoods, many artists have long since migrated to less expensive surroundings. But the regulation, written into the zoning code, and a vestigial remnant of the board -- whose membership is kept secret -- remain. 
 While officials concede that the regulation is rarely enforced, its effects live on. There are still occasionally people who seek certification, as Anthony Gordon, a photographer did five years ago. "The building I was trying to live in, a co-op on Broadway in SoHo, required it and the board wouldn't entertain my package without it," he said. 
More commonly, prospective residents are asked to sign legal documents holding building managements blameless if it is proved they are living there illegally.
Commissioners of the three agencies that share responsibility for the regulation have begun conversations about its future.
"The law was created with the best intentions at a particular moment in the neighborhood's history," said Kate D. Levin, the commissioner of the Department of Cultural Affairs, which grants the artists' certifications. "We are aware that market forces and the reality of SoHo are not in sync with the provisions of the law. This agency has been in discussions with the Department of City Planning and the Department of Buildings to see how we can most effectively address the situation to protect the neighborhood, and we intend to talk to arts groups and the community board as well. "We intend to do the right thing," Commissioner Levin said, "and if doing the right thing shifts, then it is government's responsibility to shift."
In 1971, the city began to acknowledge that hundreds of artists were living covertly in lofts constructed for manufacturing purposes and began granting, albeit on an informal basis, certifications legalizing the residency of artists in what are termed "joint live-work quarters." In 1986, it grandfathered everyone already in residence there, whether or not they were artists, and began codifying the approval process with a rigid set of standards applicable to subsequent tenants or buyers. 
In its heyday the Artists' Certification Committee, which reviewed applications, had as many as 20 members. Now it has shrunk to two, whose identities Ms. Levin said could not be divulged, but she noted that the number of applicants has declined. "Artists do continue to be certified, but only a trickle cross my desk," she said. 
According to department data, which is sketchy, of some 30 applicants last year, 24 received the certificates. All told, an estimated 2,500 to 3,000 individuals have been approved over the years. 
Once an artist moves into a SoHo or NoHo loft -- rental, condo or co-op -- in the districts designated as M1-5A and M1-5B zones, the responsibility for ensuring that the unit remains in the hands of artists falls to the Department of Buildings, which requires only that a member of the household be deemed an artist, not necessarily the lease holder or buyer. 
But the passage of time and the inevitable turnover in residents has made the regulation "virtually unenforceable," according to Ilyse Fink, a spokeswoman for the Department of Buildings.
"There is no requirement that we be notified when people move out," she said. "Someone would have to make a complaint in order for us to investigate, and then that means gaining access to the building and asking people if they are artists." 
Furthermore, she pointed out, given the city's current economic problems, enforcement is hardly on the front burner. 
"In the pantheon of things we must investigate, this is a quality of life issue, but it would never have the same priority as a building with construction or safety problems," she said. "As with many other city agencies, we have a limit to our resources. We won't evict someone for this because it is not a safety issue."
In fact, no one seems to know how many buildings or units remain in either full or partial compliance. The last known survey conducted in SoHo was completed in 1996 and one currently under way in NoHo is far from conclusion. 
Nor does anyone seem to know how many complaints about nonartists living in lofts reserved for artists have been lodged with the Buildings Department. "It is not an individual complaint category," Ms. Fink said. "Where it gets filed would depend on how the caller had articulated it and how the call manager had classified it."
No one disputes that droves of affluent nonartists -- including lawyers, physicians, investment bankers, stockbrokers and, until recently, dot-com executives -- have swamped the community in the last two decades, paying rents or purchase prices that would have stunned their predecessors.
"We have a large population living technically in violation of the statute," said Margaret D. Baisley, a real estate lawyer who said she "deals with this issue on virtually a daily basis."
While many landlords and building boards no longer demand that a member of the household be a certified artist, she said, they still require new arrivals to sign letters absolving buildings of responsibility if the residency is found to be improper. "In my opinion," she said, "there are virtually no buildings in SoHo that require certification and it has become almost universal in transactions to ask for a waiver letter."
"I find it problematic determining who is an artist, and defining art as that which is fine art only and not commercial," she went on. In addition, she said, "There is also a requirement that you have five years of demonstrated commitment to your genre of fine art. I have had very gifted artists as clients who, because they were in their early 20's, were denied on that basis." 
AS spelled out in the code, those deemed to be in the "creative" arts -- including painters, sculptors, choreographers, composers and, inexplicably, poets -- are eligible, but those in "interpretive" arts, such as musicians who play other people's compositions, actors and dancers, are not. 
To get around the barriers to commercial artists, Ms. Baisley said: "We sanitize applications to get anything remotely commercial out. I have had rock musicians reduce their work to sheet music and present themselves as songwriters."
Although he is engaged in artistic photography as well as commercial, Anthony Gordon was turned down when he first applied for certification. 
He decided to appeal, with the help of an article about him in a weekly German magazine. "Conveniently, I had once been interviewed by Stern magazine, which compared me to Robert Mapplethorpe," he said. "That meant if he was an artist, so was I. So I got a copy of the article and had it translated." The strategy worked, and he was certified. 
Mr. Gordon's subsequent experience is illustrative not only of how the process works -- or, some would say, does not work -- but of the seismic changes that have catapulted SoHo out of the reach of all but the most successful artists. 
Five years ago, Mr. Gordon paid $625,000 for his 2,200-square-foot loft in a building that is part co-op, part condominium and part retail space. (There are no maintenance fees, he said, because retail rents cover all communal expenses.) 
"It has unobstructed views of the Empire State Building, all of Lower Manhattan and three bridges," he said. "It was just appraised for $2.2 million, and several weeks ago I had an offer of $3.5 million. I called the co-op board and said, 'Will we take a nonartist?' They said, 'Well, we have a law.' "
The question, however, is academic for Mr. Gordon. He has decided to stay put. "I have looked all over New York and see that I can't duplicate what I have for under $3 million or $4 million," he said. 
Ms. Baisley, who was Mr. Gordon's lawyer when he bought the loft, favors rezoning the entire area for residential and retail use instead of perpetuating its designation as a light manufacturing district. 
"Owners should be legally permitted to sell to whomever they wish and make a profit," she said. "Why should the artists who colonized this area at great danger and inconvenience when there was no sanitation, police or fire protection, no place to shop, be denied the benefit of what they did?" 
Susan Meisel, a painter, photographer and owner with her husband of the Louis K. Meisel Gallery on Prince Street, who is also a real estate broker, minced no words when asked about artists' certification program.
"It is like an old piece of gum," she said. "We ought to spit it out and get over it. There are better things to chew on."
Ms. Meisel was certified in 1973, but if something were to happen to her, she said, "My husband and child would be living here illegally. Does that mean that my husband would have to find an artist to move in?" 
She does not buy the argument that the certification process ought to be preserved to keep artists from fleeing SoHo and NoHo en masse, grabbing enormous profits as they go. 
"It's not as if every artist who ever moved into SoHo suddenly had to leave because their lofts were worth millions of dollars," she said. "There are still dozens of buildings with artists living and working there, and when they decide to sell, they will be happy that the lofts for which they paid $15,000 are now worth $1 million."
As for the contention that the soaring prices keep emerging artists out of SoHo and NoHo, she said, "There are still places for them to go and the same thing will happen there because it is artists who make neighborhoods interesting."
"This is the only neighborhood in the entire universe where you must be something specific to live there," she continued. "It seems to me that we should be fighting to say that it is unconstitutional to decide that neighborhood be limited to a certain kind of person." 
But there are still numerous people who believe that the area ought to be reserved for artists, both to reinforce it as a cultural magnet and to restore it as a source of space affordable to artists whose work does not command stratospheric prices. 
The SoHo Alliance and several individuals balked when it was announced in 1998 that Continuum Partners, a collaboration of the developers Bruce Eichner and Hank Sopher, intended to build two luxury residential buildings, on former parking lots on Houston Street at the northern fringe of SoHo, that would be marketed to nonartists.
They won a lawsuit filed in New York Supreme Court against the Board of Standards and Appeals, which had issued the necessary variance, but the decision was reversed by the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, paving the way for construction now under way.
One argument mounted against the new buildings -- now the subject of another lawsuit, which was filed in December -- was the lack of a provision that residents be artists. The point was moot: the artist-in-residence requirement applies only to conversions and not to new construction. 
Nevertheless, Sean Sweeney, director of the alliance and a member of the executive committee of Community Board 2, which covers SoHo and NoHo, said: "This will open the floodgates. It could be the death knell of SoHo as an artists' colony."
Marie Dormuth, an adjunct professor of art at the Parsons School of Design and a printmaker, has no reservations about the effectiveness of the certification process.
"It enabled and enhanced what was already going on here by laying down a system by which the art industry could be continued," she said. "It has been most important for the preservation of this special neighborhood. I feel confident that it should be continued."
City Councilman Alan Gerson, who represents the area, has taken up the cause. "The purpose of the program remains valid, although the administration is flawed," he said. "A good land use zoning plan could serve the purpose and replace artists' certification, but we shouldn't do away with it until we put something else in its place."
Mr. Gerson has remedies in mind. "First, we should do a thorough survey of what is there," he said. "I think we need to expand the definition of the arts to include not only traditional sculpture and fine painting but new media, architecture and design." 
"We also have the challenge of recreating the conditions that allowed new artists to come in and build up the community," he said. "There are several underdeveloped areas and vacant lots that are the site of proposed development. I believe that any new development should have an arts component, whether that means reserving a certain percentage for affordable housing for artists or creating new collective art space where they can work."
"We treat artists like nomads," he continued. "They build up a neighborhood, then become victims of their own success, and we force them to move on. That is no way to treat them in a society that truly values its arts sector."
There are also those who say it is too late to close the barn door for the artists' community in SoHo-NoHo.
"Young artists don't come here anymore," said Richard Kostelanetz, author of "SoHo: the Rise and Fall of an Artists' Colony," published last week by Routledge. Mr. Kostalanetz has lived in SoHo since 1974. "Now it's time for me to go," he said. "It's no longer an artistic community and there is no reason to be here." 
He has put his loft on the market for $1 million and is building a house in the Rockaways section of Queens, "next to the A train and 1,000 feet from the beach."

HEADLINE: Business; 
How Much For Tickets? You Need a Scorecard

BYLINE:  By JOHN MORELL 

 BODY:
AS a die-hard Cubs fan, Ira D. Finkelberg was willing to pay almost anything to buy a ticket to see his team take on the Yankees this weekend. So are many other baseball fans in Chicago, particularly in a season when the Cubs have been leading the Central division of the National League.
 For many baseball teams, there has always been a seller's market for tickets -- at least for some opponents, on certain days. Now baseball executives are acknowledging this phenomenon and embracing "variable pricing" -- the practice of changing ticket prices based on anticipated demand. Tickets to games against good teams or on weekends cost more, while those against lesser opponents or in the middle of the week can be sold at a lower price. 
 "For years we'd have meetings about our prices, and we'd look at all the other entertainment venues," said Frank Maloney, the director of ticket operations for the Chicago Cubs. "If you go to the movies at night you pay more than if you go during the day, and even restaurants have 'early bird' specials to drive traffic in. Why can't we do that?" 
The Cubs are trying to squeeze every bit of revenue they can from every fan. So are the other 29 Major League Baseball franchises, in part because average attendance at big-league ballparks has fallen the last decade, to 26,600 a game in 2002 from 31,000 in 1993. For teams in the biggest cities, the pain of declining attendance has been compounded by the adoption of a form of revenue sharing, which has put pressure on big-city teams to make up for what they must give to small-market competitors.
One particularly visible approach is to increase ticket revenue by charging more for games against certain marquee teams or for games on weekends. Mr. Finkelberg, for example, bought four tickets in a terrace box for today's game at Wrigley Field for $32 each last February, when they went on sale. That is more than 20 percent more than the same seats cost last weekend, when the Cubs played the Houston Astros -- even though the Astros are in the same division and likely to fight them for a playoff spot.
But Mr. Finkelberg, 45, of Antioch, Ill., is sanguine about the increase. "I'm seeing the teams I want to see play on a day that works for me," he said. "So I'm not bothered by a price increase at all."
This is the first time the two teams have played in Chicago since the 1938 World Series, which the Yankees won in four games. Ticket brokers, including one owned by the Cubs, are asking as much as $1,500 a seat to see the game.
In the past, when a baseball fan bought a seat in a particular section, the ticket had a set price during the season, whether the game was on a drizzly May weeknight against a last-place opponent or on a sunny Saturday in July against the division champions. That was just, well, baseball.
But now some baseball executives are beginning to think and act more the way theater producers or concert promoters do. Among the teams that have embraced some form of variable pricing are the Yankees and the Mets in New York; the Anaheim Angels, last season's World Series champions; the San Francisco Giants, the National League champions; the Atlanta Braves; and the St. Louis Cardinals.
"WE'RE an entertainment entity doing 81 dates over a six-month period," said Robert DiBiasio, vice president for public relations of the Cleveland Indians, referring to the number of regular-season home games. "Of course, there are going to be dates that sparkle more than others, so our goal was to figure out which ones they were and plan and price accordingly."
The team has lowered prices for large sections of its home, Jacobs Field, dropping the bleachers price to $12 from $19, for example. To help pay for those cuts, there is a $5 across-the-board premium for 10 so-called showcase games: opening day and series against the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Cincinnati Reds and the Yankees. Opening day was a sellout, generating $211,000 more revenue than on opening day in 2002.
Over all, however, attendance in Cleveland has dropped 34 percent over the first 25 dates versus 2002. The sharp drop in attendance would appear to offset any gain from variable pricing, but Mr. DiBiasio said the Indians could still make more with less. "If we maximize our showcase games, we'll realize over $1 million in additional ticket revenue" over the full season, he said.
Daniel A. Rascher, president of Sports-Economics, a sports consulting firm in Berkeley, Calif., said variable-price ticketing "has been around for years, but baseball is just getting around to it." He added: "It's basic economics. When you've got a product that has a big demand like a matchup between two rival teams, the ticket price should be higher. You have the potential of increasing ticket revenues by 20 percent to 30 percent."
The way business has been going the last few years, baseball is more than ready for those kinds of numbers. Attendance at major league games over all fell 6.3 percent last year and has continued to decline in 2003, by 4.6 percent through May compared with the same number of games last year. Team executives blame the war in Iraq, bad weather in the Midwest and Northeast and the weak economy.
Teams with variable pricing report that the increase in prices for premium games has not put off fans or cut into sales of food, beer and souvenirs. "Our premium games are sellouts," Mr. Maloney said. "We've always got the fans who go to one or two games a year, and they don't care about paying a few dollars more for a better game on a good day."
Not all fans are happy about the change. "It's gouging," said Gary R. Clark, an Indians fan from Parma Hills, Ohio. He usually attended a handful of games each season, he said, but he has stayed away from Jacobs Field in 2003. "They cut the prices on the seats you don't want, put a poor product on the field, then they jack up prices on games everybody wants to see," he said. "And they wonder why no one's going to games?"
The Colorado Rockies were the first to make the leap into variable pricing, five years ago. The Rockies started with a simple program that charged a few dollars more a seat for games at Coors Field on weekends or if the team was playing a major rival like the Dodgers or the Mets. It has evolved into a multitiered program that compounds the extra charges for the best games. For instance, a midweek game against the Giants might include a $3 "premium game" surcharge. For a Saturday game against the Yankees, Rockies fans pay $9 extra a ticket.
"Even though we've been doing this for a number of years, we're still trying to tweak it and improve the system," said Kevin Fenton, senior director of ticket operations for the Rockies. "It adds to our revenue stream and fans understand the economics of it. They understand why they're charged more for some games; it's accepted."
At Shea Stadium this season, the Mets have begun tiered pricing that is similar to that of the Rockies. "We break our games down into four categories based on the time of year, the day of the week and the opponent," said David Howard, the team's senior vice president for business and legal affairs. Mets games are categorized into gold, silver, bronze and value levels.
"An upper reserved seat, which was $12 last year, is now either $16, $14, $12 or $8, depending on the category it's in," Mr. Howard said. "It all makes perfect business sense. We're selling out the gold games because they're marquee events, and sales on the value games have gone extremely well because we've lowered the price on games where the demand isn't as high."
After the first 24 dates this year, overall attendance at Mets games was down 25 percent from the comparable period last year. 
Despite the relative success of the Yankees on the field this season, attendance at Yankee Stadium is also down slightly, by 4 percent. The Yankees offer a discount promotion this year in which fans can pay just $5 for upper-deck seats at eight games against low-drawing opponents.
Some teams, like the Braves and Giants, have chosen a simple program -- an extra $4 for weekend games -- regardless of the opponent. "We draw fans from all over Northern California on the weekends," said Thomas M. McDonald, senior vice president for marketing for the Giants. "It doesn't matter who we're playing; the fans just want to experience the game."
WHEN introducing a variable-price program, teams face a delicate issue: what to do about their most precious fans, season ticket holders. Should they also pay premium rates?
"We talked about this and ultimately decided to include the season ticket holders in the premium-seat increases," said Mr. Maloney of the Cubs. "We have a very strong season ticket base, and they account for a huge chunk of our revenue. Our season seat sales and renewals were strong this year, so that decision has been a good one."
The Mets also charged their season ticket holders for premium-game increases. "The way we look at it is that we didn't raise our season ticket price in 2002, and for 2003 these customers are paying about 4 percent more than last year," Mr. Howard said. "This makes the price increase 4 percent over two years, which is less than inflation in New York."
Other teams have taken the opposite approach. "By not charging them the premium, we're giving the season ticket holder extra value," said Mr. McDonald, of the Giants. "It's another reason for them to renew: they won't be paying a premium on weekends."
Mr. Rascher, the sports economist, says variable pricing is here to stay.
"Within five years, it will be commonplace in most pro sports," he said. "Franchises that don't do it will try to use that as a marketing scheme: 'We're the only team in the league that doesn't vary our prices.'
"But they're going to have to pick up that revenue some other way," he added. "There's just a lot of pressure to build up your revenues, even if your attendance is down."

SECTION: Section 10; Column 4; Job Market; Pg. 1
