HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
What Would Jesus Do? Sock It to Alabama's Corporate Landowners

BYLINE:  By ADAM COHEN 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala. 

 BODY:
If the religious right had called up Central Casting last year to fill the part of governor, it could hardly have done better than the teetotaling, Bible-quoting businessman from rural central Alabama who now heads up the state. As a Republican congressman, Bob Riley had a nearly perfect record of opposing any legislation supported by the liberal Americans for Democratic Action.
 But Governor Riley has stunned many of his conservative supporters, and enraged the state's powerful farm and timber lobbies, by pushing a tax reform plan through the Alabama Legislature that shifts a significant amount of the state's tax burden from the poor to wealthy individuals and corporations. And he has framed the issue in starkly moral terms, arguing that the current Alabama tax system violates biblical teachings because Christians are prohibited from oppressing the poor. 
 If Governor Riley's tax plan becomes law -- the voters still need to ratify it in September -- it will be a major victory for poor people, a rare thing in the current political climate. But win or lose, Alabama's tax-reform crusade is posing a pointed question to the Christian Coalition, Focus on the Family and other groups that seek to import Christian values into national policy: If Jesus were active in politics today, wouldn't he be lobbying for the poor?
Alabama's tax system has long been brutally weighted against the least fortunate. The state income tax kicks in for families that earn as little a $4,600, when even Mississippi starts at over $19,000. Alabama also relies heavily on its sales tax, which runs as high as 11 percent and applies even to groceries and infant formula. The upshot is wildly regressive: Alabamians with incomes under $13,000 pay 10.9 percent of their incomes in state and local taxes, while those who make over $229,000 pay just 4.1 percent.
A main reason Alabama's poor pay so much is that large timber companies and megafarms pay so little. The state allows big landowners to value their land using "current use" rules, which significantly lowball its worth. Individuals are allowed to fully deduct the federal income taxes they pay from their state taxes, something few states allow, a boon for those in the top brackets.
Governor Riley's plan, which would bring in $1.2 billion in desperately needed revenue, takes aim at these inequalities. It would raise the income threshold at which families of four start paying taxes to more than $17,000. It would scrap the federal income tax deduction and increase exemptions for dependent children. And it would sharply roll back the current-use exemption, a change that could cost companies like Weyerhaeuser and Boise Cascade, which own hundreds of thousands of acres, millions in taxes. Governor Riley says that money is too tight to lift the sales tax on groceries this time, but that he intends to work for that later.
Church and state are not as separate in Alabama as they are in most places. (The chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court was in federal court last week defending his decision to install a 2.5-ton rendering of the Ten Commandments in the state's main judicial building.) Alabamians are used to hearing their politicians make religious arguments, and Governor Riley thinks he can convince the voters that Christian theology calls for a fairer tax system. "I've spent a lot of time studying the New Testament, and it has three philosophies: love God, love each other, and take care of the least among you," he said. "I don't think anyone can justify putting an income tax on someone who makes $4,600 a year."
The state's progressive voters, including many in the sizable African-American community, have backed tax-law changes like these for years. And reform-minded business leaders, who see such tax changes and improved schools as crucial to the state's economic development, have promised to spend millions of dollars on television ads in support of the September referendum.
But religious groups could provide the margin of victory. Susan Pace Hamill, a University of Alabama tax professor with a theological degree from an evangelical divinity school, caused a stir with a law review article called "An Argument for Tax Reform Based on Judeo-Christian Ethics," which makes an evangelical case for making the tax system fairer. She plans to train speakers this summer to take the theological argument to the grass roots. Kimble Forrister, the state coordinator of Alabama Arise, a coalition that advocates for poor people, expects the 100 church groups that are part of his organization to hold church-basement workshops this summer to get the word out to their congregations.
The Christian Coalition of Alabama has not yet taken a position on the September vote, but it has been speaking out against the plan's tax increases. In an interview yesterday, John Giles, the group's president, had trouble pointing to a biblical passage that directly supported his opposition to new taxes, but he referred to Jesus' statement about rendering unto Caesar what is Caesar's. The key question, he argued, is, "How much is Caesar's?"
As the Bush administration and the religious right fight to put theology more squarely into public policy discussions, they are going to have to be ready for arguments like the ones coming out of Alabama. Many theologians argue that it is far easier to find support in the Bible for policies that help the poor than for, say, a cut in the dividend tax. If Governor Riley's crusade succeeds this summer, Alabama may offer the nation a model for a new kind of tax system: one where the Devil is not in the details. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: RESISTANCE; 
Deadly Attacks on G.I.'s Rise; Generals Hope Troop Buildup Will Stop the Skirmishes

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD,Iraq, June 9 

 BODY:
Unknown gunmen shot and killed an American soldier at a checkpoint in western Iraq on Sunday night, continuing a series of attacks that have killed nine American troops in 14 days. 
 The number of casualties from attacks in Iraq has risen sharply in the past two weeks, but military officials said the recent deployment of 4,000 American soldiers to central Iraq would curb the threat. 
 "We are not going to allow it," said Capt. John Morgan, a military spokesman in Baghdad. "We are going to decisively engage." 
Military officials said they believed that small groups of hardened Saddam Hussein loyalists were responsible for most of the incidents. The strikes, which occur mainly across central Iraq, often involve tactics Iraqi irregulars successfully used at the outset of the war, hitting so-called soft targets like resupply convoys and isolated checkpoints. 
American and Iraqi officials said they believed the strikes did not represent the emergence of an organized nationwide resistance. American officials are eager to describe Iraq as stabilizing, but with few of the attackers captured, it is difficult to gauge whether the strikes are centrally planned. Officials have also said that radical Islamists and foreign fighters may also be involved.
In the three weeks after President Bush declared the end of major combat in Iraq on May 1, one American soldier was killed and at least 11 were wounded in hostile incidents, according to records from Central Command. In the last two weeks, 9 soldiers have been killed and at least 22 wounded in attacks. When accidents are included, Defense Department data show the toll since May 1 is 42 dead; 138 were killed in hostilities and accidents during the war.
There has also been a spate of nonfatal attacks on American forces in Baghdad. In the last eight days, unknown men attacked an American patrol with hand grenades and small arms in the Adhamiya neighborhood; an American military policemen was shot in the chest in Sadr City, the Baghdad neighborhood formerly called Saddam City; and there were at least two grenade attacks.
The continued violence is hampering efforts to bring Iraq the kind of calm needed for investment, business leaders say. If the attacks continue, they could complicate American plans to project an air of stability in the country, attract finance and eventually reduce the number of American troops. 
The American administrator, L. Paul Bremer III, met today with Iraqi businessmen and politicians, and representatives of the International Monetary Fund at a gathering of an American-led business council.
Mr. Bremer said that paying the salaries of state employees was infusing $500 million into Iraq's economy, but the country would also need outside investment. 
Though the attacks on American forces promote an image of continued strife in Iraq, other aspects of life are gradually returning to normal, particularly in Baghdad. 
Lines for gasoline are almost at their prewar lengths, thanks to the flood of fuel supplied by the allies. The food distribution system that provided sustenance to 60 percent of the population has resumed, and the lack of customs and tariff duties at borders has engendered a flood of small-scale trade as shops reopen. Sidewalks are stacked high with appliances and electronics goods trucked in from Jordan and Kuwait.
American soldiers in the city have appeared relaxed over the last several days. This afternoon, soldiers from the 82nd Airborne Division joked as they dealt with snarled traffic in northwest Baghdad. Residents said they had noticed no change in the number of American patrols or in soldiers' behavior.
"There are no incidents in Baghdad," Muhammad Nazir, a 29-year-old college student, said, referring to clashes between Iraqis and Americans. "So it's not a problem."
Most of the fatal attacks have taken place outside Baghdad in central Iraq, which is dominated by Sunni Muslims. That is where Mr. Hussein, a Sunni himself, enjoyed his strongest support and where senior members of the Baath Party were from.
The current spate of attacks began on May 26 with twin attacks on American convoys. In Haditha, about 120 miles northwest of Baghdad, assailants fired small arms, rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns at an American resupply convoy at 6:15 a.m., military officials said. Major Mathew E. Schram, 36, of Wisconsin was killed, and another American soldier was wounded.
In Baghdad at 5 p.m. on the same day, Pfc. Jeremiah D. Smith, a 25-year-old from Odessa, Mo., was killed and three others were injured when their vehicle drove over a mine or piece of unexploded ordnance on the main road leading to the city's airport. Military officials said they believed someone placed the device on the road.
The following day, May 27, a convoy of American soldiers was attacked in the town of Falluja, a city 35 miles west of Baghdad where residents said American soldiers had shot 18 unarmed demonstrators and wounded 80 during demonstrations in late April. American officials said their forces were fired on. 
In the firefight, which began at 1:30 a.m., two American soldiers were killed and nine wounded by unknown men firing rocket-propelled grenades and small arms at an American convoy. Military officials said two attackers were also killed and six were wounded. One of the American dead was identified as Sgt. Thomas F. Broomhead, 34, of Canon City, Colo. The identity of the other was not available.
A day later, on May 28, Specialist Jose A. Perez III, a 22-year-old from San Diego, Texas, was killed when his convoy was ambushed in the town of Taji, roughly 35 miles northwest of Baghdad. Six days later, on June 3, Sgt. Atanacio Haromarin, a 27-year-old from Baldwin Park, Calif., was killed when unknown gunmen fired guns and rocket-propelled grenades at his checkpoint outside the town of Balad north of Baghdad.
Two days later, on June 5, 20-year-old Private First Class Branden F. Oberleitner of Worthington, Ohio, was killed when an assailant fired a rocket-propelled grenade as he completed a patrol in Falluja. Five other soldiers were wounded.
Another two days later, on June 7, one American soldier was killed and five were wounded in an attack on American forces outside the city of Tikrit, in Saddam Hussein's home region, about 100 miles north of Baghdad. Small arms and rocket-propelled grenades were again used.
The latest killing occurred late Sunday night at an American checkpoint in the town of Al Qaim, near the Syrian border, military officials said. 
An unknown number of individuals drove up to a checkpoint saying they needed help for a sick person in the car, officials said. Two people armed with pistols stepped out of the car and shot a soldier.
Other soldiers shot back, killing a gunman and capturing a second. At least one gunman fled in the car.

HEADLINE: For Greenspan, A Time to Cut Or to Surprise? 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6 

 BODY:
By signaling that he is prepared to cut interest rates once again, Alan Greenspan has entered what many analysts consider to be dangerous territory in one of the most difficult battles he has fought as chairman of the Federal Reserve.
 Mr. Greenspan has used his rhetorical power in recent weeks to full effect, saying that he was inclined to take out "insurance" against a new downturn and the prospect of a sustained fall in prices, known as deflation. This hint of another cut in the short-term rate that the Fed controls has helped drive down long-term rates in the financial markets and reduced the cost of buying houses, factory equipment and many other engines of economic growth. 
 Before this month ends, however, Mr. Greenspan will have to switch from words to action, and he faces a dilemma in doing so. 
If the Fed does reduce short-term rates -- it would be the 13th cut since the start of 2001 -- they will fall to the lowest level since the 1950's. Rates would then be near a point where the $1 trillion money market industry had almost no room to earn profits, potentially disrupting financial markets and making it harder for some companies to borrow.
But if the Fed stands pat, it will do what Mr. Greenspan usually takes great strides to avoid doing: surprise the market. Mortgage and other interest rates would probably jump, and with the European Central Bank having cut its benchmark rate last Thursday by half a percentage point, the exchange value of the dollar might rebound somewhat, hurting American manufacturers that compete against foreign companies.
"You have so much anticipation that if the Fed didn't do anything now, people would all run for the same door at the same time," said Lou Brien, a strategist at DRW Trading in Chicago, which buys and sells financial contracts whose value is based on interest rates.
This uncomfortable choice greets Mr. Greenspan during an economic slump that has lasted more than two years and surprised him with its endurance. The Labor Department reported on Friday that unemployment reached 6.1 percent in May, a nine-year high, and that the economy was stuck in its longest sustained period without job growth in more than 60 years. 
While some other members of the Fed committee that sets interest rates have argued in recent months for another rate cut, Mr. Greenspan has remained optimistic and emphasized the underlying strengths of the economy, particularly the rapid growth in productivity caused largely by the adoption of new technology. With interest rates near zero, economists say Mr. Greenspan must soon be proved right to keep his once-secure reputation as one of the most successful central bankers in history. 
"The chairman has done a tremendous job for 15 years, managing crises, stabilizing the economy and helping to inform people about what the Federal Reserve's job really is," said Stephen G. Cecchetti, former research director at the New York Fed and now an economics professor at Ohio State University. "It would be a shame for it all to get blown because of a protracted slow-growth period."
Mr. Greenspan certainly seems energized, people who have worked with him say. In April, just a day after President Bush, responding to a reporter's question, said that Mr. Greenspan "should get another term" as Fed chairman, he released his own statement saying that he would accept reappointment. His current four-year term, his fourth, does not end until next June.
But the current fight to lift the economy out of its slump could be the last one for Mr. Greenspan. Having turned 77 on March 6, he is already the oldest Fed chairman ever. He is required by law to leave the Fed by early 2006, more than two years before his fifth term as chairman would end, because that is when his 14-year term as a member of the Fed's board expires. 
Board members cannot be reappointed, although they can remain on an interim basis for a short time until a successor is named. Mr. Greenspan became chairman in 1987 and completed the 14-year board term of Paul A. Volcker, his predecessor, before starting his own. 
In recent weeks, he has taken advantage of the scrutiny that each of his public comments receives to move markets without making any official policy decisions. By simultaneously emphasizing the economy's strengths and talking in more detail than he previously did about deflation, Mr. Greenspan has contributed to a rise in both stock and bond prices, an unusual combination that makes an economic rebound more likely.
His oratorical dance was on full display at a presentation he made by satellite last Tuesday -- from a book-lined television studio near the Fed's headquarters in Washington -- to a bankers' conference in Berlin. He began by noting that oil prices and lending costs had declined, suggesting what he called "a fairly marked turnaround" in the economy. 
But by the end of his talk, he was focusing on the unlikely but dangerous possibility of deflation, which can cripple an economy by causing wages to fall, debts to become effectively larger and consumers to cut spending. Because the risk of inflation is so low in the coming months, he told the bankers, the cost of taking out additional insurance against deflation was "very small indeed."
Long-term rates quickly fell further, reflecting a widespread, although not universal belief that the Fed would cut its benchmark rate -- the basis of the rate on overnight loans between banks -- by a quarter-point or even a half-point when it meets on June 24 and 25.
"If the market is pricing in an easing, it makes it more likely that an easing will take place," said William Dudley, chief economist of Goldman, Sachs. "In this environment, the Fed doesn't want to disappoint the market and have financial conditions tighten."
If long-term rates were to rise, the cost of buying new factory equipment, which most companies are already reluctant to do, would increase. Fewer consumers would be able to refinance their mortgages and use any leftover money for other things. Higher interest rates also tend to increase the exchange value of the dollar, making it more difficult for American companies to export goods and less difficult for foreign rivals to import.
A reduction in rates would ease these problems, and, most forecasters predict, help the economy finally begin growing at a healthy pace. But it would not come without its own complications.
At 1.25 percent, the Fed's benchmark interest rate leaves scant room for financial services companies to make a profit on money market funds. If the rate were cut to 0.75 percent, some funds' costs would exceed the interest rate. At a benchmark rate of 0.5 percent, most funds would be in that position, and some companies would probably leave the business. 
"If they want to stay in the game, they'd have to forgo some of the revenue, and that's going to hurt," said David L. Murphy, who oversees money market funds at Fidelity Investments.
Money market funds now hold more than $1 trillion in Americans' savings, up from almost nothing in the mid-1970's, and much of that money filters through the commercial-paper market to companies, which use it to invest. If the funds began closing or added fees, and caused investors to move money into bank accounts, the banks might not be willing to shoulder all the risk that a broader market now does, economists say.
Fed officials say they are not worried. Even if money market funds disappear, "there will still be lots of options that offer you very low risk," ensuring that there will be no lack of money for investment, said Arthur J. Rolnick, research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.
The officials add that lowering the benchmark rate is not their only option for fighting economic weakness. If it reaches zero and deflation remains a risk, they can, for example, take concrete steps to lower long-term rates.
Outside the Fed, though, many other economists wonder whether radical measures, like taking interest rates to 50-year lows and possibly beyond or embarking on a new set of policies, will go as smoothly as the Fed expects.
"We've never done this before," Mr. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs said. "There might be some unintended consequences, and some of the unintended consequences might be bad."
Before the month ends, Mr. Greenspan will choose which set of consequences he prefers.

HEADLINE: Mayor Says He Drove Down Cost of School Construction 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Saying that he has brought school construction costs under control, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that one of the city's leading construction companies had agreed to build a long-delayed addition to Queens Vocational High School at a cost that was nearly 30 percent lower than the city has paid for recent school building projects.
 At a news conference at the school in Long Island City, Mr. Bloomberg said the company, Turner Construction Company, would build the addition for $315 per square foot, compared with the average cost of $438 per square foot for the seven most recent school projects. 
 But while Mr. Bloomberg said the deal heralded a new era of efficiency and cost-effectiveness, others said the city still had a long way to go to rein in a school-building process that has long been known for delays and cost overruns. 
A report last year by a state panel found that the national average cost for new school construction was $146 a square foot. And the director of the Bronx Preparatory Charter School, Kristin Kearns Jordan, said her school's new building in the South Bronx was being built for less than $240 a square foot.
Mr. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said the deal with Turner Construction was a result of their effort to overhaul the school system. "For those of you that want to know what comes out of school reform, this is just another important part," Mr. Bloomberg said.
Last fall, Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Klein announced plans to merge the School Construction Authority and the City Department of Education's division of school facilities, saying that infighting between the agencies often increased the cost of projects and discouraged companies from bidding for school jobs.
But officials acknowledged that the merger alone would not reduce construction costs, and yesterday it seemed that much of what the mayor and the chancellor had done was based on recommendations in a report commissioned by the previous chancellor, Harold O. Levy. 
In December 2001, just before Mr. Bloomberg took office, Mr. Levy appointed a commission led by Peter M. Lehrer, a developer, to study ways to cut costs. The panel's report said the city could save up to 30 percent, lowering costs to about $325 a square foot, through uniform construction and less expensive building requirements.
At yesterday's news conference, William H. Goldstein, the president of the School Construction Authority, described new cost-cutting measures such as allowing the use of drywall instead of requiring concrete block for interior walls.
A senior vice president of Turner Construction, James C. McKenna, said the city had also agreed to a number of administrative reforms, such as reducing design changes during construction and avoiding delays in paying contractors.
But some said the city was still paying too much. "Clearly, $315 a square foot is better than $425," said Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the City Council's education committee. "But I still don't believe we are building at market price."
Ms. Moskowitz successfully led an effort this year to pass a law requiring the Department of Education to provide quarterly updates on all building projects. 
Ms. Moskowitz said the problem was not that bids were too high but that costs ballooned during construction. "It's what the school costs at the end of the day, once it's built," she said, adding that the mayor seemed to be celebrating too soon.
Ms. Jordan, the director of Bronx Prep charter school, said the public schools could do better. "It is a soft economy right now, so it is a good time to be buying construction," she said. "You should be able to get it for $250 a square foot."
Mr. Bloomberg has said that improving the schools is his most important goal. "We have produced better accountability, we have improved bidding procedures, and we have eliminated administrative bottlenecks," he said yesterday. 
As has become the custom at big education announcements, Mr. Klein stood quietly behind the mayor and then stepped forward to thank him. "Thank you for your leadership on this matter as well as so many other things," Mr. Klein said. "Before you became mayor, there was one report after another about the problems with school construction."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE NORTH; 
Iraqi Leaders, to Show Unity, Meet in Kurds' Area

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: ERBIL, Iraq, June 9 

 BODY:
A week after meeting two prominent Shiite leaders in the southern city of Najaf, the Kurdish leader, Massoud Barzani, gathered Iraqi opposition figures here today in Iraq's north in a show of unity that included some criticism of the American occupation.
 Representatives from the Wifaq Party and the Islamic party Al Dawa, as well as Adnan Pachachi, an independent leader, joined Mr. Barzani and the other main Kurdish leader, Jalal Talabani, here in the capital of the Kurdish region. Ethnic Kurds have lived autonomously in the area since 1991, when they won a war against Saddam Hussein. 
 The gathering of so many Arab parties here was unusual for two reasons. First, few of the parties had ever been to the Kurdish region -- the ethnic border with the rest of Iraq kept them separate from Kurds. Some parties, like Al Dawa, had not even recognized the region in the past. The visit was a nod to the growing political influence of the Kurds.
The visit also highlighted a willingness on the part of Iraqi opposition leaders to work together, at least publicly, when concerns of economy and political unity are at stake.
"The mere act of having everyone here today -- our brothers from the Arab community -- is a sign we will be working together closely," Mr. Barzani said in his speech.
There have been problems. In Kirkuk, a city and region where Mr. Hussein's Baathist Party had forced thousands of Kurds to leave their homes, tensions between Arabs and Kurds turned violent last month. Clashes left at least 12 dead.
Since then, however, political leaders of both ethnicities have called for calm and have refrained from exacerbating the already emotional situation. Also, an election in Kirkuk gave a victory to the Kurds, defusing some anger in the Kurdish community.
Today, in the Kurdish regional parliament, festooned with real and artificial flowers, Iraqi opposition leaders expressed some criticism of the American administration here and bemoaned the state of Iraq's economy.
"Indications of discontent are emerging among the population," said Abd Alelah Muslawi, of the Arab Socialist Party. "Promises given by the coalition forces have not been put into practice. Efforts at forming a national congress have evaporated."

HEADLINE: Burmese Junta's Remedy: Crackdown 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, June 10 

 BODY:
A brutal attack on Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her pro-democracy supporters a week ago has put an end to a faint spring in Myanmar and signals a return to the harsh repression of the past, diplomats and political analysts say.
 As much as anything, they say, the military junta has learned that in a country where it enjoys little public support, nothing works as well as sheer force. 
 If Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's new freedom to travel and meet supporters in the last year was an experiment in conciliation by the ruling generals of the former Burma, it was a disaster for them. 
As they have in the past, they badly misjudged the public mood when they released her from 19 months of house arrest. The wildly enthusiastic crowds she drew reaffirmed her place as a political force that is apparently unstoppable by anything short of a harsh crackdown.
"They found that even though they rule with an iron hand, the people still believe in another," said Sunai Phasuk, a Thai member of the human rights group Forum Asia who is an expert on Myanmar. "People are afraid of the generals but they respect Aung San Suu Kyi."
The generals' response was to clamp down on her, and to do so with a level of brutality that served as a warning to the rest of the country.
Late on the evening of May 30, military-backed hooligans attacked her motorcade in northern Myanmar with sticks, stones, slingshots and apparently with firearms, killing perhaps scores of people.
The State Department has said that American diplomats who visited the scene said the attack was premeditated and carried out by forces supported by the government, while the Burmese government referred to it as a clash instigated by Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's supporters.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and 19 of her lieutenants were detained. Around the country, scores of newly opened offices of her party, the National League for Democracy, were padlocked. A new roundup of her supporters has reportedly begun.
"If they can get away with it, this is the end of Aung San Suu Kyi, if not as a mythical figure then as a real threat to them," said Josef Silverstein, an expert on Myanmar at Rutgers University. "If people accept that she can be locked away and nobody can see her, and that other leaders can be silenced and that the party can be silenced, then they've won the day."
At the moment there are few signs of popular protest. The government has locked universities to prevent student uprisings, and the army reportedly has been placed on alert around the country.
When Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was released from house arrest in May 2002, she was given more freedom than she had had since the junta took power in 1988 after crushing a peaceful nationwide revolt at the cost of hundreds of lives.
In 1989 she was put under house arrest, which lasted six years, and in 1990 the generals made their first great public blunder by holding free parliamentary elections. Their candidates were trounced by the National League for Democracy.
Their response to that mistake was similar to their actions now: they simply annulled the result and started imprisoning their opponents.
Fifteen years after taking power, the ruling generals are back where they started, employing the method at which they are most successful, force.
"They are back to ground zero," said Aung Zaw, the editor of a Burmese exile magazine, Irrawaddy. "There is such a deep scar, how are you going to reconcile, how are you going to heal it? This is the ugliest political violence since 1988."
This is the third time -- since 1988 and the election of 1990 -- that the generals have stepped in with force to cut short a moment of hope.
As in the past, they are hunkering down to take on the world, whatever the cost, said Mr. Sunai of Forum Asia.
International condemnation has been led by the United States, and President Bush said last week that he backed a move in Congress to toughen current economic penalties against Myanmar by cutting off virtually all imports.
Other Western nations have also protested, along with the United Nations. 
But Myanmar is banking on a different, more forgiving set of partners now -- its giant neighbors China and India as well as the Southeast Asian nations with which it shares a loose political alliance.
In public at least, none of those nations have spoken out strongly against the crackdown.
News agencies in Myanmar reported on Monday that the Chinese ambassador had told a United Nations envoy that his country considered the events there "an internal political affair."
The envoy, Razali Ismail, has met with the junta's top leaders during a five-day visit and said today that he had received permission to meet Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi at her home. She was reported to have been injured in the attack last week and has been in custody since then.
Mr. Sunai said the timing of the attack just before the envoy's visit had been deliberate, emphasizing the junta's determination to defy outside pressure.
Mr. Razali is the representative of Secretary General Kofi Annan, who spoke out strongly last week, saying the people of Myanmar were "overwhelmingly in favor of change."
Publicly, the ruling generals have closed ranks. The military intelligence chief, Gen. Khin Nyunt, who is believed to have been behind last year's softer approach, made two speeches over the weekend blaming Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and her supporters for the violence.
In what seemed a veiled warning, the general referred to the crackdown of 1988 and said the popular uprising then showed the need to maintain law and order.
"Everyone needs to abide by the rules and regulations to be observed everywhere," he said, adding, "It is to be noted that the basic human rights would not protect those who violate an existing law."

HEADLINE: The Boeing State Fights to Build the Next Jet 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: EVERETT, Wash., June 4 

 BODY:
Anyone who doubts that seven is a lucky number need only visit this town on the eastern shore of Puget Sound.
 Over the course of three decades, workers at the Boeing Company's sprawling assembly plant here have sliced, drilled and welded the 747, 767 and 777 into airworthy shape. The company has always been subject to the ups and downs of the airline industry, but each new plane generally meant a round of hiring, and that in turn led to an urban and suburban boom for the entire Seattle area. 
 Luck, though, can fly off as easily as it swoops in.
The Puget Sound area and the state of Washington are now facing one of their worst nightmares -- the possibility that Boeing, its biggest employer, will move final assembly of its next wide-body jet, the 7E7, to another state. Boeing put out a call for proposals last month, asking interested states to submit by June 20 site plans and financial packages that would allow Boeing to build the plane at what it calls a competitive cost. Nearly a dozen states quickly expressed interest. 
Desperate to bring new jobs into a battered economy, government officials and business leaders here are scrambling to cobble together a proposal loaded with financial incentives. State legislators in a special session say they will try to work out favorable tax code revisions and tax relief before the session adjourns on Tuesday night. Workers have begun staging rallies next to Everett's 1,000-acre plant. Gov. Gary Locke's office says keeping Boeing's future production here is the state's "No. 1 priority at this point."
Critics say Boeing's threat is a form of corporate blackmail, a blatant attempt to spur pork-barrel legislation. The company, though, argues that it is simply looking for ways to better compete against Airbus, its growing European rival.
Boeing's search for a cheaper production site follows in the footsteps of many globe-straddling companies, as they decentralize operations to bolster their bottom lines. Like professional sports teams, companies have increasingly turned their backs on the places where they first put down roots and are playing states -- or even countries -- against each other in the hunt for incentives. 
Boeing, which has offices and plants in 26 states, shocked people here two years ago when it abruptly moved its headquarters -- and hundreds of jobs -- to Chicago, where it could distance itself from its commercial aviation arm and take advantage of big tax breaks and other incentives.
Washington has not done a financial assessment of what building the 7E7 here would mean for the economy, but Boeing estimates the project will create 800 to 1,200 assembly jobs after its start next year. Those will in turn create more jobs at local suppliers and businesses outside the aerospace industry, economists say.
"We think it's absolutely imperative that the next generation of Boeing airplanes be built in the state of Washington," Governor Locke said in an interview the day before leading a rally by the runways of Boeing Field, where Boeing has tested many of its planes. "We have all the infrastructure in place, the trained work force in place. We think it makes perfect sense, logical sense to have production here. I think clearly we're focused on the additional jobs that the 7E7 represents."
Connie Kelliher, a spokeswoman for District 751 of the International Association of Machinists, which represents 17,000 Boeing workers in the Puget Sound area, said that "these are good family-wage jobs that are not easily replaced, especially in today's economy."
Skeptics of the company's maneuverings say that states going out of their way during a time of budget shortfalls to help Boeing could end up with less than they had hoped for, because Boeing's commercial airplane business goes through big boom and bust cycles. This year, as the airline industry's worst downturn drags on, Boeing is laying off 5,000 workers -- on top of 30,000 already dismissed since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
"Any of these communities begging to produce Boeing's new planes should look at Boeing's track record," said Robert Lamb, a professor of management at the Stern School of Business at New York University who studies the aerospace industry. "Anyone wanting to take them on, thinking that they'll get a steady supply of jobs, that everything's going to be hunky-dory, they're not used to Boeing's cycle that leads to massive firing."
Indeed, John Feren, vice president for sales and marketing for the 7E7, said there was no guarantee that airlines would order the new plane, especially given the deep slump in air travel.
Skeptics like Professor Lamb also argue that Boeing is not gaining much of an economic advantage in holding a beauty contest, because the incentives that states offer will not be nearly enough to offset the subsidies given to Airbus by four European governments. In addition, they say, Boeing will find it tough to set up the kind of infrastructure and skilled work force that it already has in Washington.
Other states that have been mentioned as likely rivals to Washington include Illinois, Texas, Ohio, Virginia, South Carolina, Georgia, Arizona, Arkansas and Kansas, where Boeing builds many of its fuselages. Kansas has approved the issuing of up to $500 million in bonds to help build the plant.
Jim Pickens, director of the Arkansas Department of Economic Development, said that his office would propose three potential sites for the 7E7. Existing plants could be renovated to accommodate Boeing, he said, and the state is ready to dole out tax credits. Though officials are still in the middle of doing a cost-benefit analysis, Mr. Pickens said that "for a state the size of Arkansas, it would be huge and we consider it a mega-project for Arkansas."
Boeing has not made any specific demands of the state of Washington in relation to the 7E7 project. Last month, it released a broad list of criteria for the 7E7 site, criteria that include favorable weather and a nearby runway.
The company has indicated that it wants legislators in this state to lower the unemployment insurance tax and, to a lesser degree, to overhaul how companies contribute to the workers' compensation program.
"We want to be operating in a regulatory environment that is manufacturing-friendly," Mr. Feren said.
Chuck Cadena, a Boeing spokesman, said the company paid an average of $772 in unemployment insurance tax for each of its 54,000 workers in the state. By contrast, he said, Boeing pays $378 for a worker in California, where it has a major plant in Long Beach that assembles the 717 and various military planes. California is said to be one of the states possibly working on a 7E7 site proposal.
Governor Locke and many officials have said they agree that the unemployment insurance tax is onerous for big companies, and that the special session of the legislature convened to work out a state budget might revise the tax code on Tuesday. Some labor representatives, though, argue that the kind of changes that Boeing and other big companies are seeking will hurt certain workers who need unemployment pay.
The legislature passed a bill early last year revising the tax, but voters overturned it in a referendum last November after the construction industry and some small businesses mounted a campaign against the changes.
The first week of June, Governor Locke and some lawmakers suggested giving significant tax incentives to Boeing. State Representative Jeff Morris, a Democrat, said lawmakers want to give Boeing tax relief worth at least $100 million a year over two decades. He said the aerospace industry pays $300 million a year in state taxes, most of it from Boeing. That is equal to 2.6 percent of the state's total tax revenue, he added.
 On Monday, Governor Locke said at a news conference that he was pushing for a tax incentive package starting at a value of $28 million for the state's aerospace industry from 2003 and 2005 and going up to $120 million a year after 2007. The package would be contingent on Boeing's choosing Everett for its 7E7 assembly, and the incentives would be even greater if Boeing selected for its site Moses Lake, a small town east of the Cascades. 
Politicians are also pushing for the construction of a $16 million barge station in the bay near Everett to allow Boeing to receive larger shipments from its suppliers. Some lawmakers have suggested fast-tracking a project to widen traffic corridors that feed into Everett.
Besides those incentives, some government officials say, Everett would seem the natural choice for building the 7E7 because Boeing's plant here already has the infrastructure. In the early 1990's, the city allowed Boeing to add two assembly bays onto its main building to accommodate construction of the 777. Boeing ended up using only one bay for assembly, and the second became a storage area.
"We encouraged Boeing to build as much as possible so they would have the capacity," said Paul Roberts, director of planning and community development for the city of Everett. "The shell for the assembly system is already there."
Here at the Everett plant, work continues on orders for Boeing's three wide-body jets. A 747-400F cargo plane with a silver fuselage sits in an assembly bay, the 11th one off the line for China Airlines. On a balcony overlooking it, a small placard sums up the history of the plant: "Home of the twin-aisle long-range 747, 767, 777 wide-body jetliners, the Everett site represents Boeing to the world."
Unfortunately for Everett, many parts of the world have taken notice, and they are all too eager to do some representing of their own.

HEADLINE: A Museum Tends the British Melting Pot 

BYLINE:  By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 4 

 BODY:
At each end of Brick Lane in the East End of London, little plastic flags offer visitors a warm welcome to Banglatown. With its textile shops, travel agencies, restaurants and halal butchers serving a thriving community of Bangladeshi immigrants, this bustling street could well have been transplanted from the Indian subcontinent.
 But if Bangladeshis have made this Spitalfields neighborhood their own in recent years, a far older story is told at a building on a street leading off Brick Lane. Here, in what is billed as the first Museum of Immigration and Diversity in Britain, the message is that immigration to London is hardly a novelty, that for three centuries the area around Brick Lane has been a melting pot for immigrants and refugees. 
 Given the scale of immigration from Britain's former colonies since the 1960's, the museum at 19 Princelet Street is modest. Although it will be open daily during Refugee Week here, June 15 to 22, it is struggling to raise $4.8 million so that the building can be open year-round. Even in its dilapidated state, though, it is a powerful symbol of the ever-changing face of Spitalfields.
Huguenots, or French Protestants, were the first foreigners to move into the neighborhood, in the late 17th century. Among the 50,000 or so Huguenots fleeing religious persecution by Louis XIV was Peter Abraham Ogier, a silk merchant whose family was the first to occupy 19 Princelet Street in 1719. The house has remained nearly unchanged since then: even the original kitchen sink is still in place.
In the mid-19th century, with Spitalfields then favored by Jewish immigrants from Poland, Lithuania and Russia, a synagogue was added in the building's garden by its new tenant, the Loyal United Friends Friendly Society. Today, though abandoned for worship, the synagogue remains a mute witness to a Jewish community replaced by a new wave of immigrants.
The 19th century also brought Irish refugees of the potato famine, but the next big change came with the arrival of Caribbean immigrants after World War II. They were followed in the 1970's by Bangladeshis and, most recently, by a growing number of Somalis. A rare touch of traditional Britain survives at the Christ Church Spitalfields Church of England Primary School on Brick Lane, but almost all its students are the children of immigrants.
Nearby, another building represents the evolution of a neighborhood more strikingly. Built in the 18th century by Huguenots as a church called L'Eglise Neuve, it has successively housed the Society for Promoting Christianity Among Jews, a Methodist Chapel, the Great Synagogue Machzikei Hadass and, since 1976, the Jamme Masjid Mosque.
It is through this prism that the Museum of Immigration strives to recount the story of newcomers to Britain, a mission similar to that of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which interprets the immigrant experience in Manhattan during the 19th and early 20th centuries. For the moment, though, the Spitalfields museum's priority is more mundane: to raise money to strengthen its buckling walls and floors, some now supported by metal pillars. Even so, there are no plans to restore or modernize the building because 19 Princelet Street is itself the museum's principal exhibit. "We want to spend money where it cannot be seen," explained Susie Symes, a former British government economist who runs the museum's board of trustees.
The Ogier family's kitchen and living quarters give an idea of 18th-century domestic life, although the former synagogue is the most interesting architectural artifact: it retains its 19th-century chandeliers and an elegant balcony with paneling that carries the names of members of the local Jewish community and the money they contributed to the building's upkeep.
An aura of mystery was added to the building by "Rodinsky's Room," a book by Rachel Lichtenstein and Iain Sinclair published in 2000 (Granta). It recounts the strange life of David Rodinsky, a Jewish hermit who for decades lived in an attic room at 19 Princelet Street and who vanished suddenly in 1969. When his room was opened 11 years later it was found to contain cabalistic drawings as well as notebooks in Sumerian, Arabic, Japanese, Hebrew, Yiddish, Greek and Russian.
Rodinsky's room is closed now, but once the upper floors of the building have been made safe his refuge will become part of the museum's effort to keep alive three centuries of memory. In the meantime, a semipermanent show called "Suitcases and Sanctuary," organized two years ago, sets out to recall the poverty or repression that prompted immigrants to move to Spitalfields.
The charm of this exhibition is that it was put together by children from six local elementary schools who, for the most part, come from immigrant families. Thus Somali children wrote poems about the Irish potato famine and took part in a video in which they re-enacted Irish families traveling to Britain, while Muslim children from Bangladesh enacted a Yiddish folk tale. The story of Bengali immigration was in turn told by children from a local Roman Catholic school.
"We have proved with the exhibition that people want to visit thehouse," Ms. Symes said. "The idea is that you can take historic buildings and give them new meaning today through what they evoke. And we see that with visitors, who may be strangers but eagerly exchange ideas and experiences."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Visitors to the Museum of Immigration and Diversity in the Spitalfields section of London can write on luggage tags what they brought with them as immigrants or what they would take if suddenly forced to flee their homes. (Joel Pike/19 Princelet Street)

HEADLINE: Nokia Warns of Lower Sales, Blaming Economy and SARS 

BYLINE:  By HEATHER TIMMONS 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 10 

 BODY:
Nokia, the world's biggest maker of mobile phones, warned today that its second-quarter phone sales could be below forecasts because of economic weakness in the United States and Europe, currency fluctuations and the impact of SARS in China.
 It was the latest in a series of cautions over sales growth the company has issued in the last two years. The industry has weakened as consumers hesitate to buy new phones with features like cameras and color screens, while wireless operators have been slow to introduce services that generate demand for such phones. 
 Still, Nokia, based in Espoo, Finland, has had a knack for weathering slumps and setbacks. Today, the company affirmed that it would meet its target for earnings in the quarter, and its shares fellmodestly.
The scheduled mid-quarter update came a day after one of Nokia's chief rivals, Motorola, warned that it would fall short of sales and profit forecasts for the quarter and the year, citing weakening demand in Asia because of SARS.
China is an important market for phone makers, but the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome has scared off potential shoppers. Motorola has about 14 percent of the Chinese mobile phone market, while Nokia has less than 10 percent. 
"The upgrade market has been subdued, especially in China," Nokia's chief financial officer, Olli-Pekka Kallasvuo, said in a conference call today. "To what extent this is impacted by SARS is pretty difficult to verify."
Mr. Kallasvuo was more upbeat about the United States market, where Nokia had been losing market share. "There is substantial gain there, and that is driven really by the production introductions we have had there and good success there," he said.
Shares of Nokia fell 1.7 percent, to close at 14.95 euros in trading in Helsinki. On the New York Stock Exchange, its American depository receipts -- each representing one share of the Finnish company -- fell 1.4 percent, to $17.71. Motorola, meanwhile, slipped 8 cents, to $8.60, after falling 2.4 percent on Monday.
Another rival, Ericsson of Sweden, rose nearly 5 percent, to 8.75 kronor in Stockholm trading.
"Nokia is providing some relief," Rob van Oostveen, of ABN Amro Asset Management, told Reuters. "After Motorola, investors were concerned Nokia would disappoint, and although Nokia can't shrug off the dollar and China, it's managing the effects well." 
Nokia now expects that mobile phone sales could grow 4 percent or less in second quarter. Analysts had estimated phone sales would grow 4 to 12 percent in that period, based on company guidance. At the same time, market share in the mobile phone division is expected to rise from the first quarter, when it was 38 percent. 
Second-quarter sales at Nokia Networks, the company's infrastructure provider, are expected to drop as much as 5 percent from 6.9 billion euros ($8.1 billion) a year ago, the company said.
The drop reflects the fact that "operators in all major regions continue to decrease their investments," Nokia said. The drop is less than the 13 percent that analysts estimated, Merrill Lynch noted in a report issued today.
Nokia also confirmed second-quarter pro forma earnings predictions of 0.13 to 0.16 euro (15 to 19 cents), which includes a 350 million to 400 million euro charge ($409 million to $468 million) for a restructuring. In April, the company said it would eliminate 1,800 jobs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nokia announced in April that it would be eliminating 1,800 jobs as part of a restructuring plan devised in response to a series of losses. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Japan Detains 2 North Korean Ships, Part of Pressure Strategy 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 10 

 BODY:
Japan detained two North Korean cargo ships in Japanese ports today, moves that North Korea denounced as sanctions and that Japan defended as safety inspections.
 "We are ready to thoroughly inspect all North Korean vessels at ports across the country," Chikage Ogi, Japan's transport minister, said at a news conference, hours before her inspectors scoured the North Korean ships for violations. 
 The detentions were ordered a day after Bush administration officials said they were encouraging allies to put pressure on North Korean shipping by enforcing safety rules and searching for illegal drugs, a major North Korean export. The policy is part of a broader effort to force North Korea into negotiating an end to its nuclear bomb program. 
Inspectors worked all day in Maizuru, a western Japan port that last year received about one-quarter of the 1,344 calls to all Japanese ports by 147 North Korean ships. After the inspections, Maizuru transport ministry officials ordered the detention of the Namsan 3, a 298-ton freighter, until its North Korean crew of 16 could fix three major safety violations: lack of charts of surrounding seas, a hole in its bulkhead, and a doorsill to the cabin that was too low to prevent water from flooding in.
Farther north, at Otaru port in Hokkaido, northern Japan, local transport officials ordered the detention for safety violations of the 178-ton Daehungrason 2, which was carrying a cargo of crabs.
During the last decade, several North Korean freighters have become stranded along Japan's coast. Invariably, the state company owners have walked away from the shipwrecks, refusing to pay fines or to remove the hulks.
The detentions today came after North Korean authorities suspended the country's lone ferry link with Japan to protest the new safety inspection policy. North Korea's state-run press denounced the inspections.
"If this is part of 'sanctions' against the D.P.R.K., we cannot but regard it as a very serious development," the official Korean Central News Agency said, using the initials of North Korea's formal name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.
It called the policy "part of the Bush administration's foolish and shameful moves to ostracize the D.P.R.K. politically and morally on the international arena and isolate and stifle it by terming it a 'rogue state.' "
But for Japan, the largest economy in the region, North Korea's hostility only serves to strengthen the political standing at home of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi. A survey by NHK public television broadcast on Monday evening showed that 59 percent of voters supported Mr. Koizumi's two-year-old government, up five percentage points from a poll in May.
While the United States and Japan are tightening a maritime noose on North Korea, China and South Korea seem increasingly neutral.
"Under the present circumstances, both sides should avoid taking measures which are likely to escalate the situation on the Korean peninsula," China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Kong Quan, told reporters in Beijing today.
South Korea plans on Saturday to ceremonially mark the renewal of rail and road links with the North. Freight trains should be traveling from Seoul to Pyongyang by the end of September, Cho Myoung-gyon, a senior official at South Korea's Unification Ministry, said in a radio interview today.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Travel Slump Makes Prices Right for Hotel Buyers

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Of the 282 hotels in the United States that fly the Sheraton or Four Points by Sheraton flag, only one in six is actually owned by Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc., the company that controls the Sheraton brand and several other well-known hotel trademarks.
 With the lodging industry experiencing its worst slump in four decades, according to a report issued this month by PricewaterhouseCoopers, the proportion of hotels that Starwood owns as well as operates is expected to decrease. The buyers are private investors taking advantage of favorable interest rates and greatly reduced prices. 
 Like several other publicly traded hotel companies, Starwood is pruning its inventory, trying to shed hotels in suburban and other so-called secondary markets that it does not consider part of its core real estate strategy. 
Last month, it announced that it was selling 14 hotels, including 8 Sheratons and 2 Westins, to a group of four private investment companies -- Olympus Real Estate Partners, Rockwood Capital Advisors, Prudential Real Estate Investors and HEI Hospitality -- for $312 million. Starwood, which is based in White Plains, has sold several of its European hotels and is negotiating with CNL Hospitality Partners, a closely held company in Orlando, Fla., to divest itself of four additional properties, said Ted Darnall, the president of the Starwood Real Estate Group.
After two years of occupancy rates below 60 percent, many hotel companies are struggling under heavy debt loads. Selling off expendable properties gives them cash to reduce debt and to buy properties that are more in line with their business strategy. In its last quarterly earnings report, Starwood said it had $5.2 billion in net debt, compared with $5.1 billion at the end of 2002. Starwood has a Ba1 rating from Moody's Investors Service and was recently downgraded from BBB- to BB+ by Standard & Poor's. The current ratings are considered below investment grade.
The portfolio sold by Starwood mainly included properties in suburban markets like Stamford, Conn., and Danvers, Mass. Mr. Darnall said that his company had spent an average of $6.5 million per hotel on improvements since 1999, and that the properties had fairly stable earnings over the past few years. The stability made them expendable, he said.
"They didn't have as much recovery upside as most of the others in our portfolio," he said. "We think there's an opportunity for us to use that capital a little better." The company's strategy calls for owning hotels in larger urban areas, he said.
The new owners of the Starwood properties will bring in their own management company, Smilezzzz Hospitality, a subsidiary of HEI Hospitality, but the Sheratons and Westins in the deal will remain under those banners as Starwood franchises. 
Hotel companies want their reach to be as broad as possible, said Daniel H. Lesser, managing director of Cushman & Wakefield's hospitality and gaming group. "The name of the game," he said, "is having distribution -- varying hotel products at different price points in different places where travelers go."
Hotel industry experts say that companies do not necessarily sacrifice quality control by franchising, because the owners are required to maintain standards and periodically upgrade the properties. "Usually the franchise agreement is pretty restrictive," said Thomas McConnell, a senior managing director at Insignia/ESG Hotel Partners. "So they are having their cake and eating it, too." 
Mr. McConnell advised another hotel company, Wyndham International of Dallas, when it sold 13 properties for $447.7 million late last year to Sunstone Hotel Investors and Westbrook Hotel Partners IV. Sunstone, a former real estate investment trust, became a private company in 1999.
In its recent report, PricewaterhouseCoopers said that demand for hotel rooms had risen slightly since the end of the war in Iraq. The report said the increase would continue, but it predicted that averagedaily room rates would not show a real increase, adjusted for inflation, until 2005. And even then, revenues per available room would be at 1995 levels, it said.
Most other analysts are less pessimistic, said Robert I. Bowers Jr., a senior vice president at Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn. "A lot of people agree that there will be some improvement in '04," Mr. Bowers said.
Gary Mendell, the chief executive of HEI Hospitality, one of the partners in the Starwood deal, said the occupancy rate for the hotels in that portfolio was slightly more than 60 percent. "Our assumption going forward," he said, "is that when the industry starts improving it will not improve to the same level as before."
Nevertheless, Mr. Mendell said the Starwood properties were attractive because they were in good locations near prime office buildings. He said the company expected to hold on to the hotels for three to eight years until they became more profitable.
In the latest wave of hotel trading, not all the sellers have been branded hotel corporations. Hotel real estate investment trusts, which do not offer franchises or management contracts, are also feeling pressure to sell some of their properties. 
In February, FelCor Lodging Trust, a REIT based in Irvington, Tex., announced plans to dispose of 33 hotels; 2 Hampton Inns, in Moline, Ill., and Davenport, Iowa, were sold last week to a buyer that FelCor, at the purchaser's request, declined to identify.
And last month, CNL Hospitality Partners announced that it would buy RFS Hotel Investors, another REIT, for $383 million in cash and the assumption of $304 million in debt. The deal will add 57 hotels to CNL's portfolio. Arthur Adler, a managing director of Jones Lang LaSalle Hotels, which offers brokerage and consulting services for the hospitality industry, said REITs were giving up properties to raise cash.
"A lot of these REITs have debt coming due," said Mr. Adler, who is representing FelCor in the sale of Doubletree Guest Suites in Dayton and Columbus, Ohio, and Embassy Suites hotels at the Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport and in Flagstaff, Ariz., and Syracuse, "and they want to demonstrate to the market through their ability to sell assets that they can raise capital."
Despite the hotel industry's poor near-term prospects, private buyers are beginning to take advantage of low interest rates and a drop in prices. Until recently, said William B. Murney, a senior vice president and lodging and hospitality specialist at CB Richard Ellis, few better-quality hotels were up for sale. "There's a lot of pent-up demand in the market," he said.
In 1998, said Patrick H. Ford, the president of Lodging Econometrics, a brokerage and research company in Portsmouth, N.H., there were 575 transactions involving hotels, and the average selling price per room was $88,902. Last year, only 367 sales took place, for an average price of $69,237 a room.
Luxury-hotel prices have declined more slowly, Mr. Ford said. The peak was in 1999, when 11 high-end properties changed hands, at an average price of $385,000 a room. Last year, when there were only 6 such transactions, and the average price was $330,000 a room, he said.
"There's not a lot that come to market," Mr. Ford said. "These represent long-term real estate investments, and the people in them generally ride out the operating ups and downs."

HEADLINE: Flooding of S. Dakota Mine Stalls Plans for Laboratory 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH CHANG 

 BODY:
Severely hurting the chances of turning a former gold mine in South Dakota into an underground laboratory, the owner of the mine yesterday turned off its pumps, allowing water to begin accumulating in tunnels 8,000 feet below the surface.
 South Dakota congressmen met with the owners of the Homestake mine on Monday but failed to persuade them to keep the pumps going. 
 Workers severed the electrical connections yesterday, and after some tidying up will retreat to the mine's 5,000-foot level today, said Vincent Borg, a spokesman for the Barrick Gold Corporation of Toronto, which owns Homestake. 
Within days, the water, accumulating at 500 gallons a minute, will render one of the hoists inoperable and make the lower reaches of the mine inaccessible.
Scientists who proposed turning Homestake into a deep underground laboratory for an array of particle physics, geology and biology research said they would try to conduct their experiments at other underground laboratories in Japan, Canada or Europe, and look to build a laboratory elsewhere in the United States.
"I would not say it's dead," John F. Wilkerson, a physics professor at the University of Washington, said of the laboratory proposal for Homestake. "I would say as the water seeps in, its life seeps away."
Dr. Wilkerson and the other scientists working on the proposal will finish the engineering plans, including proposed layouts and detailed explanations of the experiments they would like to conduct, for the National Science Foundation in the next few weeks. Once finished with those plans, which cost about $100,000 to produce, the scientists will probably not do any further work.
Barrick officials said they supported converting Homestake into a laboratory and were willing to donate the mine to the state. However, because financing for a laboratory is at least two years away, they say it is more economical to let the mine flood now and to empty it later.
Pumping alone costs $250,000 a month, but Barrick officials said that keeping the mine open would require $50 million to $75 million of improvements to antiquated infrastructure. Emptying a flooded mine would cost about $15 million, they said.
The scientists estimated the cost of maintaining the mine at $5 million to $6 million for infrastructure improvements, but $30 million to $40 million for emptying a flooded mine.
At the meeting on Monday, the congressmen asked Barrick officials to devise a framework that would address their liability concerns and make the donation possible. The officials agreed, but did not specify how long that would take.
"I think it'll be a matter of months before things will take their shape and form, and people will be able to work on issues and start to resolve them and move forward," Mr. Borg said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Agency Drops Out Of Subway Review

BYLINE:  By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
Euro RSCG MVBMS in New York withdrew yesterday from a review for the creative and strategic planning parts of the account of Subway Restaurants, thereby giving up assignments the agency had handled since March 2000. Although billings were not disclosed, Subway spent $218.6 million to advertise in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres. 
 Euro RSCG MVBMS is part of a division of Euro RSCG Worldwide, a unit of Havas. The agency decided that its approach was "in contrast to what Subway is looking for from an agency partner," said its president, John Berg. 
 The withdrawal leaves eight agencies in the review. Three are units of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies: Deutsch in New York, Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York and the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va. The others are Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group; McCarthy Mambro Bertino in Boston, which is creating a spot for Subway on a project basis, separate from the review; Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore.; and one agency that has not been identified.
Joanne Davis Consulting in New York is helping manage the review, which is being overseen by the Subway Franchisee Advertising Fund Trust.

HEADLINE: Union Questions Tax Breaks For Wall St. Building's Owner 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Is 45 Wall Street an office tower, or an apartment building?
 In the latest chapter of the building's complicated history, a janitors' union has filed a complaint with the city claiming that the building's owners are unfairly receiving tax breaks for the 28-story tower, which originally contained offices, then was converted to apartments, then was converted back to commercial space, and now is being reconverted into residences. 
 The union is questioning the special tax breaks for which the building qualified after its initial conversion to residential use in the mid-1990's. The incentives are used to encourage developers to build more apartments in the financial district. 
The union claims that after an agreement was reached in 2001 to sell the building to the city as part of a doomed $1.4 billion project to build a new stock exchange, the owner -- Rockrose Development Corporation -- continued to benefit from the residential property tax breaks even as it was receiving up to $1 million a month from the city to keep the building vacant. 
"There's a double dip going on," said John P. Hamill, deputy communications director for the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, which has tangled with Rockrose over the company's practice of not hiring union janitors for some of its residential buildings in Manhattan. "In these gloomy economic times, when the city is closing firehouses and laying off workers, the idea that people are being paid twice for keeping a building empty is troubling."
The complaint, filed by the union last Thursday, is an administrative action permitted in the regulations governing the city's 421-g tax incentive program, and not a court proceeding. 
Kevin P. Singleton, senior vice president at Rockrose, declined to discuss the complaint or the tax incentives, citing a confidentiality agreement with city officials, but he called the union's document "another strong-arm tactic" by the union to harass the company. 
Carol Abrams, a spokeswoman for the Department of Housing, Preservation and Development, said that if the city decides the tax benefits were awarded inappropriately, "we will revoke them, and we will do so retroactively." 
Rockrose bought 45 Wall Street in 1996 and spent $75 million converting the office tower into about 435 apartments.
Under the 421-g program, which was intended to bring round-the-clock activity to Manhattan's financial district, commercial buildings converted to residences in the downtown area qualify for property tax breaks that last 14 years. 
When the New York Stock Exchange threatened to move to Jersey City in 1998, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put together a huge deal to demolish several buildings and build a new trading floor for the stock exchange, topped by a 50-story office tower. Critics complained about the mayor's plan to give $1 billion in public subsidies to retain an institution unlikely to leave New York.
Although some tenants had just settled in, Rockrose struck a deal in 2001 to sell 45 Wall Street to the city for about $160 million, and emptied the building. 
After the Sept. 11 terror attack, enthusiasm for the new stock exchange waned and the project eventually died. The city returned the property to Rockrose and the company is again renting apartments there, offering up to two months free rent with a two-year lease. 
The city will continue paying up to $1 million a month until 95 percent of the 435 apartments are leased. Mr. Singleton said 90 percent of the apartments have been taken.
