HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: BAGHDAD; 
Cheers and Grumbles for Democracy and a Would-Be King

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 10 

 BODY:
It was another day in postwar Iraq.
 On the north end of town, hundreds of tribal sheiks in colorful robes sat in plastic chairs outside the royal mausoleum to hear the first words of Sherif Ali bin Hussein, a member of the former Iraqi royal family, who returned today to offer himself as a successor to the last king, overthrown by Arab nationalists in 1958. 
 "Iraq is for the Iraqis," he said to cheers from the crowd. "We won't accept being under the mandate of anyone. Iraqis will choose their future." 
On the south end of town, a crowd of mostly Shiite Muslims gathered on a square to hear a speech by Abdul Aziz al-Hakim, the brother of Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, who leads the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution of Iraq, a group that was backed by Iran during its long exile during the rule of Saddam Hussein.
"We have to elect a president," he said to cheers from the crowd. "That is our national right."
A bright sun of early Mesopotamian summer bore down on both crowds and on the speakers whose common theme emphasized the virtues of democratic process and pluralism. These have become the common principles of the disparate groups vying to lead a country that has never known democracy.
Sherif Ali, a maternal cousin of the late King Faisal II, called for a referendum on a constitutional monarchy for Iraq, where a new king, himself, as a direct descendant of Muhammad, could bind up the divisions of Sunni and Shiite Muslims, Kurds and Turkmen, in a parliamentary system.
In the sweltering heat, the sheiks stirred, then they started to leave. Some grumbled that they could not hear the speech, but others complained that it lacked practical content. By the time it was concluded, half of them had moved to their cars to return home or line up for lunch at the lush villa reserved for Sherif Ali. It was the same house that Mr. Hussein used when he was host to Yasir Arafat and other notables in an earlier era.
"These are the same chanting people who were here for Saddam Hussein," said one sheik in a gray robe, who refused to give his name.
Sheik Majid Hatem al-Sayhoud, leader of the Sudan tribe of central Iraq, said "We will vote for the one who will serve the country."
At the Shiite rally, Sheik Hakim had more luck holding his audience throughout his 30-minute address. But as he assailed Mr. Hussein's repressive rule and his persecution of the Shiites, the sheik had to cope with a different distraction.
Two American Apache attack helicopters circled over the rally at the beginning and at the end of the speech. The flight prompted some in the crowd to criticize the United States for appearing to provoke and intimidate the Shiites as they seek to field their own leaders in the political transition under way here.
The capital seemed bracketed by political events, and from the locus of power near the center of the city, the top American administrator, L. Paul Bremer III, held his own public event, a news conference, to mark his first month as the head of the occupation authority.
In the air-conditioned hall of a convention center, Mr. Bremer took the opportunity to say that in that month, "the coalition and the Iraqi people have accomplished a lot."
Iraq is still a war zone, he conceded, and unemployment is in excess of 50 percent. "Repairing the damage of the last regime is a huge task," he said, but day by day the occupation authority is making progress. His "top priority," he said, is "creating jobs" for Iraqis. 
Today Mr. Bremer announced that he would create a $100 million public works program to start rebuilding the country's infrastructure.
"Modernizing the infrastructure is essential to modernizing the economy," he said. "At the same time, this fund will create jobs for thousands of Iraqi workers on important projects across the country." 
The funds will be drawn from Iraq's assets, funds left in the Central Bank and seized from the accounts of Mr. Hussein's government. The first $45 million will be distributed to Iraq's three regions -- north, central and south -- for urgent projects. About $20 million will be used to repair the looted and destroyed ministry buildings in Baghdad and $35 million will be allocated to unfinished public projects, like the last 60 miles of the Baghdad-Basra freeway and the Baghdad surgical hospital, he said.
Here in the capital, the rhythm of life is returning slowly to normal but the landscape of destruction still is vast. The mornings belong to the commerce that is much more in evidence than just two weeks ago as consumer goods flood a market where the lack of tariffs or customs duties have led to an explosion of imports.
The streets are filled with schoolchildren, and the universities are in session though many buildings remain stripped of equipment and windows. Politics and religion, too, are day occupations, for when the sun begins to set, Baghdad reverts to a war zone, where looters, bandits and hundreds of army patrols own the streets. Gunfire still punctuates the night and few Baghdadis venture out to the fish restaurants that are opening to empty tables in a town where a dinner of river carp called masgouf is a staple of life.
At dusk on a day that saw the death in Baghdad of another American soldier, a paratrooper with the 82nd Airborne Division, the American patrols set out in strength, again, through the capital. 
On Rashid Street in the old shopping district, most of the stores were shuttered when gunfire rang out at 7 p.m. A 22-year-old man who had been pushing a wooden cart loaded with aluminum scrap gathered from the looted and burned-out Ministry of Trade was challenged by troops from the First Armored Division.
The suspected looter dropped his cart and ran. Several soldiers gave chase through the warren of the old commercial district.
"Stop," a soldier yelled, according to witnesses. "Stop," he yelled again. But the young man, Ahmen Jassim, kept running. He was afraid they were going to arrest him as a thief. He said he had received permission to carry away "debris" from the destroyed ministry building.
As Mr. Jassim rounded the corner onto Rashid Street, the lead soldier giving chase went down on one knee, leveled his weapon and fired, bringing Mr. Jassim down on the sidewalk. The bullet pierced his leg, severing a major artery, doctors said.
The soldier asked a passer-by, Salem al-Baladawi, to transport the wounded man to the nearest hospital. The man was not placed under arrest.
The shooting was treated with some sensitivity at the checkpoint that initiated the chase of Mr. Jassim. An officer told witnesses not to speak to a reporter. Some did anyway. They applauded the aggressive action against looters. American military officials last month said they were not going to shoot looters unless the soldiers were threatened. Instead, they said they would arrest the looters and hold them for 21 days.
A sergeant at the checkpoint said his comrades had pursued Mr. Jassim because they assumed he was a looter. "He wouldn't have run unless he was guilty," the sergeant said. 
As night fell, the crowds melted away. The soldiers stood guard or went on patrol. Occasional gunfire popped in the distance, setting off the city's street dogs. Then quiet.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Hussein Offering Bounty, Iraqi Says
 Ahmad Chalabi, a prominent Iraqi exile who has now returned to Baghdad, said yesterday that he had evidence that Saddam Hussein was still alive and offering a bounty for killing American troops.
In a breakfast speech to members of the Council on Foreign Relations, Mr. Chalabi asserted that the deposed Iraqi leader, whom he said was roaming the northern part of the country, was offering 300,000 Iraqi dinars (about $200) for every American soldier killed. 
He said he had been told that payments had already been made.
An administration official said that while there were reports of bounties early in the war, officials had not heard recently about a bounty being offered by Mr. Hussein or his supporters.
To reduce American military casualties in Iraq, Mr. Chalabi urged the administration to begin training an Iraqi security force of 25,000 to work with allied forces to police the streets and restore order. He said he had proposed such a force to Mr. Bremer, the American administrator in Baghdad, and to Pentagon officials, but said they were noncommittal.
Mr. Chalabi also criticized the administration for trying to appoint an Iraqi advisory council, rather than pressing forward with plans for a democratic provisional government.
"It is not possible to manufacture leaders," Mr. Chalabi said. Asked about Mr. Chalabi's criticisms of American policy in Iraq, an administration official said that postponing plans for elections was necessary in order to concentrate on restoring security and basic services.

HEADLINE: TRADE SECRETS; 
Let Flies Keep Out, Let Summer Fly In

BYLINE:  By ROLAND MERULLO 

 BODY:
UNLESS your 6-year-old pokes a hole in it, a tipsy dinner guest leans too hard on it or -- as happened during an early scene in "The Wizard of Oz" -- a violent wind rips it from its hinges, you are liable to take your screen door for granted. Sure, the slapping sound echoes in your memory like the melody of a childhood summer. And, sure, the striking plate or the hydraulic door-closer needs an occasional maddening adjustment. But for the most part, it is just there, letting breezes in and keeping mosquitoes and hornets out, a curtain of frame and mesh that guards the border between domesticated air and something slightly wilder.
 The screen door, in one version or another, has been around since shortly after the Civil War, when people discovered how to weave metal wire. These days, industry leaders like the Home Depot sell millions a year, most made of metal, cellular PVC or softwoods. Typically, these off-the-rack doors cost $20 to $120, last an average of five years and slam, bang or sigh according to the hardware they are fitted with. 
But some homeowners are willing to pay for a door with more personality than aluminum and more durability than pine. About 15 years ago, Yvonne Hannemann and Penny Young, the owners of the New England Screen Door Company, stepped in with an appealing combination of enthusiasm and naivete. 
Today, working out of a former schoolhouse in Bristol, Me., they sell about 1,000 individually made doors a year, most costing $300 to $400. Their screen doors decorate the governor's mansion in Augusta and the homes of customers like Richard Gere, Yo-Yo Ma, Mary Steenburgen and Senator Olympia Snowe.
But the path to screen-door stardom has not always been smooth. "Our company," Ms. Young, 53, said on a sunny May afternoon near the Maine coast, "is a series of goofy stories and mishaps."
The two women, both sailing enthusiasts and Maine transplants, met accidentally on a boat ramp in 1984, talked about boats briefly, then did not see each other again for a full year. In their second conversation, they discovered they were both looking for odd-size screen doors, impossible to find at local lumberyards. Ms. Hannemann was primarily living in New York City, making documentary films. Ms. Young, a Massachusetts native, was working as a nurse. Neither had any woodworking experience, but they decided to solve their screen door problem by starting their own company.
Their business partnership began with a road trip up the Maine coast in 1986, a kind of cultural anthropology of the classic New England screen door. They came to the conclusion that the most appealing designs had been made by boat builders for the homes of sea captains. They took hundreds of pictures: basic rectangular frames, elaborate corner brackets and decorative spindles. 
"We'd jump out, see if people were home and march across their lawn," Ms. Young said.
Soon, with investment capital from their own savings, they bought and renovated the schoolhouse, purchased high-end European machinery, hired two craftsmen, found someone nearby who could make the screens and were ready to start.
There were few orders. Builders were not convinced that these two new arrivals -- trim, auburn-haired, looking more like figures from a Wyeth painting than hard-driving entrepreneurs -- could produce a quality product. Sometimes the women themselves were not sure. 
Ms. Hannemann, 66, says that machinery representatives hung up on her, timber companies ("in the Pine Tree State, no less") told her she could not buy clear pine from them because it had all been bought and paid for when the trees were seedlings. There was the freezing day when they watched in horror as an $18,000 ton-and-a-half European planer, just shipped across an ocean, crushed a trailer flat as it was offloaded in Brunswick. 
An imported clamping machine squeezed a redwood door "into splinters," as Ms. Young put it, because its new owners could not read the Italian directions. Customers, laboring under the illusion that hanging a screen door is simple, called and left measurements like this: "It's 40 plus 2 lines, by 7 feet plus 4 lines."
The learning curve was as steep as the sides of Mount Katahdin, so steep, in fact, that neither woman took home a salary for the first five years. Ms. Hannemann continued making films for corporate clients, and Ms. Young kept on with nursing.
The search for proper machinery and good advice was followed by a longer search for the perfect materials. They started with pine, but discovered that today's plantation-grown pine too often has a tendency to warp when exposed to the extremes of the New England seasons. They tried redwood, which was difficult for the machines to work and raised environmental issues. At last they stumbled upon South American cedar, one of 1,400 species in the mahogany family. Lighter than genuine mahogany, stable, resistant to decay and insects, easily worked, not harvested from rain forests, South American cedar has long been popular with makers of boat decks.
By the mid-1990's they had all the pieces of the puzzle in place: the right workers, the right wood, the right combination of office and workshop and, coincidentally, the right timing. Screen porches were then beginning to make a comeback. 
And screen-door expertise replaced their initial naivete. They now know, for instance, that because thresholds angle down and away from a house to shed water the bottom edge of a screen door should be beveled, not square. If you paint the door a dark color and hang it in a sunny spot, it will absorb heat quickly on summer days, causing a large temperature difference between the outside and inside faces, thus increasing the chances of warping. Unpainted doors need to be "treated like a boat," as Ms. Hannemann puts it, that is, protected with five or more coats of varnish.
They also learned that if a door edge is planed, it should be resealed immediately. After a piece of wood is cut, it needs to rest from the trauma to the grain before any assembly is done. They discovered that their preferred screening -- made from charcoal-anodized aluminum -- works well everywhere except right on the coast, where it tends to collect a salty residue. 
On the business side, Ms. Hannemann's college background in architecture and her marketing experience helped them come up with a corporate strategy: while New England Screen Door could easily make almost any size door -- screen, exterior, interior -- the partners concluded that it was wiser to sell their product through professionals and avoid getting into detailed telephone conversations with homeowners.
"Now we have a stable of architects and high-end builders who use us over and over again," Ms. Young said, and it is through architectural firms like Ryall Porter in Manhattan and builders like Peter Whitehead in Great Barrington, Mass., that the ex-neophytes have become, as Ms. Young facetiously puts it, "screen door makers to the stars." 
Charles Myer, a Cambridge, Mass., architect who discovered the New England Screen Door Company's products about 10 years ago, said: "They're beautifully made. Historically, the issue with screen doors is that for a long time there were only economy models, so people who do beautiful porches had to get their doors custom made."
Though the company is in Bristol, about an hour and a half north of Portland, most of its business comes from clients in a 600-mile stretch with Long Island at its center. To avoid mishandling and high shipping charges, and to foster face-to-face contact with customers, Ms. Hannemann personally delivers each door, traveling as far south as Washington and as far west as Albany, logging 45,000 miles annually on a Ford Econoline van.
There is little chance that they will move their enterprise elsewhere. "We're here in Maine because we want to be here in Maine," Ms. Young said. A visit to their airy and sunlit workshop (entered through a lilac-colored screen door) shows why. Though the company literature says that Bristol "consists of a flagpole and a small blue diner," that is not completely accurate: there is a fire station and a Congregational church, too. 
In warm weather, at least, the town is an ethereally pretty place, with huge old slate-roofed, shingle-sided barns sitting on fields overlooking coastal inlets.
The former schoolhouse, bought for $86,000 and expanded twice, has lots of natural light, a kitchen, a sales and design area, with nasturtium and tomato seedlings in trays on the windowsills and a workshop presided over by a former marine and master woodworker named Jody Perry, who says of his bosses, in a wry Down East accent, "I keep them in the office now."
Ms. Hannemann said she learned through trial and error that some of the hard-driving management techniques that served her in film producing made for disaster with the skilled craftsmen who have long populated the Maine coast. "I didn't realize that with men in woodworking, pointing out a flaw was a personal insult. In film, people have much thicker skins."
Now, after 17 years of struggle, they have a sense of being respected in woodworking circles and even time for a bit of philosophizing. "The slam of a screen door has always represented a sense of freedom for me," Ms. Young mused. 
Her partner chimed in: "It's very satisfying work. The product is basic. There's no spin, there's no jive. You need a door, it has to open and close. But it's the first thing you touch when you come to a house. It's the entrance to a person's life."
Keeps the black flies out, too. And that, in Maine, around this time of year, is no laughing matter.

The Made-to-Measure Screen Door
BEFORE you install a screen door, it is essential to take precise measurements -- from casing to casing, not from jamb to jamb as for an ordinary door. Allowance should also be made for the downward sloping bevel that fits against the threshold. 
The New England Screen Door Company makes interior and exterior doors using South American cedar. The screening is bronze, aluminum or fiberglass. (Glass panels are not included.) Prices start at about $300. The company prefers to work with architects and builders, and does not have a Web site; the number for a catalog is (212) 533-3023. 
Wood doors must be sealed and varnished or painted. They can be fitted with different hardware, including spring-loaded steel hinges, which are either brass-plated or primed and then painted. Some builders use hydraulic closers, but New England Screen Door recommends spring-loaded hinges because they do a better job of protecting the door in high winds. ROLAND MERULLO

HEADLINE: An Online Tag Sale Goes Uptown 

BYLINE:  By DAVID COLMAN 

 BODY:
EVERY year, arrivistes land in New York, freighted with bags of money earmarked for impressing one and all. The centerpiece of this effort is usually a showplace done by a top decorator and calculated to dazzle the locals. Last year, it was Richard and Lisa Perry, whose redo of a Sutton Place penthouse appeared over 10 pages in the September issue of Vogue.
 This season, it is Beekman Place, not Sutton. And it's not one designer, it's six. It's not the social scene's latest aspirants, it's eBay. 
 EBay, based in San Jose, Calif., had revenues of $1.2 billion last year. But like many rich out-of-towners, eBay longs for a toehold in Manhattan. To counter a popular impression of eBay as a vast flea market whose wares belong on the set of "That 70's Show," the company has worked up its own version of that old chestnut, the designer show house. In a penthouse duplex currently on the market for $4 million, four interior designers, one junior style expert and one magazine editor transformed its seven rooms into an eBay fantasia, calculated to impress viewers with the riches eBay has on tap. 
The aim is to make consumers aware of the depth and breadth of available merchandise, Henry Gomez, a vice president for communications, said. 
And the timing is deliberate. Having started its largest advertising campaign late last year, the company is trying to overcome its image as a giant garage sale. "EBay's single biggest concern is getting people to understand that they sell more than collectibles and junk," said Carrie Johnson, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, consultants in Cambridge, Mass. "They've been very successful at getting early-adopter shoppers to buy, but the majority of U.S. shoppers don't understand the breadth of product available on eBay, or that they can buy things for fixed prices."
Mayer Rus, design editor of House & Garden, said, "They clearly want to make a statement that eBay isn't just obscure Hummel figurines, that people with truly adventurous design agendas can find something." 
To advertise that point, the company gave the six designers a budget based on room size, with a mandate to buy all or most of the furnishings on eBay. Jamie Drake, for example, was given $10,000 for the living room, and Glenn Gissler received $8,000 for a bathroom, kitchen and hallway. All six spent their entire budget or went slightly over it. The money was deposited into accounts on PayPal, a popular online payment service that eBay bought last year, in part to simplify the transaction process for its customers. The designers were given two months to shop, assemble and install. The results will go online starting Monday at www.ebay.com/showhouse. (The show house will be open in person only to the trade.) The rooms will be viewable in a 360-degree virtual tour until Oct. 23, when the contents will be auctioned, with 80 percent of the proceeds going to Alpha Workshops, a design studio that trains and employs people with H.I.V.
The show house is meant to demonstrate that there is something for everyone on eBay, but it also makes a contrary point: that shopping on eBay is not a simple task for everyone. While the six designers came to the project with varying tastes, what is most evident is their differing skill at using the medium to best effect. 
The most engaging rooms -- with a unified vision and good range of decor -- are clearly those of eBay veterans like Mr. Gissler and Tiffany Dubin. After seeing Marian McEvoy's impressive red dining room, it is no surprise that one seller wrote in the feedback section, "I nominate her for Queen of eBay!"
Ms. McEvoy, the flamboyant former editor of House Beautiful and Elle Decor, staple-gunned the walls with yards of bright red cotton duck, and trimmed them in black silk grosgrain ribbon ( $3 a spool). She dotted the room with fine-art prints, including a Motherwell silkscreen ($857.50), a Matisse lithograph ($340) and a Braque lithograph ($324). Finding a settee and six reproduction French provincial dining chairs ($1,536 for six), she reupholstered them in white cotton duck and festooned them, using a gluegun ($7), with cut-up embroidered suzanis, ceremonial cloths from Uzbekistan.
By contrast, the living room, done in a midcentury style by Mr. Drake, and the children's bedroom, by Laura Bonn, both new to eBay, are filled with new brand-name items, just the kind of thing eBay wants to emphasize. Mr. Drake, for instance, found several good-quality pieces of furniture, some of them local, which helped reduce shipping charges the buyer is obliged to pay. He found an almost-new linen-upholstered armchair by Portico; a pair of newly upholstered curved sofas ($1,275 for the pair); a new modern chandelier by Flos, a trendy Italian maker ($600); and a black chinoiserie secretary ($2,500). 
For the children's room, Ms. Bonn found a selection of good-quality new or newish items, including a winning pair of faux palm trees and a Donghia armchair. Her most inventive touch was a pair of sheer camouflage panels ($91.26) made into a scrim to separate a bed and crib. Ms. Bonn said she was surprised at how much brand-new merchandise she found, though sorting through it "takes a tremendous amount of time."
She said she also found it difficult to judge an object's size. Photographs on eBay rarely show objects with props that reveal their scale. As a result, Ms. Bonn said, she wasted time bidding on objects that were the wrong size. "You need to know what you're doing," she said. "It's not your average sport."
Mr. Drake's and Ms. Bonn's rooms show that it is possible to find new products on eBay, but their rooms lacked the polish and cohesive style of their more eBay-fluent colleagues, none of whom featured new products. Mr. Gissler's sophisticated, masculine hallway and Ms. Dubin's high kitsch sunroom, while wildly divergent in taste, both demonstrated that eBay is a treasure trove for people who are prepared to put on a helmet lamp and descend into the site for serious spelunking. 
"I would say that this project mirrored most of my experience on eBay," Mr. Gissler said. "I'm rarely disappointed, usually satisfied, and occasionally thrilled."
None of the professional designers said they planned to shop for clients on eBay. That comes as no surprise; designers generally rely on the standardized markups on costly furnishings for a portion of their fee, if not all of it. 
Asked what advice she would offer first-timers, Ms. McEvoy said that one should be prepared to enter the bidding with a game spirit. "You have to be ready to take a hit if it's not what you think it is," she said, adding that for her, disappointments had been infrequent. "You have to be willing to work with what you get." 
The eBay site may well win converts with its New York show house, and with the others the company is considering staging in other cities. (The company said it had not yet decided if the New York show house will be an annual event.) 
Still, it remains to be seen whether mainstream shoppers will be willing to give up the reassurance of ordering from stores like Ethan Allen or Pottery Barn, where furnishings can be inspected in person and returned to a known entity. 
Mr. Rus of House & Garden said he was among those who abstain from eBay for that reason, and his innate aversion may speak for the mainstream shopper. "I just don't have the patience for it," he said. "I love to see a thing, touch it. I love the act of shopping, and I am always happy to pay the upcharge for service and seduction."

HEADLINE: Japan to Spend $16.5 Billion to Save Bank 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 12 

 BODY:
The Japanese government announced today that it would spend $25 billion to ease private pain: $8.5 billion to buy bonds issued by corporations and $16.5 billion to all but nationalize one of the nation's largest banks.
 In a country where corporate socialism is often preferred over creative destruction, investors greeted the market interventions with glee. The main stock market average, the Nikkei 225, briefly crossed above 9,000, about 1,000 points above the 21-year lows recorded here two months ago, before receding late in the day. 
 Resona Holdings, the troubled bank that the government is bailing out, was the darling stock of the day, topping all others in Japan in trading volume and rising 18 percent in price on the news that the government would aid the bank financially by buying a two-thirds ownership stake in it. 
More broadly, the Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, said it would buy up to 1 trillion yen ($8.5 billion) in asset-backed securities issued by corporations over the next three years. While the central bank has often bought government debt and otherwise intervened in financial markets, it has never before agreed to buy corporate debt securities. 
The bailout of Resona is an effort to keep the bank, which lends to thousands of small- and medium-size companies in the depressed industrial heartland around Osaka, from running out of capital and slipping into insolvency. The government will spend an amount equivalent to the gross national product of Ecuador.
The government is going ahead even though its own debts have risen to 150 percent of the country's gross domestic product, the highest rate for a major economy. Four years ago, Japan spent $78 billion to save four private banks. It now has just $21 billion worth of securities to show for that investment.
The government rescued Resona because "there was substantial risk of systemic risk to the financial system," an official at the Financial Services Agency, the country's chief regulatory body, told foreign reporters today. How long will the government have to stay involved in Resona? "We don't have any specific plan for when we will sell," the official said.
Some Americans hope that a "second generation" of Japanese bank bailouts, starting with Resona, will be done in a way that cleans up the banking industry. 
"I am especially heartened by the Japanese government's action to preserve the stability of the financial system in the recent case of Resona Bank," Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said Tuesday in New York at a Japan Society dinner. "The accelerated resolution of bad loans will provide a useful model as the Japanese government considers a new framework this summer."
But with Japan's economy showing little or no growth, bank lending in May was down 4.2 percent over last year's levels, the 65th consecutive month of decline. 
The Financial Services Agency has been criticized for contributing to Resona's problems by failing in its watchdog role. Kohei Ohtsuka, a legislator from the opposition Democratic Party of Japan, read in Parliament last week what he said was a six-page agency memo showing that agency officials pressed auditors last month to bend accounting rules to help Resona appear solvent. 
"There was an intense behind-the-scenes struggle over whether or not to reveal Resona's situation," Richard Katz, editor of The Oriental Economist, wrote this month. The June edition of Mr. Katz's newsletter includes a transcript of a telephone conversation that it says took place on May 10 between an agency official and a Resona executive. In it, the regulator assures the banker that Resona need not pay attention to the auditors' concerns about the bank's solvency.
A week later, the bank applied for government aid because its auditors had balked at approving its accounts.
Today in Parliament, Yashuhisa Katsuta, a former president of Resona Holdings, said that the bank's two auditing firms were responsible for the crisis at the bank. Addressing the Japanese people, he said, "I deeply apologize for the fact we will receive massive public money as a result."
In separate testimony before the same parliamentary committee, Kenji Takeyama, president of one of the auditing firms, Shin Nihon & Company, defended his firm's actions and denied that his company had had any improper contacts with the Financial Services Agency.
Mr. Katz said today in a telephone interview from his New York office that each new revelation about the cozy relationship between Resona and the regulatory agency would strengthen the hand of Heizo Takenaka, Japan's top banking regulator, in his efforts to purge the agency of officials accustomed to colluding with banks.
Last month, the four giant Japanese bank groups, excluding Resona, reported combined losses of nearly $31 billion for the fiscal year ended March 31.
Some Americans see opportunity in distress.
"There is obviously going to be tremendous focus on restructuring banks, restructuring insurance companies," said Lee D. Roberts, chairman of the Filenet Corporation of Costa Mesa, Calif. The company designs databases to help companies capture, store and manage information from varying computer systems, a problem facing the Japanese megabanks, which were created through often unhappy marriages of two or three smaller banks. 
"In times like this, we can walk into a major bank and show how to substantially automate back-office processes," Mr. Roberts said in an interview here, explaining why he had chosen this time to expand in Japan. "There is clear desire to get Japanese banking back on track. Five years ago, there was a reluctance to change."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Hope onEconomy Extends Rally, and Dow Tops 9,100

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street extended its rally yesterday as investors shook off a warning from Texas Instruments and sent stocks higher on optimism about the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed above 9,100 for the first time in 11 months.
 "The market momentum here is quite strong," said Steven Goldman, chief market strategist at Weeden & Company in Greenwich, Conn. "When we have a sustainable advance, market horizons tend to expand, with investors willing to look further into the future and shake off bad news." 
 The Dow industrials gained 128.33 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 9,183.22. They have advanced in seven of the last eight sessions for a net gain of 343 points. It was the highest level since July 8, 2002, when the Dow finished at 9,274.90.
The broader market also rose. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 18.35 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,646.02. 
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 12.64 points, or 1.3 percent, to 997.48. It was the highest finish since June 20, 2002, when the index stood at 1,006.29.
Texas Instruments fell $1.53, to $18.86, after it lowered its second-quarter outlook, citing in part sluggish sales caused by fear of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in Asia.
"What's interesting in my opinion is that we've seen pieces of bad news that the markets could have responded to negatively, but unlike the last couple of years, the market isn't responding," said Subodh Kumar, chief investment strategist for CIBC World Markets.
"When a company issued a warning or there was an accounting scandal, it used to tar the market, but now investors are just ascribing it to the individual company and not to the market as a whole," he said.
Stocks have surged in recent weeks on strong first-quarter earnings and hopes of an economic rebound by the end of the year. But with the Dow and S.& P. now trading at levels not seen in nearly a year, some traders say the market is ready for a pullback after moving upward so quickly.
Other analysts, however, say stocks are firmly on an upward path. Since hitting a five-year low of 7,286.27 on Oct. 9, 2002, for example, the Dow has risen about 25 percent.
"I believe we're in a bull market -- one that can carry the averages sustainably higher," said Mr. Goldman, citing in part low interest rates and the end of the war in Iraq.
Lennar, the home builder, surged $5.70, or 8.2 percent, to $75.45, after it said its fiscal second-quarter income rose 51 percent, handily beating analysts' expectations.
Eli Lilly advanced $2.96, to $63.19, after it raised its second-quarter earnings outlook to the upper end of its previous forecast; it also backed its full-year estimates.
I.B.M. rose $2.26, to $83.97, after Merrill Lynch added it to its highly recommended list of stocks.
Freddie Mac fell $1.50, to $50, after federal prosecutors began an investigation into possible misconduct.

Treasury Prices Decline
(By Reuters) -- Treasuries lost steam yesterday after a report on the economy from the Federal Reserve fell short of bond bulls' pessimistic expectations, reducing hopes for a big cut in interest rates.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 6/32, to 103 15/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.22 percent from 3.19 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/32, to 117 30/32. The yield rose to 4.27 percent from 4.25 percent.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
New Rules Expected TodayOn Faster Wi-Fi Equipment

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
The leading standard-setting body for wireless communications equipment is expected to give final approval today to rules for designing gear in the Wi-Fi format that would operate at up to four times the speed of today's most popular Wi-Fi devices.
 Equipment makers and industry analysts expect final approval of the standard to prompt a new wave of investment by computer companies in building and marketing wireless devices that can connect to the Internet whenever they are near a Wi-Fi base station. 
 "Now there will be guaranteed interoperability," said Marc Cetto, the general manager for wireless networking at Texas Instruments, a leading chip maker. 
The new standard, which is being issued by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, is formally known as 802.11(g). The spread of laptop computers and other mobile electronic devices built to that standard will allow hot spots, as the base stations are known, to handle more users without interference or dropped connections. 
The new standard also makes it more practical to download bigger documents or multimedia presentations than today's leading standard, which is formally known as 802.11(b). It also is expected to enhance security for Wi-Fi users.
The new standard represents a compromise among competing proposals and is not the only Wi-Fi standard likely to gain widespread acceptance. Another standard, called 802.11(a) and already in use, is at least as fast and operates at a radio frequency that is less subject to disruption from microwave signals than that used by the (b) and (g) formats. But 802.11(a) operates over a much shorter range -- no more than 75 feet in most cases.
Both 802.11(b) and the new (g) variant can connect to a base station from up to 300 feet away, although performance in offices, airports and other busy environments is best within 150 feet. Moreover, because they operate at the same frequency, devices made to the new standard are expected to be compatible with the millions of 802.11(b) devices already deployed.
Some companies, anticipating today'sapproval, have already been shipping so-called pre-(g) chips and equipment incorporating earlier versions of the standard. In practice, such products have often proved incompatible with pre-(g) devices from other companies, causing them to default to the slower 802.11(b) performance or fail to connect to other devices altogether.
"People made assumptions that didn't pan out," said Stan Schatt, a wireless industry analyst with Forrester Research in San Diego. 
With publication of the final standards, analysts expect chip giants like Texas Instruments and computer makers like Hewlett-Packard, which have held back from the 802.11(g) market, to move rapidly into it. And companies that entered the market early are expected to issue software updates to bring their versions of the standard into line with those published today.
The market for Wi-Fi chips is expected to jump to $559 million this year, from $471 million last year, according to IDC, a market research firm. Kenneth Furer, an IDC analyst in Mountain View, Calif., predicted that 802.11(b) shipments would fall to 50 percent of Wi-Fi chips this year from 94 percent in 2002. By next year, he said, 802.11(g) will become the most popular form of Wi-Fi, but dual-band systems capable of handling both 802.11(g) and (a) will grow more rapidly. By 2007, he said, dual-frequency chips will account for nearly 80 percent of shipments.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new equipment standard, known as 802.11(g), is expected to improve wireless communications and to prompt a wave of investment by computer companies in making and marketing Wi-Fi devices. (Susan Ragan)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Looking beyond free trade as a solution to helping the developing world.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and the journal Indicators, and he also teaches at Cooper Union and New School University. His new book is "Why Economies Grow," from Basic Books. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
SINCE the Iraq war, developed nations like France and the United States seem to be vying to show that they care about the world's poor. The events of Sept. 11, 2001, made us all more aware of the deprived state of citizens around the world. The difficult aftermath of the war has also shown us that overthrowing a dictator is not enough to ensure security, economic opportunity and sustained decency.
 Interestingly, President Bush has taken the lead on these issues at home. His Democratic rivals for president are hardly heard on the subject. Mr. Bush has proposed a free trade region for the Middle East, a number of bilateral trade pacts, a 50 percent increase in international aid and a costly new program to combat AIDS. 
 But with the exception of the AIDS plan, is all this mostly talk? Economic development of Afghanistan seems to be faltering. And Mr. Bush's rationale is disturbingly ideological. "Across the globe, free markets and trade have helped defeat poverty, and taught men and women the habits of liberty," he said last month.
In the last decade, economists have discovered how much more difficult development is than just promoting trade and free markets. Despite the adoption of such policies in the developing world, poverty remains high, inequality at unacceptable levels, and economic growth poor. The Middle East, many agree, seems far from ready for free trade. The amount Mr. Bush plans to devote to nontrade reforms is peanuts.
What do economists know about growth? "At the more practical end of things -- how do we make growth happen? -- things have turned out to be somewhat disappointing," the Harvard economist Dani Rodrik writes in a fine summary of the state of development economics in the forthcoming "Handbook on Economic Growth" (North-Holland). That is an understatement. 
But the danger is to think that nothing has been learned in the last decade, or that the developed world has truly tried hard to help. 
A useful contribution to our understanding has been put together by the Center for Global Development and Foreign Policy magazine. It is an index -- based on a variety of components, not just quantity of aid -- that ranks the contribution developed nations make to the developing world.
Why an index? "A horse race attracts attention," said Nancy Birdsall, the center's president. It also helps broaden thinking about just what contributes to growth.
Even the highest-ranked nation, the Netherlands, scored only 5.6 out of a possible 10. But for the United States, the results are disturbing; second to last out of 21 nations, nosing out Japan.
Even though many factors are used in the index -- some debatable -- the United States, as a basic matter, gives so little to the developing world as a percentage of gross domestic product that its score is brought down significantly. In the days of the Marshall Plan, Ms. Birdsall notes, the United States spent 1 to 2 percent of its G.D.P. on aid. Now it spends 0.1 percent. President Bush says he would like to raise thatfigure to 0.15 percent, but his most recent budget made no allowance for that.
America's score is also reduced by other factors. The index penalizes nations for polluting the world, and America's carbon emissions are the highest of the 21. Surprisingly, our immigration policy is also more restrictive than in most other nations.
But we lead the pack in openness to imports, an urgent issue for many developing nations. European nations are significantly more closed to agricultural imports. Yet even here, our credibility has been hurt by Congress's recent protectionist farm bill, signed by Mr. Bush without a fight.
Although it certainly looks as if Mr. Bush is moving in the right direction, questions arise over his tenacity and whether his commitment to development will essentially be only about free trade. "Free trade agreements are at best only part of the solution," said Robert Z. Lawrence, a Harvard economist. "They must be complemented with other reforms."
What are those reforms? There seem to be two broad lessons to be drawn from recent experience. Perhaps most important, as Mr. Rodrik emphasizes, there is no single set of policies for all countries. Any one-size-fits-all strategy, including the formulaic demands of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the Treasury Department, can hurt more than help. 
In fact, he notes, Latin America came closest to following the precepts of the "Washington consensus," which includes budget discipline, deregulation and the liberalization of trade and finance, but the record has mostly been dismal. East Asian nations like South Korea and Taiwan, not to mention China, followed different, often contradictory paths to success.
The second lesson, closely related to the first, is to tap local strengths while constructing policies. David Ellerman, a consultant to the World Bank, argues that it is important to recognize what existing institutions can work in a nation and not impose rapid-fire Western-style privatization.
As an example, the Bush administration's anger toward the Baath Party in Iraq could backfire because the skilled technical and administrative people needed to rebuild Iraq turn out, inevitably, to have been party members. Most should be incorporated into developing the nation, not banished from it.
Similarly, a locally run regional development bank may now make sense for the Middle East. "Successful reforms are those that package sound economic principles around local capabilities, constraints and opportunities," Mr. Rodrik writes. This is also where liberty and democracy can matter. They are integral to respect for local concerns. 
Development is now clearly about elbow grease, not canned ideas. It is about tenacity and pragmatism, not political values or the export of ways of doing business that are congenial to our own companies. Now is the time to hold the Bush administration and others to their promises, and to broaden our thinking beyond slogans and ideology.

HEADLINE: Mexico Repays Last Bond From Crisis 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 11 

 BODY:
Mexico announced today that it was paying off the last of its $35 billion in Brady bonds, in a symbolic end to the 1980's debt crisis.
 This final series of Brady bonds is worth $1.284 billion and is denominated in European currencies. 
The Finance Ministry said it would use cash raised in recent debt sales to retire the bonds. 
The United States Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, who is visiting Mexico, said that the repayment reflected Mexico's commitment to orthodox fiscal and economic policies. Mexico's "deficit is the envy of most countries," Mr. Snow said during a joint appearance with Francisco Gil Diaz, Mexico's finance minister.
"If you get fiscal and monetary policy right, it pays you dividends because it reduces the markets' concerns about the economy," Mr. Snow said.
In April, Mexico paid off $3.84 billion in dollar-denominated Brady bonds. Brady bonds, named for former Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, were created to help heavily indebted Latin American countries restructure their foreign debts in 1989 and 1990.
Mexico's Finance Ministry said that this final repayment would reduce servicing charges on Mexico's foreign debt by $283 million.

HEADLINE: McGreevey Sees Parking Lots As Vital for 'Smart Growth' 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 11 

 BODY:
State and Essex County officials said today that they had reached an agreement to save and expand a commuter parking lot here, delivering a 500-space installment on Gov. James E. McGreevey's vow to create 20,000 additional spaces statewide over five years.
 The McGreevey administration has made commuter parking a centerpiece of its so-called smart growth policies, which seek to promote mass transit and decrease automobile traffic on state roads. 
 The agreement today expands a lot adjacent to the South Mountain Arena and the Turtle Back Zoo, which now has about 300 overcrowded spaces that were endangered by insurance liability problems. The site will include an expanded, three-level parking structure, to be built for $8 million and open to commuters by next May for a small fee.
The Essex County executive, Joseph N. DiVincenzo, said that safe and economical county operation of the lot, which now serves commuters connecting with express buses into New York City or Newark's Penn Station, had become "impossible" in recent years even as its need increased. There is currently no fee at the lot. In intensive lobbying of Governor McGreevey and his administration over the last six months, he said, he convinced them to help out.
Mr. McGreevey said today that despite the state's $5 billion deficit, it still planned to spend about $2.5 billion on roads, mass transit and commuter parking over the next year.
"We are doing this because we recognize its importance to our quality of life," Mr. McGreevey said at a news conference today. "These must be our first options and not our last options, but adding new mass transit services are meaningless if motorists can't find parking spaces."
In an interview after the news conference, Mr. McGreevey acknowledged that unlike Essex County and West Orange, some communities continued to see such parking structures as more a blight than a benefit. But he insisted that "we are changing the culture" with the extensive statewide debate he was encouraging on "smart growth."
The 500 spaces at the West Orange location are part of a total of nearly 5,800 in 6 counties and 17 municipalities for which the state has already secured funds.

HEADLINE: In a Tax Battle, McGreevey Criticizes Casino Executives 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 11 

 BODY:
Gov. James E. McGreevey today raised the stakes in his showdown with New Jersey's casino industry, unveiling a campaign-style radio ad that accuses "millionaire casino C.E.O.'s" of shirking their responsibility to help the state close its budget gap and forcing homeowners, older residents and middle-class families to pay higher taxes.
 Last month, casino industry officials took to the airwaves to criticize Mr. McGreevey's call for a new casino tax, intended to raise at least $90 million, with radio ads predicting that the tax increase would cost thousands of jobs and scuttle plans for new construction projects in Atlantic City. 
 With negotiations on the issue stalled and the governor trying to close a projected $5 billion budget gap by the end of the legislative session on June 23, the Democrats responded today with their own ad. In it, Mr. McGreevey boasts about his effort to balance the budget without raising the sales and income taxes and chastises the casino industry, which has not had a tax increase in 25 years.
"When the casinos pick a fight with New Jersey's working families, they've chosen the wrong target," he says in the spot. "That's why I'm fighting to put the odds on our side."
The increasingly shrill political battle over casinos is something of an anomaly in New Jersey politics. In the quarter-century since legalized gambling began in Atlantic City, the casino industry has been regulated heavily and taxed moderately but has usually been treated gingerly by elected officials from both parties.
Senator William L. Gormley, a Republican from Atlantic County and the casino industry's strongest supporter, argues that Mr. McGreevey is unwise to vilify the industry because it now employs 50,000 and has become the economic engine of South Jersey.
But other observers, including some Republicans, suggest that casinos are a juicy, and welcome, target for Mr. McGreevey, whose public approval ratings have been hampered by the budget crisis.
"It's a great political opportunity for Jim McGreevey," said Peter J. McDonough, who was communications director for former Gov. Christie Whitman.
"Here's someone who personifies glitz, glamor and greed -- someone like Donald Trump and Steve Wynn -- and he gets to push back against that. The only thing better than that, politically speaking, would be a border war with New York."
When Mr. McGreevey originally proposed $135 million in tax increases on casinos in his budget plan early this year, the financial and political fallout was swift and severe. The stock market value of resort companies operating in Atlantic City fell by more than half a billion dollars the first day and Bally's postponed a major construction project. 
Republicans vowed to kill the tax. And when the McGreevey administration proposed a plan to allow video slot machines at racetracks, the uproar only intensified.
Although the video slot proposal has been dropped bythe McGreevey administration, the casino industry issued its trenchant radio ads, accusing the governor of unfairly trying to balance his budget on the backs of the service workers employed in Atlantic City. 
That high-profile lobbying was a departure for casino executives, who have traditionally enjoyed a laissez-faire relationship with state leaders in Trenton.
During negotiations with legislators and casino industry executives, the governor's office has reportedly dropped its call for a $45 million tax on free rooms, food and entertainment given to high rollers. 
But Mr. McGreevey is said to be reluctant to reduce the proposed tax from $90 million, arguing that New Jersey taxes casinos far less than other states with legalized gambling do.
The narrator whose voice appears in the radio ad with Mr. McGreevey makes that argument even more forcefully, portraying casino executives as corporate fat cats who are reluctant to pay their fair share.
But Mr. Gormley predicts that the radio ad, paid for by the Democratic State Committee, will backfire.
"He's trying to focus on the C.E.O.'s, but it's not the C.E.O.'s," he said. "They can go to another state and invest their money there. It's the waiters and waitresses and plumbers and carpenters. Where are they going to go?"

HEADLINE: Kidnappers in Separatist Georgian Region Free 4 U.N. Workers 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia, June 11 

 BODY:
Four United Nations employees kidnapped last week in a secession-minded region of the country were released by their abductors on Tuesday night and returned here to the capital today.
 The four -- two Germans, a Dane and a Georgian -- spent nearly six days in captivity after being taken at gunpoint last Thursday by a group of unknown men in the Kodori Gorge, a remote area divided between Georgian forces and those loyal to leaders of the breakaway region of Abkhazia. 
The United Nations workers were part of a team that monitors a cease-fire agreement, struck in 1993, between the Georgian government and the Abkhazian leaders. 
After demanding $3 million in ransom, the kidnappers agreed to release the four in exchange for a guarantee that they would be allowed to leave the area without being arrested.
Georgian television showed the hostages, unshaven and dirty, celebrating their release with food and wine in a village before heading to Tbilisi by helicopter.
They offered few comments on their arrival here. Georgian officials said that at least some of the four had been injured during their abduction. No ransom was paid, the officials said.
"They are in shock," Peter Mamradze, deputy state minister for the Georgian government, said shortly after the release.
It was the fourth such kidnapping of United Nations monitors. Each time, they have been released relatively unharmed, and without ransom being paid. In October 2001, a United Nations helicopter was shot down over the Kodori gorge, killing nine people on board. It was not clear who shot the aircraft down.
Members of the American military, who take part in the operation, are not permitted to be based in areas close to the cease-fire line.
While the motivations of the kidnappers in the current case are unclear, Georgian officials said they suspected that the crime might have had a political component. Some said they thought it had been the work of the Russian government, or at least some members of it, who wanted to embarrass Georgian leaders.
Relations between Georgia and Russia have been strained since the two countries emerged from the breakup of the Soviet Union.
In the early 1990's, Abkhazia mounted an effort to secede from Georgia and largely succeeded; the Georgian government accused Russia of intervening on Abkhazia's behalf. Though Abkhazia is not recognized internationally, it has established de facto independence from Georgia.
In recent months Russian leaders have accused Georgia of harboring rebels from the secessionist region of Chechnya, and last September threatened to invade the country if it did not do more to contain them. In the kidnapping that just ended, Georgian officials pointed out, a team of Russian soldiers who were supposed to protect the observers were freed by the kidnappers almost immediately.
The last few months have seen something of a thaw in Russian-Georgian relations. In March, the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, and the Georgian president, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, proposed several joint economic projects, including the establishment of rail service between Russia and the Georgian capital.
Some Georgian officials suggested that elements of the Russian government or military might have used the kidnapping to freeze relations again.

HEADLINE: Fed Says Economy May Be Set to Rebound 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11 

 BODY:
The weak economy, which has suffered thousands of job losses in recent months, may be on the verge of a rebound now that the Iraq war is over, the Federal Reserve said today.
 The Fed said that 4 of its 12 districts -- Dallas, Kansas City, New York and Minneapolis -- detected signs of increased economic activity and no district reported further deterioration since the last report in late April. 
 "The unwinding of war-related concerns appears to have provided some lift to business and consumer confidence, but most reports suggest that the effect has not been dramatic," the central bank said in its latest survey of business conditions. 
The central bank cautioned against reading too much into the scattered signs of a rebound, describing overall activity in many districts as still "sluggish, subpar or subdued."
The survey of business conditions, known as the beige book, will be used by Fed policy makers when they meet on June 24-25 to set interest rates.
Many analysts are convinced that the Fed will reduce rates for a 13th time in this round of cuts in an effort to make sure that the current weak patch the country is experiencing does not deepen into something worse.
The beige book said that consumer spending remained lackluster in May, with retail sales rebounding at the end of the Iraq war but remaining below levels of a year ago. Many analysts say they believe that consumer spending will remain depressed until the unemployment rate turns around.
The jobless rate hit a nine-year high of 6.1 percent in May, the government reported last week, even though the pace of layoffs slowed somewhat.
The Fed's survey detected some improvements in the manufacturing sector, which has suffered 34 consecutive months of job losses. Three districts -- New York, Minneapolis and Cleveland -- reported an increase in manufacturing activity. But three others -- Philadelphia, Richmond and Boston -- indicated further deterioration. The remaining six Fed districts said there had been little change in industrial activity, which they reported remained sluggish.
The survey found that agricultural production was impaired by unusually wet weather in many parts of the country, with rain delaying spring planting in the Atlanta, Chicago, Kansas City, Richmond and St. Louis districts.
Yet, the Fed reported that crop conditions remained too dry in the Dallas district, where farmers delayed planting cotton because of inadequate moisture to germinate the seeds.

HEADLINE: The University of California Names Insider as President 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., June 11 

 BODY:
The University of California Board of Regents today chose an insider, Robert C. Dynes, to be the new president of the nine-campus university system. For the last seven years, Dr. Dynes has been chancellor at the University of California at San Diego.
 Dr. Dynes, 60, a physicist from Canada who once considered a career as a professional hockey player, will succeed Richard C. Atkinson, who announced last fall that he would retire in October 2003. Dr. Dynes will step into what is considered one of the most influential and prestigious jobs in public education. The system, the nation's largest, has 192,000 students and 157,000 faculty and staff members. 
 Officials said Dr. Dynes was chosen from a field of nearly 300 candidates, including chancellors at other University of California campuses and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a top economic official in the Clinton administration who is now dean of the London Business School.
The regents' vote was taken behind closed doors, and the breakdown of the vote was not disclosed. A separate vote on a compensation package for Dr. Dynes, including an annual salary of $395,000, was approved 18 to 1.
"I am overwhelmed, there is no doubt about it," Dr. Dynes told a meeting here of the regents after being welcomed with a standing ovation. In prepared remarks, he added later: "I believe education is the single most important thing we do. In the process we create new knowledge."
Judith Block McLaughlin, chairwoman of the Harvard Seminar for New Presidents, said that educators around the nation would be looking to Dr. Dynes for leadership. "In the same way that Harvard is a bully pulpit for private research universities, the presidency of the University of California system is a bully pulpit for public research universities," she said. 
During his tenure as president, Dr. Atkinson was instrumental in reshaping college admissions across the nation. He encouraged the overhaul of the SAT and was an important player in a national debate over affirmative action.
Dr. Dynes will take over at a time when the University of California faces severe financial problems because of state and federal cutbacks. 
The system is slated for about $300 million in cuts in Gov. Gray Davis's proposed state budget. At the same time, pressure for the system to grow is greater than ever, with a 10th campus under construction in Merced to open next year.
By next year, university officials estimate, enrollment in the system will have grown by 18 percent over three years, while state financing over the same period will have fallen by 6 percent. The system has an annual budget of $13 billion, about $3 billion of which comes from the state.
"There is an enormous amount at stake, and the new president comes in having to hold the line," said David Ward, president of the American Council on Education, a Washington-based lobbying group for the nation's colleges and universities. 
At a news conference, Dr. Dynes said he would be inclined to limit student enrollment if the budget crisis forced choices between quality and size.
"We are under severe budget pressure right now and the one thing I will not compromise is the quality of the university," he said. "If we need to adjust the growth, we will do that until we find the funds."
Dr. Dynes will take his new post as the University of California faces criticism in Congress over its administration of three federal research labs, including the Los Alamos Laboratory in New Mexico, where some employees have been accused of fraud.
For the first time, the Energy Department will seek competing bids to run Los Alamos when the university's current contract ends in September 2005. The university has overseen the lab since it was established during World War II to create an atomic bomb.
Dr. Dynes, who worked for 22 years at AT&T Bell Laboratories before becoming a professor of physics in 1991 at the University of California at San Diego, has a long affiliation with the lab. He is a member of the lab's oversight board, and has served as an adviser and consultant to the physics research and weapons programs.
At a news conference, John G. Davies, the regent who led the search committee for a new president, said Dr. Dynes's knowledge of the national labs was "a very important factor" in his selection. 
Sidney Drell, professor emeritus of physics at Stanford University, who is a member of the Los Alamos oversight committee, said that by choosing Dr. Dynes the regents sent a message that they were serious about correcting problems at the labs.
"He is the one I would have voted for had I been a regent," Professor Drell said. "He knows the background of the labs, and he certainly understands very well the science that is going on."
At the news conference, Dr. Dynes was circumspect about his approach to the labs and other issues he might face, saying it was too early to take positions. He said he would first consult widely.
"One of the things I do know how to do well is listen," Dr. Dynes said. 
Joel Dimsdale, a professor of psychiatry and chairman of the Academic Senate, a faculty body at the University of California at San Diego, said Dr. Dynes had a reputation there of doing just that.
"I look at him as a duck on the water," Professor Dimsdale said. 
Growing up in London, Ontario, Dr. Dynes said he dreamed of becoming a professional athlete. "I was a pretty good hockey player," he said.
He described his decision to attend college as "almost an accident" after he was pressured by his mother, a nursery school teacher, and some high school teachers to give up his hockey dreams. A naturalized United States citizen, he holds a bachelor's degree in mathematics and physics from the University of Western Ontario and master's and doctorate degrees in physics from McMaster University. He immigrated to the United States in 1968.
"I am a first-generation college graduate whose life was transformed by educational opportunity," Dr. Dynes said.
He said there were other benefits of giving up his dream of professional hockey.
"I still have my teeth as well," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 13, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the appointment of a president by the University of California misstated a distinction of the institution. It is the country's largest public research university system; the largest senior university system is California State.

HEADLINE: Word for Word on the Web, Isaac Newton's Secret Musings 

BYLINE:  By PETER DIZIKES 

 BODY:
JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES called them "fascinating" and read them in taxis. Albert Einstein called them "unique treasures." But for roughly 300 years, just a handful of people had ever seen Isaac Newton's voluminous writings on alchemy and theology. Now that is changing, thanks to a group of scholars who are making them available on the Internet. 
 The Newton Project, a joint effort based at the University of London, aims gradually to post all of the scientist's previously unpublished work at a Web site (www.newtonproject.ic.ac.uk), including thousands of pages of alchemical and theological writings and, eventually, someof his optical studies. The material, which may take 15 to 20 years to finish transcribing, will be accompanied by high-resolution images of the manuscripts. 
The enterprise was founded in 1998 by a small group of Newton scholars who had grown tired of seeing the complete writings of other important thinkers published only as expensive multivolume editions that would invariably languish in a few academic libraries.
 "In these projects in the past, you've got scholars who produce very high-quality printed texts for about three people," said Rob Iliffe, a historian at the University of London and a co-founder of the project. "Ordinary people who've funded these things, taxpayers, don't have access." 
 For the Newton Project, said Dr. Iliffe, "My image was of something that would be available to anybody with a computer -- an 8-year-old kid, an intelligent lay reader, a university scholar."
 But Newton is famous for his work in physics and mathematics. Why publish his thoughts about religion or alchemy?
 "Newton did not compartmentalize himself," said Mordechai Feingold, a historian of science at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, Calif., who is an adviser to the project and the curator of an exhibition on Newton's influence that is to open at the New York Public Library next year. "To understand the man himself, we must understand the various facets of his own activities."
 Other Newton scholars, while intrigued, are taking a wait-and-see approach. "The question is how much light it will shed on Newton and the emergence of Newtonian science," said Alan Shapiro, a historian of science at the University of Minnesota. 
 But George E. Smith, a philosopher of science at Tufts University in Medford, Mass., said there was no clear distinction in Newton's time between chemistry and alchemy and that he expected the papers to reveal much about 17th-century science. "He did a huge amount of chemistry," he said. "It's a broad form of investigation characteristic of the time. No one has really worked through those manuscripts in any detail." 
 Newton spent years studying alchemy, using furnaces in his Cambridge rooms to conduct experiments. He wrote thousands of pages in his notebooks about religion but kept his views almost completely secret. Although loyal to the Church of England, he feared that his anti-trinitarian beliefs -- he thought that regarding Christ as God was a sin -- would destroy his career.
 Enhancing the mystery in this side of Newton, the alchemical and theological papers remained in private hands from Newton's death in 1727 until they were sold at a Sotheby's auction in London in 1936. Among the buyers was Keynes, the legendary Cambridge economist and monetary expert, who scooped up the bulk of the alchemical writings chiefly to save them. 
 Keynes then donated his holdings to Kings College, Cambridge, though not before studying Newton in his spare time. "There are stories that Keynes read these things in taxis going from one Treasury meeting to the next," Dr. Iliffe said. 
 Many of Newton's theological writings were purchased from Sotheby's by Abraham Yahuda, an iconoclastic scholar who enlisted the services of Einstein, a close friend, in an effort to resell them. Despite letters from Einstein vouching for the papers' importance, several prominent American universities are said to have declined to acquire the collection, which wound up in a Jerusalem archive. In all, nearly 40 libraries, from Jerusalem to Geneva to Los Angeles, now own portions of Newton's work; bits of it have circulated on microfilm.
 Over all, an estimated 2.7 million words are to be transcribed from Newton's small, right-slanting handwriting on pages littered with crossed-out words, revisions and equations. 
 A zoom tool at the Web site can be used to magnify the scanned images of Newton's original manuscripts, making it easier for users to read them. The site is adding a search engine this year so that readers can find recurring topics in the sprawl of Newton's work. Web publishing also gives the project the ability to incorporate scholarly revisions and commentaries nearly instantly.
 With people perusing the works on the Internet, Dr. Iliffe said, the Newton Project can also receive valuable assistance from around the globe. "People who are interested can write to us and say, 'Look, we've discovered a mistake in your transcriptions,"' he said. "There is a sense in which end-users can become part of the authorial team."
 In the meantime, the project's scholars face new challenges. Their main financing, a five-year British government grant, expires in 2004. Another concern is ensuring that their software does not become obsolete by the time the project is completed. "The one deep problem about electronic scholarship is we don't know how it will be preserved in the long run," Dr. Smith said. The Newton Project's transcriptions are now being coded in XML, but members say they are wary of being derailed by changing standards. For this reason, they are considering an eventual print companion to the site.
 If the Newton Project seems like an unending effort, the team can always draw inspiration from the scientist himself. "Newton never thought anything he did was finished," Dr. Iliffe said. "He was constantly revising his work and he was never satisfied."

GRAPHIC:  Photos: ACCESS -- "My image was of something that would be available to anybody with a computer," said Rob Iliffe, a University of London historian and co-founder of the Newton Project. Its Web site, top left, offers transcriptions and scanned images of little-known Newton manuscripts. (Steve Forrest for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Supporters Object to Efforts To Alter Ground Zero Plan 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
A coalition of civic and planning organizations said yesterday that Daniel Libeskind's plan for the World Trade Center site is in danger of being undermined by business and community groups that have proposed changes to it and by the companies that hold leases to the site.
 But rebuilding officials and others involved in the process disputed the criticisms, saying that they are working together and that few if any decisions will be made without Mr. Libeskind's support. In addition, rebuilding officials said they had all but ruled out some of the proposed changes that are the most worrisome to the planning groups that spoke yesterday. 
 Officials of the group, the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York, said Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who controls the office space at the site, and others were pressuring rebuilding officials to accept changes to the Libeskind plan. 
If carried out, those changes could take the soul out of Mr. Libeskind's plan and undermine the public process that created it, said Robert D. Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association, one of the organizers of the Civic Alliance, which comprises more than 75 civic, labor, business, academic and community groups. 
For example, one of the chief objections voiced yesterday by Civic Alliance officials concerned a proposal by some groups of downtown residents to place the memorial at ground level, rather than 30 feet below ground, as Mr. Libeskind has proposed. The change would allow residents of Battery Park City to cross the site more easily to reach subway lines and commercial and cultural developments.
Kevin Rampe, the interim president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the lead rebuilding agency, said in an interview yesterday that although the memorial setting will be determined by the jury overseeing the memorial design competition, it must be consistent with the Libeskind design.
"It's hard to imagine that any memorial plan that would fill the bathtub area to ground level would be consistent with the Libeskind plan," Mr. Rampe said, referring to the sunken memorial area. "The entire memorial area will not be filled in."
Family members of people killed at the trade center on Sept. 11, 2001, also have expressed their desire to see the Libeskind plan maintained. At a recent meeting with members of the memorial jury, some family members also called on the jurors to closely follow the mission statement and design guidelines that the family members helped to develop, according to a transcript of the session released by the development corporation. The meeting, on May 27, was closed to the public.
The development corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center site, have also agreed that although Mr. Libeskind's design will provide the basis for the development of the site's office buildings, other architects will be hired to do detailed designs of the office buildings and retail space.
According to a memorandum of understanding between the two agencies, which is scheduled to take effect within a few days, those designs will be completed in cooperation with Mr. Silverstein and Westfield America, the shopping center company that holds the lease to retail space at the trade center site. 
That has led to fears among some members of the Civic Alliance that the buildings will not resemble the designs in Mr. Libeskind's signature images, but instead be boxy structures indistinguishable from other downtown office towers. These members also fear that retail space will infringe on what some people call the sacred nature of the memorial site.
Mr. Libeskind said yesterday that that is not the case. "I'm not the only architect who will be working on the entire 16-acre site," he said. "There will be many, many others working in big teams." But his design "will be at the nexus, at the core of the project," he added. "I'll be very involved. I'm not going to be there just as some form of critic." 
Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Silverstein, said he "supports the Libeskind plan." 
"There will necessarily be refinements as the concepts are developed," Mr. Rubenstein said. "But it will be a consensual process among the various agencies, stakeholders, Libeskind and other professionals."
