HEADLINE: The Remains of the Dog 

BYLINE:  By Jay McInerney; Jay McInerney is the author of six novels, including "Bright Lights, Big City," "Brightness Falls" and "Model Behavior." He is working on his seventh.

 BODY:
 THE CURIOUS INCIDENT
OF THE DOG
IN THE NIGHT-TIME
By Mark Haddon.
Illustrated. 226 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $22.95.
 THE difference between literature and its imitations might be defined in any number of ways, but let's be reckless, even elitist, and propose that a literary novel requires new reading skills and teaches them within its pages, while a conventional novel -- whether it is about lawyers or professors or smart single girls -- depends on our ingrained habits of reading and perception, and ultimately confirms them as adequate to our understanding of the world around us. Mark Haddon's stark, funny and original first novel, "The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time," is presented as a detective story. But it eschews most of the furnishings of high-literary enterprise as well as the conventions of genre, disorienting and reorienting the reader to devastating effect.
Fifteen-year-old Christopher Boone of Swindon, England, seems, at first glance, an unpromising narrator for a novel -- a curious hybrid of reliable and unreliable. By his own admission he doesn't like fiction. He is incapable of lying, of understanding metaphor or jokes. He's also incapable of reading any but the most basic of human facial expressions. "Usually people look at you when they're talking to you. I know that they're working out what I'm thinking, but I can't tell what they're thinking. It is like being in a room with a one-way mirror in a spy film." His own range of emotional response is so limited he makes the repressed butler in Kazuo Ishiguro's "Remains of the Day" -- a novel that this one resembles in its elegant economy of means -- seem like Zorba the Greek. 
The book's jacket copy identifies him as an autistic savant, but Christopher tells us all we need to know about his condition without reference to medical terminology -- just as well, since the term "autism" encompasses a variety of symptoms and behavioral problems that are still baffling behavioral scientists. The American Psychiatric Association definition includes "problems with social interaction, verbal and nonverbal communication and a restrictive repertoire of activities and interests." The problems of autism are related to how the brain processes, organizes and retrieves information; Christopher compares his own brain to a computer that is easily overloaded by multitasking. He has a photographic memory and is capable of working out complicated factoring problems in his head but is so overwhelmed by unfamiliar visual or verbal stimuli that sometimes he shuts down, holding his hands over his eyes or his ears while he groans or screams. He abhors physical contact, new environments and the colors yellow and brown. 
Haddon manages to bring us deep inside Christopher's mind and situates us comfortably within his limited, severely logical point of view, to the extent that we begin to question the common sense and the erratic emotionalism of the normal citizens who surround him, as well as our own intuitions and habits of perception.
Christopher's mind is logical and literal in the extreme; early on he suggests that metaphor is a form of lying, pointing out that very few people actually have skeletons in their closets or apples in their eyes. "When I try and make a picture of the phrase in my head it just confuses me because imagining an apple in someone's eye doesn't have anything to do with liking someone a lot and it makes you forget what the person was talking about." Christopher's inability to tell lies is one of the many reasons he has difficulty engaging in, or understanding, normal social intercourse. And his distaste for falsehood is one reason he doesn't like novels, except for murder mysteries, which are essentially puzzles, Sherlock Holmes being his literary hero -- though he has problems with Arthur Conan Doyle, Holmes's creator, who became involved with spiritualism later in life. Christopher's mind is purely scientific.
One of the subtle ironies of the book, given the evolution of the murder mystery detective toward the tough guys of Hammett and Chandler, is that young Christopher is ultimately far more hard-boiled than any gumshoe in previous detective fiction; unlike Sam Spade or Nick Charles, he has no sentimental streak, no underground reservoir of emotional identification with other human beings -- although he is fond of dogs.
When Christopher discovers his neighbor's poodle dead, skewered on a pitchfork, he sets out to solve the mystery and to write a true account of his detective work. In so doing he inadvertently stumbles upon the messy, illogical, emotionally complicated secrets of his parents and their neighbors. And even as he is finally forced to come to some limited accommodation of this knowledge, he makes a kind of plausible case for his own, ostensibly crippled worldview. Perhaps the greatest mystery here is whether Christopher is capable of change -- a question that goes to the heart of certain deeply held convictions about character.
If all this sounds somewhat grim and clinical, it's not. Christopher's skewed perspective and fierce logic make him a superb straight man, if not necessarily a stellar detective. In the course of interrogating one of his neighbors, while waiting impatiently for her to cut the chitchat, he observes: "Mrs. Alexander was doing what is called chatting, where people say things to each other which aren't questions and answers and aren't connected. . . . I tried to do chatting by saying, 'My age is 15 years and 3 months and 3 days.' " His inability to interpret basic social cues results in great moments of deadpan comedy, with strangers as well as with his patient, long-suffering father. 
MIDWAY through the book, Christopher's quest for the dog's murderer becomes a search for his mother, who his father has told him is dead. His solo journey from Swindon to London is, for him, a terrifying leap into the unknown, as suspenseful and harrowing as anything in Conan Doyle. He literally sees everything around him and is unable to edit the onslaught of sensory data in a new environment. And he is afraid of strangers and ill equipped to ask for their help. 
Christopher's book seemingly has a nice tidy ending, as he would have wished -- horrified as he is of indeterminacy. But this tidiness is an illusion, as the gulf between Christopher and his parents, between Christopher and the rest of us, remains immense and mysterious. And that gulf is ultimately the source of this novel's haunting impact. Christopher Boone is an unsolved mystery -- but he is certainly one of the strangest and most convincing characters in recent fiction.

HEADLINE: The Woman Who Kept the Secrets 

BYLINE:  By Sara Mosle; Sara Mosle is working on a book about East Texas in the 1930's.

 BODY:
 LIARS AND SAINTS
By Maile Meloy.
260 pp. New York:
Scribner. $24.
 Every once in a while a book comes along that upends popular notions of American fiction. There is the literature of family dysfunction, often put forward by disgruntled writers who, plumbing their own histories, take revenge on their parents in "Mommie Dearest" style (the more disastrous the breakdown, the better the potential for promotion and sales). There is regional literature, frequently praised, in a kind of backhanded compliment, for its parochial strengths by urban critics who find everyday life in some remote part of the world -- a farm, say, in Nebraska -- exotic and (briefly) interesting. There is the social novel about current events -- "ripped from the headlines," as the promos for "Law & Order" like to say -- which is at times satirical, studded with references to brand names, from Prozac to Prada, that act as a shorthand for character and class. And there is the historical novel, which escapes all that by going back in time, often combining the virtues of regional and social literature in one hefty volume. 
"Liars and Saints," Maile Meloy's spectacular first novel, is at once all of these literatures and none of them. The book follows the Santerres, a French Canadian and American family that settles in Southern California during World War II, through four generations as they crisscross the continent and globe for the next half-century. Propelling them, in part, are the tragic ramifications of a family secret: the beautiful and beguiling Yvette, the matriarch and a devout Roman Catholic, tries to conceal the unwanted pregnancy of her teenage daughter Margot by sending her to France for a supposed "year abroad" with distant relatives. Yvette feigns pregnancy and provokes a fight with her equally religious husband, Teddy, over whether to abort the unexpected child; she then flees in apparent distress to a convent, where she can continue the phantom pregnancy unobserved. Once Margot's baby is due, Yvette flies to France and "delivers" a baby boy. Yvette's other daughter, Clarissa, and Teddy are none the wiser. The boy, Jamie, is ignored by Margot, who craves a return to normality, and he is raised as Yvette's son.
In the hands of a lesser writer, this might have deteriorated into a melodramatic tale of family dysfunction. There is, after all -- in addition to the pregnancy, at the hands of a predatory dancing instructor -- a hippie Jesuit priest who smokes pot with his junior high school charge, an uncle (or so it seems) who impregnates his niece, Yvette's regrettable handling of her teenage son's sexuality (which sends him spiraling out of control for the next two decades) and another father, so consumed by his political career that he notices only after the fact that "his 20-year-old daughter was having a fatherless baby, and was letting cancer go untreated, and had become a fervent Catholic, and his ex-wife was sleeping with a woman who made wedding cakes."
Meloy, however, is too fond of her characters to subscribe to Philip Larkin's view about what mums and dads do. As one family member remarks, "each choice," at the time, "had seemed like the only one possible." That's not to say Meloy doesn't recognize the Santerres' various weaknesses and failures, but she tends to view them with wry humor rather than satirical condescension, noting affectionately of one character that "he could be counted on to do absolutely the wrong thing," as if his dependability were a virtue. Indeed, it's a testament to Meloy's powers of storytelling that by the book's end, the entire family regards the mother, unsentimentally, as a saint, the Jesuit has emerged as a minor hero, and the dance instructor, while not exactly reformed, has been resurrected in a narrative miracle worthy of Easter. 
Much of the novel is set in the West, as were the stories in Meloy's first collection, "Half in Love" (2002), which got her pegged, initially, as something of a regional writer. But in that stunning debut, Meloy already showed an uncanny ability to depict cosmopolitan cities as well as rural communities and different historical periods, conjuring up a no-nonsense ranch girl in Montana, a pampered Parisian aristocrat and a troubled gay diplomat in Saudi Arabia with equal economy and aplomb. Still, her writing follows what E. B. White once called "the neighborhood pattern." He was referring to New York and its collection of small towns, each a few blocks long, in which residents, loyal to their particular neighborhood, conduct the majority of their daily lives. White's comment was meant to defend the city from small-town charges that its teeming hordes are overwhelming and unfriendly. But it perhaps took a farmer from rural Maine, as White was at the time he wrote his essay, to notice that the converse is also true: that a small town is as bustling and socially complicated as any street corner in Manhattan. 
Meloy's genius is to recognize that we all live our lives within a few mental blocks, with our own set of "Winstons five doors down," as the Santerres' neighbors are forever being called, even long after they've moved away. In "Liars and Saints," her characters settle in, among other perfectly rendered places, free-love Hawaii in the 1970's, the Louisiana of rich Southern belles and bohemian Seattle, but the real landscape of the book is the geography of family, with its intimate connections and concerns, no matter how far the Santerres may stray from home. With each successive generation, the family secret gets concealed and takes on new forms, abiding by an underlying logic, like a few city blocks being continually rebuilt over the same grid system. 
The only person Meloy doesn't locate in this context is herself. With admirable restraint, she tells us virtually nothing about her background on this novel's dust jacket. We don't know if she's writing "what she knows." But her command of human nature is such that she writes with authority whether the setting is, however fleetingly, a Navy aircraft carrier, a biology lab or inside an R.V. in New Mexico. Indeed, the book is notable for its lack of place or brand names. Very occasionally, Meloy will mention a political event or a pop song in passing, but history enters her characters' lives not with a capital "H" but in small-letter ways. A daughter forever associates John F. Kennedy's assassination with her husband's sudden change of careers (which, in time, leads to their divorce); a child asks about the lyrics to an Eagles song. But what makes these moments memorable, and roots them in time, are the individuals involved. We don't hear about the feminist or gay rights movements. Instead, as time unfolds, a previously heterosexual daughter begins to date a woman, and a homosexual couple, "Bill and Bill," turn up next door. The family adapts -- or doesn't. 
If this weren't enough, Meloy accomplishes the above -- all these literatures -- not in some sprawling historical novel but in a breathtakingly spare 260 pages. She can telegraph years in a few sentences or lines of dialogue with aching specificity. Here is how she condenses Teddy's return from the Korean War, as seen by his perplexed younger daughter, into a single paragraph: "He didn't dance anyone around the house anymore, and he talked about moving the family away. When he found them coming back from the beach with their mother, all sandy in their swimsuits and squinting in the sun, he seemed angry. He'd say the weather was too good in California, and their lives were too easy, and they should see how the rest of the world lived. They were all rotting from the inside, he said. Clarissa kept her distance from him then."
MELOY is particularly good at teasing out the inner lives of children, and when a precocious kindergartner tries to work out an understanding of religion in our multicultural times, Meloy touches on many of the book's larger themes. "The kids at school -- except Gurpreet, who was Hindu, and Leyla, whose father was Muslim, and Allen, whose mother had been a Rajneeshee in Oregon and didn't like to talk about it -- said that Jesus was the Son of God. They agreed that you went to heaven when you died, and that Santa was real, but the Easter Bunny and the Tooth Fairy were parents. There were a few dissenters about Santa, but they had been mostly silenced. T. J.'s father, when T. J. asked which one was right, and who was real, said that different people believed different things, and that he could choose to believe whatever he wanted. This was not a satisfying answer at all."
Meloy never supplies a definitive answer, but her novel explores religion and faith from nearly every possible angle, with equal empathy for the faithful and doubting alike. In this sense, her book remains agnostic, but you can't help hoping that if God does exist, he -- or she -- looks down on us all with Meloy's generous gaze.

LENGTH: 1047 words

PERSON: Armando Falcon Jr. 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
In the Shadow of Freddie Mac

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FROM his office, which is a block away from the White House, Armando Falcon Jr. regulates two gigantic home mortgage companies that are vital to the economy. Yet few people have ever heard of him or his tiny agency.
 And that might be just fine, except for the bolt of bad news that hit last week, when one of those giants, Freddie Mac, a pillar of the multibillion-dollar mortgage securities market, announced the departure of the three top executives amid an investigation into possible accounting irregularities. Because Mr. Falcon's agency, the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, was not the first to blow the whistle on the accounting practices, it has come under scrutiny from Congress. 
 Last Monday, Freddie Mac's board unexpectedly said that it had fired the company's president, David W. Glenn, and accepted the resignations of its chairman and chief executive, Leland C. Brendsel, and its chief financial officer, Vaughn A. Clarke. The departures came just five days after investigators said they found that Mr. Glenn had altered and removed diary entries he made at company meetings. Freddie Mac said the alterations were unrelated to accounting records. The company had announced in January that it would have to restate earnings for 2002, 2001 and perhaps 2000.
The disclosures galvanized legislators from both parties to call for hearings to examine possible wrongdoing not only at Freddie Mac, but also to scrutinize Mr. Falcon's embattled agency, which critics said had coddled Freddie Mac and its larger counterpart, Fannie Mae.
The low-key Mr. Falcon, a former House banking committee staff member appointed to his post by President Bill Clinton, said in an interview in his office last week that his agency had done its job, and that the oversight process had worked.
"Our job is not to run the company," Mr. Falcon, a native of San Antonio, said in an interview in his office overlooking the Old Executive Office Building, "but to make sure it is safe and sound."
Mr. Falcon, who has a law degree from the University of Texas and a master's degree in publicpolicy from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, acknowledged that there was still room for new revelations about Freddie Mac's financial practices. He said his agency had been closely involved since differences cropped up between Freddie Mac's former auditor, Arthur Andersen, and its replacement, PricewaterhouseCoopers, over how hedging transactions were booked.
The current crisis began to unfold on June 4 -- Mr. Falcon's 43rd birthday -- when he learned that there were problems with cooperation in the board's internal investigation of the accounting problem.
"The board informed us as soon as it was done," he said, referring to the executive changes on Friday, June 6, which directors approved last Sunday and made public on Monday. Mr. Falcon said that he met with James R. Doty, a lawyer conducting the internal investigation, on June 7, and "we appointed our team of six people, and started work on Sunday."
The examiners and other specialists are looking into deficiencies in accounting practices and controls, and any possible employee misconduct, he said. It expects to make public its findings within 90 days.
Mr. Falcon -- who, as a Clinton appointee, is scheduled to be replaced with a Bush administration candidate -- could be gone by that time, with the agency's troubles landing squarely in the lap of his successor, Mark C. Brickell, a former managing director at J. P. Morgan Securities and the chief executive of Blackbird Holdings, which ran an electronic exchange for derivatives contracts.
Before being appointed to oversee Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, Mr. Falcon spent eight years working for Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, who was then the chairman of the House Banking Committee. After rising to general counsel of the committee, Mr. Falcon left in 1997 to run against Mr. Gonzalez's son, Charlie, in the Democratic primary for a House seat representing San Antonio. Mr. Falcon lost.
In 1999, he settled in as the director of the agency overseeing the mortgage giants, only to find that he might have walked into the ultimate no-win job. On one side, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as government-sponsored mortgage lenders, have enough political influence to resist oversight. Pushing back from the other side is the private mortgage industry, which would like to crimp the two companies' rapid growth.
Squeezed in the middle, Mr. Falcon said he focused on building up his 140-member staff by adding more examiners and other specialists, and by increasing its budget, to $32 million from $16 million.
But the shake-up at Freddie Mac last week blasted long-simmering concerns about the regulator to the surface. William Michael House, the executive director of FM Watch, a group of seven mortgage associations, accused Mr. Falcon's agency of being "more of a cheerleader than a regulator."
The agency was established in 1992 to guard against a recurrence of the excesses that had led to the savings-and-loan debacle of the 1980's. But the agency's oversight is split, with the Department of Housing and Urban Development watching over some of Freddie Mac's work.
From the time it was created in 1992, Mr. Falcon's agency had trouble fulfilling its key mission of devising a "stress test" to measure the companies' capital adequacy in worst-case situations. Mr. Falcon, who blamed a lack of financial support from Congress for the time required to do the job, got the mechanism in place in 2001.
But that has not quelled his critics. Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana, who heads the subcommittee that oversees Freddie Mac, said Mr. Falcon's office was not equipped to handle "the extremely complex and expanding universe" of the mortgage providers. Mr. Falcon's supporters say that blaming his office is unfair, because even Mr. Baker had declared publicly that "I've said repeatedly that Fannie and Freddie are managed well."
When the White House cut a year off his five-year term in February, Mr. Falcon decided not to fight it and agreed to resign. Because his wife, Rosemary, works in Mount Vernon, Va., and the couple have two girls 8 and 13, in school, he said he would stay in Washington and work on public policy.

HEADLINE: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION 

BYLINE:  By Sherie Posesorski 

 BODY:
 TURNING THE WHEEL
Essays on Buddhism and Writing.
By Charles Johnson.
Scribner, $23.
 Since adolescence Charles Johnson has been haunted by the plangent question posed in 1926 by W. E. B. Du Bois: "What we do want? What is the thing we are after?" He sees his work as a writer of philosophical fiction and nonfiction, and as a teacher,as well as his decision to practice Buddhism, as his response -- a "lifelong meditation on what it means to be free." The central leitmotifs of the lucid, fervently reasoned essays collected in "Turning the Wheel" are "enlightenment and liberation." In Johnson's essays on Buddhism, he illuminates its beliefs and observances and their formative influence on his life and writing. He then argues that Buddhist principles underlay the civil rights movement -- Du Bois's struggle for the "complete advancement of black Americans, spiritual as well as political, cultural as well as economic" and Martin Luther King Jr.'s leadership and "dream of the 'beloved community.' " Through the purview of Buddhist philosophy, Johnson provides nuanced appreciations of Jean Toomer and Ralph Ellison. In the concluding autobiographical essays, Johnson affectionately recalls family members and his teacher and mentor, John Gardner, who opened "Dharma doors" that transformed his life into an "adventure of learning and growth and service." Sherie Posesorski

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 15, 2003
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 7263 words

HEADLINE: Going for Broke 

BYLINE:  By Jennifer Senior; Jennifer Senior is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
George E. Pataki has often professed his commitment to the education of each and every child in New York. But Dan Klores, a well-known public relations guru, never realized just how literally the governor took this pledge until one Friday morning some 18 months ago.
 "Dan?" His wife popped her head in their bedroom door. "Governor Pataki's on the phone." 
 Governor Pataki? Not only had Klores never spoken with the governor, but he had just begun helping to formulate a campaign strategy for Andrew Cuomo, one of Pataki's potential rivals in the coming fall election. 
He picked up the phone.
"And it was him, not someone making the call for him," Klores marvels. "And he said -- you could almost tell he had a script in front of him -- 'I hear you're trying to get your son Jake into Temple Emanu-El nursery school. Would you mind if I made a call to help you?' "
Klores had no idea what to say. The governor added, "I hear you're a great guy but politically misguided.' " That made Klores laugh. "Of course I wouldn't mind," he said. "But Governor, you have to understand: Andrew Cuomo is one of my best friends. If you make this call, I'm still going to do everything I can to get him elected. But I'll tell you what: I'm going to vote for you.' "
The governor also laughed, told him fine and hung up. "It was such a brilliant move," Klores says. "I ran into him a couple of months later at a Knicks game. And I told him, 'No matter what happens during this campaign, I will never go negative on you.' And I didn't."
I point out that many interest groups the governor wooed last fall -- like the New York City teachers' union, for which he worked to provide a historically large raise, or the health care workers' union, for which he worked to secure an unusually large contract -- probably felt similarly indebted on Election Day.
"Yeah, well, I guess those days are over," Klores says. "Until he runs again for something."
Last fall, George Pataki was soliciting the Democratic vote with spirited promiscuity, pushing a women's wellness bill through the Legislature, promising a popular bill on gay rights and spending money like a sugar daddy. By Nov. 4, the Republican governor had landed the endorsement of a raft of traditionally Democratic interest groups. On Election Day, he won with margins wide enough to plow.
This spring, however, was the end of Pataki's bartering season. Faced with an $11.5 billion deficit and no new revenue streams in sight, he dug in his heels and declared he would not contemplate raising taxes. He said it was a matter of philosophical principle; the members of New York State Legislature, galled that his principles were finally making an appearance after slumbering all autumn, flew into open revolt.
The Democratic Assembly and Republican Senate joined together and passed a budget that raised taxes. When the governor vetoed it on May 14, they overrode him within 24 hours. A recent poll places the governor's approval rating at an all-time low of 37 percent, and the members of his Legislature are freely venting their disgust. "I have never," says Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican leader of the New York State Senate and Pataki's habitual ally, "been this far apart from the governor."
Of course, it isn't unusual, at this bleak moment in the economy, for governors to find themselves so angrily pushed to the sidelines. It's the sort of thing that happens when states go broke and the federal government declines to bail them out. In late April, I asked Mike Huckabee, the governor of Arkansas, whether any governors were currently enjoying their jobs. He thought for a moment. "Well," he finally answered, "if they are, they're keeping it to themselves, because we'd all club them with large bats."
It is, however, highly unusual for George Pataki to be the object of seething resentment. This is a man who spent the great bulk of his tenure without generating much public feeling of any kind at all -- evading the spotlight, speaking in bumper stickers, blending like tofu into his surroundings. Yet today, only a small fraction of the electorate still trusts him. New York City residents are convinced he's trying to bleed them dry, voters upstate and in the suburbs are convinced he's trying to starve their schools, the unions that supported him in October were picketing him by April and state conservatives -- well, they gave up on the governor ages ago, fed up with his willingness to spend his way into voters' good graces.
Ordinarily, in times of crisis, politicians rely on their core supporters. But the economic downturn exposed the basic paradox of George Pataki, which Mario Cuomo and two subsequent challengers could not: he has no natural base. Like other Republicans who have tried to subdue a strongly Democratic state, he has been living in a tremulous state of equipoise, as if perched on top of a bowling ball. "Liberals are always grumbling because he's insufficiently liberal, and conservatives are always grumbling because Pataki's selling out," says Stephen Moore, president of Club for Growth, an influential Washington-based conservative group. "So he's an orphan, sort of. He's been liked. But not loved."
In fact, the last significant Republican to hold three consecutive statewide terms was Pataki's patron, the former senator Alfonse D'Amato, who was swept into office during the 1980 Reagan revolution, just as Pataki was swept in during the Gingrich revolution of 1994. And D'Amato managed to stay in office much the same way: by gamely wheeling and dealing with Democrats and running against a string of weak opponents. When Charles Schumer, a bright, scrappy Democratic congressman from Brooklyn, came along, D'Amato's string of good luck ran out. Moore wonders if this budget crisis might serve the same function for Pataki -- foreclosing any future in elected office and sending him out on a very low note. "In retrospect," he says, "the governor might have been better off not running for a third term at all."
Pataki dismisses such sentiments as alarmist, shortsighted. History, he insists, will show that he provided the real leadership during this difficult time while the Legislature faltered.
"I don't mean to be a psychoanalyst here," he said as he swirled ice cubes into a beer at a New York City pub a few weeks ago, "but I think one of the reasons the Legislature is angry is because they understand they did the wrong thing. You have to blame somebody for having done that."
I asked if it was possible that he, too, made some tactical errors.
"No."
None? 
"You can't go through anything, whether it's a campaign or a day, where you'd say, 'I wouldn't change a thing.' "
So what would he redo?
"I'd have continued to present the same budget. I'd have fought the fight."
Which in fact sounds a great deal like "I wouldn't change a thing." Despite the fact that he lost that fight and all his Senate allies in the process, he said he has only one regret: "The result."
Pataki has been down this road before. Whenever he has enraged his colleagues -- truly enraged them -- it has been part of a careful calculation, and it has paid off in some finer career dividend. In 1992, for example, when he was still a member of the New York State Assembly, he shocked everyone in Albany by challenging Mary B. Goodhue, his 70-year-old friend and mentor, who also happened to be the only female Republican in the Senate. But he won. The following year, Pataki grandly protested the excesses of the budget that the Legislature had forged with Mario Cuomo. His colleagues wheedled, cajoled, even held a marathon closed-door conference to try to change his mind, and he spent the rest of the year in tense estrangement. But then he converted this act of defiance into a gubernatorial platform. And again, he won.
Today, many in Washington and Albany say that Pataki has made a similar calculation. Though he publicly claims not to be bored with his job, privately he refers to himself as a lame duck. "Last year, I didn't even think he was going to run again," says Peter Vallone, the former speaker of the New York City Council. "Because every time I saw him in Albany, he wasn't happy. He was always totally frustrated with the lack of give on both sides of the aisle."
At this point, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle would be perfectly delighted to see the governor go. In fact the members of his own party would be happiest of all. Poke a Republican state senator, almost any at all, and a vat of bile comes rushing out. After passing so many left-leaning bills on his behalf, they can hardly believe the extreme conservatism of the budget they were asked to pass -- which forced them into the arms of the Democrats all over again.
"Hey, it wasn't like he was well loved when he was in the State Senate," says Tom Reynolds, a Republican congressman and a confidant of Pataki's. "By the end, he had two choices: either run for governor, or run his farm in Peekskill." It was up or out, in other words. Which seems to be the situation he's in today. 
"The most frequent barroom and hallway explanation I've heard in Albany is that he's running for vice president," says Randi Weingarten, president of the union representing New York City public-school teachers. 
"What he wants," Moore declares, "is to be president. I briefly worked for him in 1999, as an economic adviser, when he was considering running back then."
Looked at a certain way, Pataki has a better shot at the presidency than any New Yorker ought to. Though the state has produced some vivid political personalities in recent years -- Ed Koch, Alfonse D'Amato, Mario Cuomo, the late Daniel Patrick Moynihan -- their appeal beyond the Hudson River was always uncertain; they were too vainglorious, or too highbrow, or too crazy, or bullying, or brusque, or (at any rate, in every case) too conspicuously New York. Pataki, on the other hand, is a soothing and homogenized factory product, as lab-created and test-marketed as Kraft Singles. He's the first politician to reflect the new suburban-and-upstate power base of the state, whose composition more closely resembles that of the national electorate. "George Pataki's style seems more like a Midwestern governor's," Rudolph Giuliani says. "You could see him running Ohio or Illinois. But maybe that's really good, because it sort of ties us to the rest of the country."
For most Republicans in the rest of the country, however -- especially those in Washington -- the idea of a Catholic, pro-choice, pro-gay-rights, pro-gun-control candidate with a history of cozying up to unions is utterly risible. Pataki has made a career of defying expectations -- in Peekskill, the State Senate and the Governor's Mansion, and perhaps he thinks he can do it again. But this time, he would be playing on an incomparably larger field, with much longer odds and very different rules.
So New York could be the end of the political road for Pataki. And if the economy doesn't improve, and if he continues to fight with his own Legislature, the man who had so shrewdly timed his risks could exit political life an outcast. Too conservative for liberals, too liberal for conservatives. Overqualified for all the dull cabinet positions in the Bush administration, underqualified for all the good ones. Too Nebraska for New York, too New York for Nebraska.
That would be a sad ending to his story -- not unlike the ending Mario Cuomo had, when he left office in a plume of high deficits and thwarted ambitions. And it's not unlike the ending Giuliani was headed for, had Sept. 11 not violently rewritten his final act. 
"La familia Pena-Herrera sufrio una tragedia. . . . "
Sitting in the back of his car, unfurling a leg so long it creeps between the two front seats, Pataki is testing out his speech on Mel Cartright, his designated state trooper and unofficial Spanish tutor. The content of the speech -- stricter penalties for drunken drivers -- is unobjectionable, but its timing might raise eyebrows: it's April 11. He and his legislators are at a hostile impasse, and he is now 130 miles south of Albany.
"How bad was that?"
"Es tra-GE-di-a," Cartright says, correcting his emphasis.
"Ah. Trah-HAY-di-as. Si." Tragedy.
When Mario Cuomo was doing battle with the Legislature, he'd be in his office early, making phone calls, convening meetings, hounding aides. ("Mario wasn't happy unless he had his green eye shade on and his quill pen out," says Martin Connor, a Democratic state senator.) The same cannot be said of Pataki, who has long kept the Legislature at arm's length. When he first took over the governor's suites in 1995, he installed a desk with a state trooper at the entrance, which made it difficult for legislators to pop in. He does not live in the Governor's Mansion; when he spends evenings there, he seldom has members over. The governor's staff has sometimes spoken about the members of the Legislature as if they were a bunch of fractious parochial-school adolescents (which may not be entirely unfair), and today he barely has a functioning legislative-liaison office. 
"Y Borrrr-ACH-o," Cartright continues. Drunk.
"Bo-RACH-o," Pataki says.
Of course, there's a reason Pataki lurches into campaign mode when things get tough in legislative chambers: he's great at it. On television, his speeches (at least until recently) were positively narcotizing. But television misses the more tactile, interactive parts of these gatherings. He lingers on handshakes, makes easygoing chitchat; with his long arms, he seems genetically engineered to hug. In person he is warm, funny, charismatic. Ask what part of his job he likes most, and he answers: "Being with people. Ordinary people."
What about Albany? Is there anything about the process of passing laws he has grown to love? The governor stares. "I'm not a big process person," he says, after a second of deadpan silence. "I like to envision where you want to get to, and try to figure out how to get there."
Delivering uninspired oratory but relaxing everyone in his path, thinking in broad strokes but allowing others to follow through on the details -- those traits sound an awful lot like those of another Republican executive, in a capital one shuttle ride away. "Both George Bush and George Pataki are approachable, friendly, underestimated by consiglieres," says Karl Rove, the president's senior political adviser. "They're both loyal and not knee-jerk partisans. They both talk about what they're for, rather than tearing someone else down."
They've also each courted the Latino vote. The governor made a smart move when he decided to learn Spanish a few years ago. But it suited his temperament, too, allowing him to mingle with more constituents. He has also picked up French, German and Hungarian. "Les langues m'interesser tres!" he declares. Languages to interest me very!
Pataki's communications director, Lisa Dewald Stoll, looks up from her papers, vaguely concerned. "I have no idea what you're saying."
"I just came out for a massive income tax increase in French."
She gives her eyes an extravagant roll.
Pataki may be able to speak five languages, but throughout his tenure people have doubted that they really understood him -- or what he believed in. Back in February, at a specially-convened dinner in a supporter's Manhattan town house, the governor told the select crowd that they were going to see "the real George Pataki" emerge in this, his third term. It was an attempt to reassure them that he shared their views, but it seemed more like an admission that he had previously said whatever was necessary to get himself elected.
That's how it looks to a great many others too. "He has no discernible ideology in any direction," says Tom Carroll, head of the now-defunct Change-New York, representing the disgruntled right. 
"What the governor has done is whatever is popular at the moment," says Mario Cuomo, representing the disgruntled (and defeated) left.
"It could be that when he first ran, he ran right, and that when he ran this last time, he drifted left," says Randi Weingarten, who isn't so much disgruntled as confused -- Pataki worked to provide large pay raises for the members of her teachers' union before the election, then issued a budget that called for about $1.24 billion in education cuts. "Or it could be that he believes in these things. At this point, I don't know which theory is right."
Pataki will at least admit to one flip-flop overthe course of his eight-and-a-half-year tenure. In his first State of the State address in 1995, he flatly declared he wouldn't run for a third term, because he said he believed in term limits. ("I now know better than to make flat statements," he says.) But few things make the ordinarily sunny governor more prickly than questions about his ideological moorings. "I think in the first term the real George Pataki came through, and in the second one the real George Pataki came through, and in the third term, again, people will see the real George Pataki," he says, his voice tinged with irritation, as he stabs a forkful of salmon at the Governor's Mansion in late April. "Everything has been consistent. I've always gone out of my way to be as real as I can."
And so he may have done. But getting there has taken him along a tortuous path of extremely well timed pirouettes. While still a member of the State Legislature, for example, Pataki railed against big budgets, voted against clinic-access bills and Medicaid financing for abortion, opposed anti-discrimination laws for gay men and women and advocated the death penalty -- an argument he made a central plank in his 1994 gubernatorial campaign. Then he won that campaign. And by the beginning of his second term, he'd signed a clinic-access bill and was authorizing budgets with Medicaid financing for abortions. He reinstated the death penalty, but layered it with so many restrictions that the state has yet to execute a single prisoner. And though he diligently trimmed spending and lowered taxes his first two years, he started spending lavishly once the bull market plumped up the state treasury. "He went bananas, like a friend who goes off and starts drinking again," says Richard Gilder, former chairman of the conservative Manhattan Institute. "Though I do think his heart is in the right place."
The philosophy of any public official, of course, is allowed to evolve. But on a few notable occasions, Pataki has evolved at campaign time, or when his back was pressed against the wall. When Pataki first entered the State Capitol in 1995, for example, he showed little interest in dealing with Dennis Rivera, the savvy head of 1199/S.E.I.U., the health care workers' union. Then the union started running television ads against Pataki's Medicaid spending cuts. "He basically called me out of the blue," Rivera recalls. "And he said: 'I don't want to fight you anymore. I'd like to meet you.' So we met over wine." The union remained neutral in the 1998 election. Last year, facing historic deficits but also an election, Pataki supported a large wage increase for the union. It formally endorsed him.
Pataki has an almost identical history with Empire State Pride Agenda, New York's most influential gay-and-lesbian organization. Right before his re-election campaign in 1998, the group started hammering away at him for cutting one of its favorite programs. He agreed to restore it partly, and the group held its tongue. By 2000, he'd signed a hate crimes bill, and in October 2002, just days before the election, he moved on an anti-discrimination bill. The group endorsed him. 
People who try to divine the ideology behind the governor's pirouettes miss the point. It's pragmatism that has guided most of Pataki's political decisions. In fact, pragmatism has been the survival tactic for Republicans in this state for quite some time -- D'Amato was so good at it that many Democrats preferred doing business with him than with their fellow Democrat Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Until now it has served both New York and the governor well. But what happens when the desires of his constituents are at odds with the needs of his career? 
Back in September, Bruno publicly warned that the deficit for the following year would probably be around $10 billion. The governor responded he had no idea where Bruno was getting his numbers. Which is not the same, it should be noted, as saying that Bruno was wrong. The senate majority leader subsequently mentioned to him -- in private this time -- that Pataki should find some way to add extra revenues to the budget before the election, in order to stave off a fiscal disaster. "But he was preoccupied with what was going on in his life," Bruno says, "which was getting re-elected."
Pataki insists he still didn't know about the $11.5 billion deficit -- "I thought it was going to be significantly lower," he says. The Senate Republicans, at any rate, are having none of it. Last month, Bruno stopped just short of calling him a liar. The rest of the Republican senators stop just short of declaring they've been burned at the altar of the governor's ambitions. 
Michael Bloomberg, the mayor of New York City, has never let slip a stray word about the governor. And Pataki has been a forceful presence in the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, setting a firm timetable and committing the governor's office to be a tenant of Daniel Libeskind's new building. But the financial support Bloomberg got from him since Sept. 11 has clearly been less than the mayor expected. During Pataki's re-election campaign, Bloomberg gave him at least two fund-raisers, one at $15,000 a plate, and did him the favor of keeping mum about the commuter tax that City Hall was so urgently counting on. Prominent New York Democrats told the mayor the campaign was the perfect time to get the governor on record about just how much he'd help the city. But Bloomberg chose not to pursue such a crass prenuptial agreement. Then, in late summer, he discovered a series of ads on radio and television from the Pataki campaign opposing the commuter tax. Still desperate to close the $6 billion budget gap the city was facing, Bloomberg worked the phone tirelessly and made numerous trips up to Albany. But he always returned empty-handed.
"I think Bloomberg started off with a little political naivete," ventures Guy Molinari, the former Staten Island borough president. (Bloomberg himself declined an interview for this story.) "I think he felt that if he made a case based on merit, he'd achieve a goal." He ponders this idea. "You also see a remarkable difference between what Pataki does and Bloomberg does," he adds. "If there are political chits to pick up, Pataki will pick them up. And Bloomberg won't." 
Case in point: just as the budget battle was slouching toward its ugly finish, Pataki nominated Diana Taylor to be the next state banking superintendent. By all accounts, she was qualified for the job, and she had held several jobs in the Pataki administration. But she also happened to be dating Bloomberg. The timing -- and the decision -- was impeccable. The governor managed to keep giving, even as he was trying to take away. 
Pataki is in his S.U.V. again, his six-foot-five frame collapsed in thirds, like a deck chair. "Straight ahead is Mount Beacon," he says, pointing with his Fresca bottle. "What's interesting is, Mount Beacon is where they first identified a separate species of hemlock. And the weeping hemlock is going to be an important part of the garden at -- " He gets distracted by something and motions at his driver. "Hey, Bobby! There's a motorcycle for sale!"
It's Earth Day -- a good day for Pataki, who even the crankiest Democrats concede has a fine record on the environment -- and we're going hiking in Fahnestock State Park. "Isn't this magnificent?" He points to a ravishing, lacy stretch of marshland. "I still think they should be called 'swamps' and not 'wetlands.' 'Wetlands' is a yuppied effort to make something more attractive. What's wrong with a swamp?"
Swamps, woodpeckers, snake dens, stone-wall formations: the governor's inner dork pours endearingly forth in anticipation of this setting. You can see the vestiges of the Peekskill farm kid who made his own radios, the mailman's son who showed up his freshman year at Yale in thick glasses and trousers that were too short. 
I ask him why, after eight and a half years, the public has never seen any hint of his natural looseness or sense of humor. Both drain right out of him. "I don't know. Ask the press."
But it's not just the press. 
"I don't know. That's just me. I can't worry about people."
I tell him it'd be nice to have his musings about it.
He's silent. "I just mused," he insists. Then he laughs. "I mused." 
In early 1994, John Zogby, a pollster in upstate New York, did a survey comparing the performance of each of eight Republicans in mock races against the incumbent governor, Mario Cuomo. At the last moment, he threw in Pataki's name. He came in last. But Pataki was still a virtual unknown. "So at the very end of the poll," Zogby explains, "we also said: 'What if you knew that George Pataki was the father of four, ran the family farm, was the mayor of Peekskill and had served four terms in the State Assembly and one in the Senate? Now, knowing what you know, whom would you vote for?' " 
Pataki pulled ahead of Cuomo, beating him by a 10-point margin: 41 to 31.
"The thing is," he slowly says, "nine years later, I don't know that George Pataki is any more than what he was in that one paragraph. Except you can now add three terms as governor."
It takes effort to remain that opaque, particularly in a media market like New York's. Part of it is that Pataki isn't driven by the same aggression and libidinal chaos that propel most men into public office. He's not angling to seduce everyone, as Bill Clinton always was; unlike Koch and D'Amato and Cuomo and Giuliani, he's not always spoiling for a fight. His ego is balanced, a true rarity in politics.
But dullness is also a shrewd media strategy. The governor almost never loses his temper publicly. His press conferences are rare, brief and uncontroversial. And he famously, comically, refuses to stray from the script. "In his early years as governor," Tom Carroll says, "you could ask him about the weather or how his kids were doing at Yale, and he'd still respond with a set message about tax cuts."
To ensure the maximum adherence to the message of the day, Pataki has always surrounded himself with painfully media-conscious advisers, who on their own time are a real "South Park" gang of vulgarians. Most are former employees of the original South Parker of New York politics, Senator Alfonse D'Amato (now on Park Avenue South, in his retirement). To hear them speak, it is sometimes hard to believe they're responsible for the governor's bland image and press strategy. To print most of what they say would be an exercise in reading around asterisks -- and yet it works. A former Pataki appointee recalls watching a new hire field a difficult phone call from a journalist. "Just tell them the governor's for lower taxes and the death penalty," screamed Zenia Mucha, his bellicose former communicationsdirector.
Pataki's aides complain that spontaneity in politicians is overvalued by the media. But Pataki pushes this idea to the breaking point. I asked him, for example, about Trent Lott, the Mississippi Republican whose nostalgic remarks about segregation cost him the title of senate majority leader. Had the governor issued a statement condemning them? At first, he said yes. A few minutes later, he said no. Then he said he couldn't remember. "I'm not exactly sure what we put out. Or didn't," he said. "I know I was asked. And I made it plain then that I thought it was wrong."
Alfonse D'Amato sits at his desk in his Park Avenue office, having a glass of extremely fine red wine, defending the man he handpicked nine years ago to defeat Mario Cuomo. "There is not a governor who ran in 2002 who said, 'I'm gonna raise taxes to cure the deficit,"' he says. Neither did most of their challengers, for that matter, including Carl McCall. In fact, McCall pledged not to raise them. "None!" he continues. "So why would you expect George Pataki to do something so idiotic?"
An appreciation for Realpolitik is one of the many things that D'Amato has passed on to his political protege. He has also passed on his communications directors (first Mucha, later Dewald Stoll), his chief fund-raiser (Charles Gargano, now head of the Empire State Development Corporation) and his two primary political strategists (the elusive Arthur Finkelstein; the garrulous Kieran Mahoney). Many of his friends are still the heads of New York agencies. The state wiring diagram, in fact, is still a series of loops connecting the former senator and the current governor. And the two men still socialize and speak frequently.
"If George Pataki raised taxes," D'Amato adds, "there'd be no discipline. There'd be spending on every cat and dog. And remember, when I was in office I was the biggest violator of that rule. I said, 'I'm going to get as much as I can for my state.' I never saw a road that New York didn't need. Or a bridge. Or a hospital. Or a program. Or a railroad."
The state certainly benefited from this arrangement, but so did all the contractors who oversaw the projects, and many of them subsequently became big donors to D'Amato and, in turn, to the giant Republican political machine the senator built. Because George Pataki is a tall, firm-boned graduate of Yale, it's easy to overlook the fact that he came up through this very machine. It's one reason he's so good at street politics.
D'Amato's assistant walks in, alerting him to a phone call from a former associate. 
"You need a spanking," D'Amato barks at the caller. "Or worse. You need -- " The rest of this sentence is unprintable. "You know what your problem is? You're working with these bloodsucking expletive , and you're becoming one. And you better make up with your lady friend! Because she'll -- " This sentence also ends badly.
"Well, you're my former protege," he says. "And I still love ya. But you don't steal a client from a friend. And you better call that lady and make love to her. Because she'll kill you. She will."
He hangs up and gloats. It occurs to me that perhaps one reason Pataki's handlers control him so tightly is that they all used to work for D'Amato.
"Well, look," he says. "You know, I was excessive, singing 'Old MacDonald' on the Senate floor -- 'Here a pork, there a pork, everywhere a pork-pork."' He might also have added calling Senator Charles Schumer "a putzhead" and doing a flagrantly racist impression of Judge Lance Ito. "So I think that maybe the people who worked with me were more sensitive to the fact that I had foot-and-mouth disease, which hurt me politically," he says. "It could be some kind of psychological thing, where they say, 'Look at Alfonse -- he had a promising career until he shot off his mouth one too many times.' "
The French ambassador suddenly appears on Fox News, which has been running on mute during our discussion. D'Amato scowls and uncurls his middle finger. "Weasel!" he shouts.
The governor is crunching along the hiking trail in Fahnestock State Park. Up in Albany, members of the Legislature are working on a budget of their own.
Are there moments, I ask him, when he ever wakes up in the middle of the night and thinks, What if I am blamed for the worst fiscal crisis in state history?
He chuckles. "No. Nooo. No. Never." 
He's silent for a bit. "We've laid out what I think is a good and reasonable solution," he says. "And assuming the Legislature ever acts, we will get through this time." 
He points at a blade of grass. "Hey. Look at that. It's a spring azure butterfly."
Whenever the governor sits at his desk in his private office, his head is crowned by a flock of stuffed birds that sit on a shelf behind him, giving him the look of a cartoon character who has been sucker-punched. And in a sense, that's what happened today, April 29: the New York State Legislature began voting to enact the budget Pataki deemed so ruinous to New York. Yet the governor is calm, almost sanguine, with no circles under his eyes, no anxiety distorting his face.
"I might turn it around," he says. "But tell me, why is it -- and this is something I found most frustrating as a legislator -- why is it that the members of each party delegate their responsibilities to one individual? That I have to negotiate with only two people is a very systemic flaw. If they hadn't delegated that authority, I'd talk to the legislators. I think the vast majority of the legislators in the Senate share my philosophy."
Pataki has complained before about the system in Albany, whereby decisions are made by three men in a room: the assembly speaker, the senate majority leader and the governor. But for the governor to blame that system for his current predicament seems a stretch. Most members of the Legislature will freely tell you that Pataki's ruling style is imperious, mysterious, aloof -- that he keeps his cards so close to his chest you can barely distinguish them from his shirt.
To lay this crisis at the feet of the State Senate's 74-year-old majority leader, Joseph Bruno, also strains credulity. Bruno is an old-fashioned politician, a guy with a horse farm, the sort who observes gentlemanly conventions of comity and cooperation. Pataki would never have been able to pass so many of those liberal bills if Bruno hadn't persuaded his fellow Republicans to do so -- sometimes against extreme odds. (The gay anti-discrimination bill, for example, started with only a handful of votes.) When the governor announced he'd be proposing a gun-control bill in 2000, Bruno and his colleagues first learned about it from watching ABC News. That didn't go over well. 
This year, however, Pataki put his Legislature in a position that even Bruno could not finesse. Pataki repeatedly declared he'd support no "job killing" new taxes, thus painting himself (and his lawmakers) into a corner; in January, he proposed a budget with cuts in education and health care so deep that any senator or assemblyman who supported them would have been run out of the district by an angry mob. Though Pataki has denied it, legislative leaders say he indicated that he wouldconsider raising New York's sales tax -- one of the few taxes that the elders of the national Republican Party might tolerate -- and let Bruno know he'd be willing to restore about $1.6 billion in spending. So Bruno and Sheldon Silver, the Democratic assembly speaker, went back to the books and came up with a budget that he thought would do the trick. Pataki disagreed. 
In previous odd-numbered years, the budget might have played out differently. But this year the state's coffers were empty; the Democrats controlled enough seats to override a veto; and the governor no longer had a goon squad to deliver votes for him. And this year, maybe for the first time, the distant goal of Washington seemed to matter more than the immediate conflict in Albany. So rather than trying to close the distance between the two positions, he simply walked away. 
If it was just Pataki's negotiating strategy, then clearly he didn't anticipate its effect: it drove Bruno into the arms of Silver, whom he and Pataki had so long conspired to contain. Together, Bruno and Silver hammered out a budget -- one that, unlike anything Bruno might have worked out with the governor, contained a personal income tax increase, a national Republican taboo. If it was just Bruno's negotiating strategy, then clearly he didn't anticipate that the governor would be so obstinate that he'd even allow an income tax increase on the wealthy to soar through on his watch. But as Tom Libous, a Republican senator and close ally of the governor's, says, "When this guy digs in, he's not going to move." 
Among certain constituencies -- people at the far end of either wing, generally -- it is now fashionable to suggest that the feuding between the governor and his two legislative leaders was all just an elaborately scripted work of political theater: Pataki knew his budget was untenable, and he knew the Legislature would come up with something more realistic. He'd get to look like a fiscal hawk, but New York would get the money it needed.
But that wouldn't account for how much he's now obsessing -- and smarting -- over the episode. In its aftermath, Bruno complained to his fellow Republicans that the governor sounded like a broken record, calling him every day to rehash the budget, demanding to know why he'd been betrayed. The senators would respond by cataloging the ways the state agencies had frozen them out, and by wondering aloud whether Pataki was ever going to get over it.
It's too soon to say whether the new budget will be as ruinous for New York as Pataki predicts, or how long the acrimony will continue. It could produce an endless volley of torments, in which the governor withholds money for legislators' pet projects, and they, in turn, malign him publicly, and he, in turn, freezes out their relations in patronage posts, and they, in turn, join with the Assembly Democrats for the next three years to pass budgets. But in September 2004, George W. Bush and tens of thousands of his supporters will descend on New York City for the Republican National Convention. A man with national political ambitions would be wise not to let out-of-town guests see him squabbling with his house staff. 
Odds are, Pataki and Bruno will find some working alliance. They're trapped together on the same desert island, after all; they need each other more than they'd each care to admit. "This is . . . a time," Pataki says. "I'll make you a bet right now as to where we are six months from now. I think we'll be working closely together and moving forward together as well as possible." Pataki has been known to mend some severely damaged fences. The evening of his first election as governor, in 1994, he was so furious with Rudolph Giuliani for endorsing Cuomo that he dismissed the mayor's congratulatory phone call with a two-word expletive and refused to speak with him for weeks. Their feuding didn't subside until Giuliani called the governor at his home in Garrison and told him he was gravely ill with prostate cancer.
Pataki invited him up for the weekend. "When he asked me on the phone, it seemed perfectly natural," Giuliani says. "But I think there was a point where I got in the car -- I was probably about a third of the way up -- and I started thinking: This is very strange. People would probably be really surprised we're doing this. I wonder what we'll talk about. But I'd often have that thought when we worked together. My reaction had always been that he's a very nice person. A good guy. Someone you could talk to." 
"It's the home of leaders," says one child.
"It's the home of change," says another.
The most recent I Love New York commercial features a sweet montage of grade-school kids posed against New York tourist sites. One little blond girl gets a close-up - so close that we can read the words on her T-shirt. 
"It's the home of the amazing. . . ."
"The inspiring. . . . "
Soon George Pataki's voice is heard: "This year, take your children home. Take them to New York."
The camera bounces back to the girl, whose T-shirt provides a felicitous subliminal subtext: "Future President." Then it moves on.
If Pataki is auditioning for a job in Washington, it is not clear, at this moment, that Washington has noticed. Washington is busy. "Look," Karl Rove says, "I hate to tell you, but I can tell you more about Section 79 drought relief than I can about what's going on in the New York State Senate." 
And how much, you wonder, has Pataki noticed about the unglamorous realities of Washington? In the Bush administration, the only genuinely powerful cabinet posts belong to the secretaries of defense, state and homeland security. Pataki's underqualified for one and two, and as for the third -- for which he obviously has some relevant experience -- the position's taken, at least for now. "I don't get any sense he has an interest in being a part of the administration," Rove says. "If he'd wanted to, he could have signaled it at the beginning of the term."
Pataki offers: "Actually, I would love to be secretary of state. I'm letting out a trade secret, but it's never going to happen. I've just always been fascinated by foreign policy."
Is that a suggestion? 
"No," he says firmly. "If it were a suggestion, I'd have suggested it to the president. Which I never have."
Which leaves, essentially, a shoot-the-moon bid for president in 2008, or the hope that he's fortunate enough to be tapped for vice president. 
In 2000, Libby Pataki, the governor's wife, says, they talked in some detail about what it would mean for the family if he were offered the job. "He was on the list," she says. "He was on the list." If that's the case, the governor can hardly be faulted for letting it shape his aspirations. But he took a startling gamble this spring, even if it did coincide with the beliefs of "the real George Pataki." It's hard to imagine why he would do so, in a state as liberal as New York. Then again, if you're a lame duck, you might as well bet the farm.
But Stephen Moore, one of the most important activists in the party's ascendant right wing, doesn't waste much time considering the odds. "It's impossible for him to be president," he flatly declares. 
Scott Reed, a Republican strategist, agrees: "For most Republicans around the country, New York and its politics are like Pluto."
Howard Wolfson, former head of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, says, "Let me put it this way: George Pataki is more liberal than many of the Democrats we had running for Congress in 2002." 
"I think a successful governor of a big state is bound to be taken seriously," says John McCain, the maverick Republican contender of 2000, as he struts through the Senate hallways early one May morning. McCain's campaign model is a point of intrigue for Pataki advisers. "Would it be possible for a Pataki campaign to skip campaigning in South Carolina and concentrate on California? Or a more moderate state whose principles would be more agreeable? So much of it is about expectations. Everyone thought it mattered that I skipped campaigning in Iowa, and it didn't." He pauses. "Having said that, I think he'd have rather dim prospects in the South."
For now, it seems, the best platform Pataki has to look forward to is Madison Square Garden in September 2004. And even there, Giuliani will doubtless upstage him. 
Still, he sometimes allows himself to daydream about what he might do with the opportunity. "I've always believed that the party should reflect the diversity of opinion not just within the country, but within the party, and that certainly includes a tolerant plank on choice," he says. "I'll make the case, make the arguments, as passionately and as vigorously as I can."
In the best of circumstances, budging the party's anti-abortion position even an inch would be an unfathomably huge feat. Only Pataki would dare to speak about it at the nadir of his power, when he's such a diminished version of himself. 
Even at the pinnacle of his power, after all, in the days of effortless wheeling and dealing, the governor couldn't always get his way. He kept his promise to Dan Klores and called Temple Emanu-El preschool on behalf of little Jake, whose application had been sent in late. But the governor's intervention couldn't save him. The child was rejected.

HEADLINE: 'Law & Order' To the Actors' Rescue 

BYLINE:  By VANESSA GRIGORIADIS

 BODY:
TO the residents of Craig Walker's SoHo neighborhood, he is mostly known as a talented barista. From 8 until noon, he plies his trade at Porto Rico Coffee on Thompson Street, a dimly lighted anti-Starbucks with the Rolling Stones on the stereo, paperback copies of Jacques Derrida in the sagging bookcase and a cluttered bulletin board advertising giveaway futons and classes at a local "D. J. university." 
 But Mr. Walker, 35, who has a shaved head and stands 6-foot-3, is also sometimes recognized for achievements beyond the espresso machine. "I was watching a 'Law & Order' rerun last night with my girl," a customer in chunky glasses told him the other day, "and I was like: 'I know that guy! How do I know that guy?' " 
 Mr. Walker grinned. "You know, man, I get that all the time," he said, grinding a pound of dark roast. 
Mr. Walker is one of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of struggling New York actors who owe their fame, and a share of their financial solvency, to the ever-expanding "Law & Order" franchise on NBC, which now includes the original crime drama, 13 years old, and two spinoffs. With each of the three shows producing about 22 episodes a season, and a supporting cast of at least 20 needed to play each episode's lawyers, police officers and gruesomely slain paralegals, the "Law & Order" industry has become the most important staple in a traditionally lean New York acting diet. 
"We have students who've been on it, instructors on it, even the artistic director of our playwriting affiliate," said Kathryn Eaker, managing director of HB Studio, which has been an acting school in Greenwich Village for over 50 years. "It's become a benchmark in an acting career -- 'Yippee, I landed my first spot on "Law & Order"!' "
A quick scan of Playbills from the Broadway hits "Nine," "Gypsy" and "Oscar Wilde's 'Salome' " shows 15 biographies listing a credit for "Law & Order." 
Dick Wolf, who created the redoubtable franchise -- its producer, Universal Television, is asking NBC for more than $550 million a year to keep it going, and a fourth spinoff is in the works -- said, "It's actually gotten to the point where if I go to the theater and open the Playbill and the actor doesn't have one of the 'Law & Orders' in his or her credits, I figure they either just got off the bus or they are really bad."
The "Law & Order" shows are not the only game in town. "Sex and the City," "The Sopranos" and "Third Watch" are also produced locally. But for character-actor roles of all ages and ethnicities, the "Law & Order" troika is unrivaled: the original series alone has meant over 36,400 days of work for New York actors since 1990 and has injected $602 million into the city's economy, the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting said. The three series -- the others are "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit," which began in 1999, and "Law & Order: Criminal Intent," dating from 2001, have so far produced 449 shows. 
"Quite frankly, I've started to think about holding an acting seminar for New York actors called 'Let's Talk About the Victim,' " said Roger Bart, a former star of "The Producers" on Broadway and a two-time "Law & Order" guest actor. "We'd only do monologues that begin with, 'Well, I didn't think much of him at first,' 'He was just a quiet neighbor,' 'I'd only dated her for two months.' "
For bit players used to scraping by on temping and coffee-bar tips, a "Law & Order" check can be the difference between canned tuna and sashimi. Those hired for a single day earn a Screen Actors Guild minimum of $655. Weekly performers are paid $2,272 and a lead guest star, $5,240. Residual fees from reruns can also be lucrative since the repeats are among the most popular on television. 
But even when the checks, which generally shrink with each rerun of an episode, grow tiny, they can still represent a lifeline for the proverbially starving New York actor. George Demas, who played the husband of a victim of medical malpractice ("She died during a routine laparoscopy -- don't ask me what that is"), said he received $1.22 for one rerun of the episode on TNT. "I didn't even frame that check," Mr. Demas said. "I cashed it. Now that's sad."
Aside from payment in whatever amount, "Law & Order" appearances add prestige to an actor's resume because the shows are critically respected, and even small parts are written with more depth than most television and film roles. With plot lines spun from headlines -- P. Diddy's trial after a nightclub shooting, Michael Jackson's dangling of his infant son from a window -- each episode follows a foolproof formula of crime, investigation and trial, presented with the methodical chronology of a police report and usually leading to the satisfaction of a conviction.
"If you choose to make your life in New York as an actor because you love theater and want to do theater or independent film, it's one of the only ways you can make some kind of money as an actor and still have integrity," said Marianne Hagan, a pretty strawberry blonde in a flowing blue caftan, who was nursing a cafe-au-lait-size cup of coffee alfresco at Les Deux Gamins, a cafe on Houston Street. 
Ms. Hagan was first cast on "Law & Order" when she returned from Los Angeles in 1997, fresh from a starring role in "Halloween 6." "I came back to New York to try to do theater, but everyone in New York was doing 'Law & Order,' " Ms. Hagan said. She was cast almost immediately. "I was like, 'Yes!' " she said, raising her cup in a toast. "I've returned back to New York, like Caesar returning from Gaul."
The original "Law & Order" has a history of showcasing future stars, with Julianna Margulies (as a navy lieutenant), Claire Danes (child model) and Laura Linney (in a Japanese white slavery ring) all appearing during their salad days. 
The jury is still out on what a guest spot actually does for a supporting actor's career. "The credit hasn't superseded Broadway in terms of casting, but it's allowed all of us who work in the business to see actors we might not have seen otherwise," said Tara Rubin, a casting director for "Mama Mia!" and "The Producers." 
But the parts these actors are playing might not be the ones they want casting directors to see. "I don't feel like a lawyer, but they always cast me as a lawyer," said Bob LuPone, who has appeared in sixepisodes. "It hasn't done anything for my career to bring me out of the fray, as it were, as a career actor."
Nor has Mr. Walker been able to turn his appearances into a career that lifts him out of his SoHo coffee bar. So far, he has made $15,000 to $20,000 for three guest spots on the "Law & Order" shows, but has yet to find an agent. "They can't figure out my type," he said, referring to Manhattan agents and casting directors. "I get a lot of 'downtown hipster guy.' I mean, what does that mean?" 
So Mr. Walker auditions mostly for commercials, like one for a beer. "It was a party scene," he said. "They hired a hypnotist, and the hypnotist says to one of the guys, 'You are a dog.' " Then another guest appears with beer. Everyone runs over to him, and the scene shifts to the hypnotized guest lapping water out of the toilet bowl -- " 'cause he's still a dog," Mr. Walker explained grimly. "And they wanted me to play the dog."
On the other hand, John Dossett, who is starring in "Gypsy" on Broadway, recalled that last year he missed an audition for "Dinner at Eight" at Lincoln Center but was cast anyway from a "Law & Order" tape.
Casting directors on the "Law & Order" shows maintain they now have a difficult time finding new faces -- which might be the first time in the history of the New York acting world that demand has outstripped supply. Last season, Mr. Wolf ordered directors to wait 60 days between casting the same actor twice in prominent guest roles on any of the three shows. "We don't want someone to tune in Wednesday night for 'Law & Order' and then Sunday night for 'Criminal Intent' and see the same actor playing the villain in one show and the cop in the other," said Gayle Keller, the casting director of "Criminal Intent." 
But as surely as BackStage appears once a week, New York actors will show up for an audition. On a rainy Thursday in June, 30 of them lined the gray-carpeted hallway of the Chelsea Piers offices where the three series are cast. This call was for an episode in the third season of "Criminal Intent," the story of a woman who avenges the death of her husband, a hit man, by marrying and then murdering the killer. (Kinky!) 
A New Yorker cartoon is on the casting assistant's corkboard: "In the criminal justice system, the courtrooms are cleaned every night by members of the cleaning crew. These are their stories."
Gripping dog-eared pages of script, actors trying out for mobster roles wore heavy gold chains and tight white T-shirts. Those reading for lawyers wore suits and carried leather portfolios under an arm. They had all dressed the part on their own -- including Peter Mele, in a bright orange jumpsuit with "State Prison" stenciled on the back, hoping to be cast as convict. "I'm a Mafioso about to be paroled in a week, but there have been some complications because my son took it upon himself to do some dirty work on my behalf," Mr. Mele said, explaining the role. "But business is business in the mob world," he continued. "When you come down to it, family don't mean nothing."
Mr. Mele shot a sideways glance at the "lawyers." "I don't know who these suits are," he grumbled. 
Stevie Ray Dallimore, auditioning for the part of a prosecutor, strode out of the casting room confidently, holding the hand of his 3-year-old daughter, Rose, in green galoshes. (Mr. Dallimore had brought her to save on the cost of baby-sitting.) 
"It went well," he said, "though she" -- he indicated Rose -- "stopped me in one of my speeches. She just said, 'I'm finished with my fruit snacks.' I stopped and then went on. It wasO.K." 
Later, he learned he did not get the part. "They're saving me for something better," he said.
